issue_title: Change task behaviour when dynamic parameter changes.
issue_contents: Thank you for providing this state machine
I am wondering if I could somehow tell my task to do a certain operation only if the parameters have changed.
I.e.
where I am looking for such
Cheers.
Hello,
You could do it this way and in this case, you could define your magic flag in the .cfg file corresponding to your task. You would then need dynamic_reconfigure GUI to update the flag.

However, I don't think this is the correct approach. It would make more sense for your task to create a service or a subscriber for this magic_flag event (maybe a std_msgs/Bool), and trigger the replanning using the appropriate ROS mechanisms. You could also put the subscriber/service in the environment is several tasks will need the same variables.

Update of the task parameters with dynamic reconfigure was designed initially for control gains, to make it easier to fine tune a task control law. I don't think they are the right mechanism for system-level interaction with the task.
I agree that it would be wrong to send a command to my node via rqt_reconfigure.

We currently use rqt_reconfigure to change the trajectory parameters, e.g., maximum velocity. And we were wondering if our task could only recalculate the trajectory if we change these parameters instead of constantly replan even if the parameters did not change. Kind of like a callback to the rqt_reconfigure server.
Maybe that's both the same and we should reconsider our design and replan on a specific event, e.g., service request.
If you have another idea of monitoring changing rqt_reconfigure parameters I'd appreciate. Otherwise you can consider the issue closed and I rework our design :)

The only alternative so far would be for you to store the value of the parameter (or the whole cfg structure) as a class member and check if it has been changed when entering iterate, this is typically how the  callbacks for dynamic reconfigure are implemented.

It would also be possible to add a ros::Time to the callback to record when the dynamic reconfigure callback was called but I am not sure this is the right design. Feel free to give it a go. The class that register the dynamic reconfigure server is TaskDefinition in task_manager_lib.

Thanks! These are plausible ideas. We will consider implementing one of both when the trajectory generation becomes a bottleneck! I'd maybe go for the second version as this does not require manually copying all parameters.
Hi,
I just found out that all task instance can overload the reconfigure function. This would be an easy way for you to handle your replanning only when a configure event has been triggered.
From TaskDefinition.h:
// Setup a dynamic reconfigure server that just update all the
// config. To be updated
virtual void reconfigure(CFG &config, uint32_t level) {
cfg = config;
Awesome!

has been defined as a package when it is supposed to be a stack. Please give it a proper name. Also a README file
to be there. Please fix it ASAP.

issue_title: Value of speedRight and speedLeft in the embedded code
issue_contents: Hi Chris

Nice to see your work, I have checked your embedded interfacing code to ROS. In that code i have a doubt regarding speedRight and speedLeft used in the odometry calculation. What is the value and where is it changing? i have seen its value always zero
Thanks
Lentin
Hi Lentin, thank you for looking at my code, and thank you for taking the time to comment!
speedLeft and speedRight are set in this line in the getticks() function:
The drive_getSpeedCalc() function is from the ArloBot libraries from Parallax.
This is the point in time speed, and is used to set V and Omega in this code here:
which is sent to the ROS propeller_node.py as the 5th and 6th fields of the odometry output.
The propeller_node.py uses this for the current forward and rotational speed.
They will be zero as long as the robot is stationary. They will only be non-zero while the robot is moving, and they will return to zero as soon as the robot stops.
If you start up the arlobot_bringup package:
and the teleop package:
and then watch the serial output:

while you drive the robot with the keyboard_teleop packge you can see the numbers for the V and Omega output (5th and 6th fields) become non-zero while the robot is in motion, and go back to zero when it stops. The 6th column will only become non-zero if there is rotation, so direct forward movement will leave it at zero.
Here is one output line for example:
Notice how he number 0.132 in the 5th field indicates a small forward speed and the -0.990 in the 6th field indicates rotation to the right at the speed of 0.990
Does this clear things up for you, or did I misunderstand your question?
Thanks for your reply :) Clearly written ..Can you send me your linkedin profile for connecting with you ?
Hey Lentin, if you look at any of the package.xml files in my source you will find an email address that you can reach me at. Shoot me an email and I will reply.

Some artificial base name is probably the best. E.g. like TICSync (
) but better of course :).
In general I would not call it (time / clock)
because we don't change any clock and therefore certainly do not perform synchronization. In fact we rather translate / map timestamps or times between different clocks.

I've just realized that it would be even better to call it
because hardware is a bit stupid as the main CPU is hardware too of course! Most accurate  would probably be
What about

is the better name to go for. In principle it could be used to translate the time of a different large CPU system as TICSync is used for example.

Context: the repo is meant to facilitate translating sensor hardware timestamps into CPU time and typically run within the device driver. But obviously it could be used for any (typically cheap) clock that you don't want to or cant synchronize for whatever reason.

+1 to CuckooSync! I am all in favor of catchy, fun names that you can repeat over and over again to annoy your officemates. Not offensive at all.

cheap_clock_sync/cheap_clock_time_translation is also good (because it's funny) and device_time_translation is probably the more boring accurate one. But cuckoo_time_translator/sync is best by far. :)
Also
I'm so glad you're writing this library! This will be a great asset in all of our device drivers, especially once open source.
Thanks a lot
, for your feedback!
Clearly it is going to be open source! But please don't expect new solve-it-all algorithms :). I merely want to collect what we use anyway and make it
to amend / fix an existing driver with all the HwClock functionality that you typically need and at the same time reduce the risk to do it all wrong (possibly without knowing).
Optionally I'm aiming at providing the user with parameters and data to tune the clcok translation without extra cost for the driver developer.
Then I'd say it is
for namespace and repo and CuckooTranslator as short(er) name.
(of course CuckooSync sounds even nicer and refers to more standard concepts. But IMO it is just much more wrong :) )

issue_title: How to adjust the configuration defaults based on the package using it?
issue_contents: This doesn't seem to me like a nice solution for the client code :
do you know a nice way the library code could make that easier?
(Ideally when creating the device time translator the client package can provide specific defaults).
I have no better idea than to create a child class for the generated dynamic reconfigure class and shadow the internal static
method :(.
Is there a way on the ros paramter / launch file side? (consider me still a ROS-newbie)
Looking through and I agree what I did was a bit ugly. I should have used the setExpectedAlgo function.

The only issue then is that this change would not be shown in the dynamic reconfigure. However it seems this can be updated using dynamic_reconfigure_server.updateConfig(config); which would just need to be added to the setExpectedAlgo function call.
, I didn't mean to criticize your solution! I merely criticised my library for not providing a nice option - to you :).
I agree that setExpectedAlgo isn't the right solution either (it is more low level) and doesn't play nicely with the dynamic reconfigure.
My problem with most solutions that I see and also a potential
is that it would override what somebody provided as value from the launch file, or is that wrong? And also an existing configuration in a already running dynamic reconfigure GUI, if I'm not mistaken.

From a purely conceptional point of view, what I want to give to the client code is changing the default for the dynamic reconfigure configuration. This is also possibly given the design of dynamic reconfigure itself. But I can't find the why how the others intended to support this.

If there really is no nice way to do this, I'd consider that a major flaw of dynamic reconfigure because it basically prevents nice modular design as soon as a module should be dynamically reconfigurable.
I'm afraid I have to try the crazy child solution and shadow the
With dynamic reconfigure if a parameter exists when it starts it will take this value rather than the default.
This means you could do what I did in the client side internally in the constructor before the server starts to achieve the results you want.
Ah thanks for explaining. Yes, I guess that was what I wanted :). I didn't expect it work precisely this way, but apparently it does :). Thanks a lot!

issue_contents: I'm using the catkin branch of this repo, on a ROS indigo/Ubuntu trusty system. I'm sending IMU and Odometry information to message_to_tf using the libhector_gazebo_ros_imu and libgazebo_ros_p3d plugins. The base_link -> base_stabilized tf published by message_to_tf switches intermittently between
and
After some investigation, in the part of imuCallback that creates this transform, the translation is never set. Adding a
resolves the issue. Does this make sense as a fix?
Fixed in
It was indeed a bug as
is not default initialized (other than ROS messages). Additionally, the published pose from an IMU orientation was not initialized correctly if the
parameter is set to false.
Thanks for reporting this!

Note that you should not have two input topics to the same message_to_tf node. It would publish the same transforms from different data sources. In the case of libhector_gazebo_ros_imu and libgazebo_ros_p3d the orientation error is calculated differently and message_to_tf would publish slightly different roll/pitch transforms from
to
depending on the parameter settings.
I see. I was wondering what the slight glitchiness was about. Thanks!

thank you for the detailed report. Sorry for the late reply. Actually you are reporting two problems:
Strangely, I cannot reproduce it. Is it a fresh workspace? Maybe there is some old stuff lying around. I could have a look at your workspace, if it still there?
There is an important and breaking change I should have announced properly: the correct import is now
So, they are no longer hoisted into the former umbrella module
The sad background is a ros design that I just don't get a nice solution to:
The cpp package cuckoo_time_translator creates implicitly a python module due to the included dynamic configuration and messages. It even creates a
file for the module possibly overriding whatever the cuckoo_time_translator_python package does provide for the python module cuckoo_time_translator.
The anticipated and common solution is to create a python module in the package cuckoo_time_translator_python with identical name. But I'm somehow reluctant to require an
for python. The

prefix seems like superfluous nonsense to me. Do you know a good solution? (moving the messages to a separate package, e.g. cuckoo_time_translator_msg is an interesting idea. However, it doesn't solve the problem because of the dynamic reconfigure support in cuckoo_time_translator, which already creates a python module called
Update on 1: I could reproduce it eventually. (It was my workspace having other stuff impacting it, namely the already build cpp package
, preventing this failure to appear).
My solution is PR
Update on 2.: I gave up my principles and followed the mainstream with (
) - the former design has cost already too much time.
Closing this issue since PRs
and
should solve it. Please reopen if problems persist.
Solves our compilation. Thanks!

issue_contents: Hi
Thanks again for your framework!
When calling
where
is
and
is
we get the error:
No pressure but whenever you have time we would be happy to get some feedback.

I believe, this is a wrong usage. If you are having a ROS time you probably don't have to unwrap it (unwrapping is more for hardware counters that wrap frequently). What you probably want instead is a
Sorry, I did a wrong problem formulation.
is
, our hardware timestamp in micro seconds.
Ah, okay. And you only want to translate? I.e. you don't want to update the translator? (updating you would do with

Line 138
      in
If so you would need to use

Line 150
      in
Maybe there is a misconception somewhere? To catch these the library is typed so rigorously...
Maybe I should elaborate our setup for you to see if it makes sense.

We readout several sensors / sensor timestamps on a microcontroller, set the microcontroller clock time on receive time, send the data via serial to a computer and translate the timestamp into the computer clock time.

Our thought was that we only update the cuckoo filter on the IMU message (or even a PPS signal from the arduino) where we can insure the same message size and try to keep constant frequency. All other message timestamps then only get translated.
or different channels to receive messages from the same clock with different mean transport delay.
I guess this is our case?

Ah. Thanks. Awesome diagram :). Yes, I think you are pretty much in that case. So, you need the separate unwrap. Just make sure that you call it in the order in which the packages arrive through the serial connection.
However, since you seem to have the micro controller under your control I see more accurate alternatives:

Line 183
      in
But I guess using the IMU message is also a good start. And you are very close to that solution.Maybe keep the alternatives in mind in case you are not happy with the result.

Btw. in you image I can't see RS232 or similar connections on the computer. Are you using a USB to RS232 adapter? Those are really, really bad in terms of random delays! Mostly due to the flaws of USB (<= 2.0). For the timestamps you can get away through the translation. But if you get a 100ms delay spike (I've seen such) you actually might miss the message in the processing. In theory USB3 adapters could be much better (leveraging the USB3 support for interrupts) but probably they are hard to get.
Thanks for your comments! We will first try the oneway unwrapping strategy and if we have time (or it is unsufficient) we will try to use this library with transmission timestamps.
Btw. in you image I can't see RS232 or similar connections on the computer. Are you using a USB to RS232 adapter?
We use a
which has an embedded Intel Curie microcontroller.
. Any opinion on the

Ah, interesting! Thanks for the links. Actually this design looks quite troublesome to me timing wise. So sad. The SoC has two UARTs (typically very low latency) but instead of using one of them for the link they use USB that gets probably converted to a serial signal anyway because otherwise it wouldn't be like an Arduino.. Unbelievable.

On the bright side it seems like a dedicated USB port. Hence, the random delays are probably around 10ms (wild guessing). Eventually you might want to do a simple ping test from the SoC to the uC and back and observe the randomness of the two way latency.

If it is all to bad I would look into creating second link through one of the UARTs, that comes out of the expansion connector 2. You can probably connect it to the digital IO of the mC and create a proper serial connection with low latency (probably below 1 micro second) that you can use for synchronization.

If that is too much work you could have a look increasing USB polling rate -- because that is what happens prior to USB3.0 : the devices get polled for new events! But the polling is not the only timing problem with USB on Linux...
issue_quotes: or different channels to receive messages from the same clock with different mean transport delay.
Btw. in you image I can't see RS232 or similar connections on the computer. Are you using a USB to RS232 adapter?

issue_contents: The ROS documentation is so lacking and I'm trying to get up to speed as quickly as possible. Are you willing to tutor me in getting started? I would be thrilled to be able to accomplish what you demonstrated in your arlobot video. I would be happy to compensate you for your time.
You can reach me at dan  electricmovement.com
I already answered this via email, but for future onlookers.
No, I don't have time to tutor, although I do carry on regular email correspondence with several people who are building ArloBot. I can answer any questions here or in email.
If you want to learn ROS, better than I know it, I suggest the ROS by Example books:
Hi Chis,
First, I can't thank you enough for putting all of this together! You've given all of us a huge jumpstart on creating our own arlobots.
I'm getting an error "Error: Cannot find module 'roslib'" when I try to run the StartRobot.sh script.
I am running Ubuntu 14.04 and I just did a fresh install a couple of days ago. I used your install script to install ROS and your packages.
Any idea what I'm doing wrong?
My first guess is some sort of problem with your environment, that is to say, with the list of variables the shell has for where to find things.
That should all be automatically set up by scripts that run every time you log in now.
The most important one being ~/catkin_ws/devel/setup.bash, which tells the shell where to find ROS and all of the Arlobot packages.
Is the line 'source ~/catkin_ws/devel/setup.bash' in your ~/.bashrc file? It should have been put there by the setup.
What happens when you run 'roscd roslib'? If that command doesn't work, then the shell environment is certainly not right.
I apologize in advance if I'm missing something obvious. I should note that I  am new to Linux and ROS so this issue is probably something I am doing wrong.
I decided to just start over with a fresh install of Lubuntu then I ran your script to install everything again.
When I double-click on the ArloBot icon on the desktop it brings up a terminal window and then brings up Firefox and I get an error in Firefox "unable to connect"
Then when I just open a new terminal and run the StartRobot.sh I am still getting the same error.
I'm sure that you're right about it being my environment, but being new to both linux and ROS I'm not sure what I'm doing wrong.
Here's a screenshot of what I get when I run StartRobot.sh and then roscd roslib:
Thanks again for not only taking the time to put this together, but also to help newbs like me!
I'm glad that you reinstalled, because I fixed a lot of issues. I see I still have an issue though.

Would it be possible for you to run the install script again? You do NOT have to rebuild or anything, you can just run the install again right over the old install, it will just update/fix it. I run it over and over.
Here is the command again:
and send me all of the output?
You should be able to copy and paste it from the terminal session. Just use your mouse to select it, and right click to get the menu to "Copy"
I would like to see what the output is to see if it shows why it isn't installing all of the packages.
After you do that, what might fix the issue is to run these commands:
If you do run those commands, please send me the output if there is any,

issue_title: nodejs package problems (NaN, contextify, ngrok, log.io)
issue_contents: a number of the nodejs packages seem to have gotten themselves broken and require the latest NaN.js.. fixed by going into the node folder ~/catkin_ws/src/Metatron/node/
nvm stable
npm install nan
then npm install

Also found I had to find every instance of contextify mentioned (even in the node modules folders of the node modules installed) and change to the latest version (for log.io I had to actually install contextify globally)
ngrok needed to be updated to 0.2.2 to allow it to build as well as to get log.io working (i think.. it was really late, and my notes got a bit.. er, scrawley there at the end)
figured I'd share where I am so far in case anyone else runs into it. Knowing how nodejs packages work.. they probably will.

current issue seems to be after I get the startRobot.sh to go, I start ros (the running log states ROS successfully started, but the upper left indicator sticks at "startROS starting up . . .") remote control screen states it's not connected, and the log streamer keeps cycling that it is resetting a relay and waiting for the PAB to "settle down" though I has no relay. heh, will post another issue if/when I track that one down.
thanks by the way, for sharing all of your work on this so far, I'd still be muddling around the ROS tutorials deciding if I wanted to start getting a bot together if I hadn't ran across this.
Thanks. Could this be because of using node 4.0?
I just changed the code today to use 0.12.7 instead of "stable" because I found it doesn't work with 4.0, but if this can make 4.0 work then I'll make the changes and update.
using 4.1.1 according to nvm, really, this is just one of the fun quirks of using nodejs and npm i've found. it's like linux 10 years ago. haha
Good to know. My guess is that this is an issue with the node version.
If you run the setup again now it will install node 0.12.7 and use it.

The entire idea of npm and nvm is to be able to develop in and deploy a consistent version so you can be confident things will work. However I broke that by having it use "stable" instead of a specific version.
That said, with your notes here I can probably get it up to 4.1.1

I pulled ngrok out. I'm not using it anymore. It was only there for use with Twilio for incoming SMS messages to the robot, but it requires a paid account now to be stable, so I'm not going to use ngrok anymore. It never worked "out of the box" anyway, so I'll leave Twilio to a blog post later if other people want to try it.
That fixes the ngrok issue. Next for log.io
i'll give it shot in an hour or so
saw no errors rerunning the install script this time. almost everything fired up!
log streamer won't start (no error, just click and nothing, will investigate)
new error after turning on ROS run (error:parameter [/movebase] is not set)
and I'll have to re-comment the toggle relay stuff
and a weird bit of stuff coming up in the status window of the main page.. will track down and open a new issue for anything I find.. i think this bugger is done!
Thanks, I made some updates based on what you told me here, so this was very helpful. I'll close this down now.
Please do open new issues with anything else you find.

"Watchdog Timeout Reset initiated" means that the serial communication is not working. It is timing out waiting for data form the Propeller board and then trying again.
So yes, the kernel issue would cause this, but if you went to -63 it isn't the Kernel.
Did you use SimpleIDE to install the code on the Propeller board?
In ~/catkin_ws/src/Metatron/scripts/ there is a script called direct2PropSerialTest.sh that you can use to test communication with your Propeller board, make sure it works.

There is also a file in the same location called direct2PropSerialTestLines.txt with some test lines to run. You don't need to run all of them, in fact, if you just get the "i     0" lines back from the script then it should all work, but the lines help with future testing.
P.S. And I'm going to look into the USB Relay issue. I haven't tested in a long time without it, so I must have missed something.

direct2PropSerialTest.sh has been my current mountain, it returns the "i 0" until i try a test line, then sometimes it returns garbage, other times it just hangs until the world freezes over. Interestingly enough, if I restart the script, it sends data still "i 0" nothing new sadly

Before you built and installed the code on the Propeller board did you edit the settings in ~/.arlobot/per_robot_settings_for_propeller_c_code.h and did it use them?
If those settings are wrong it might work right up until you initialize it with some text, and then it will try to access some hardware you don't have and hang.
Did you try sending text to it inside of SimpleIDE? I think that it uses a completely different serial interface driver, because it worked even with the broken kernel.
You might look here at the full duplex serial code:

Finally, if you are sure it is using the settings from ~/.arlobot/per_robot_settings_for_propeller_c_code.h and that they are right, just get into SimpleIDE and start tearing apart the code and running it in the local terminal inside of SimpleIDE,

The first thing I would do is just change the code so that when you send it something it just replies with some generic text like "Hello world" and loops back to the "i 0" part, just to prove that you can receive data from it.

Then you can just kind of work down the code, stopping it at different places with a line from the code to you and watch it in the SimpleIDE terminal. You can even just put an output line after every line of code and eventually you will find what line is causing it to stall.

P.S. You can even just change it so that it "initializes" itself in the code, for testing, so you don't have to send it a line. I think there is even a commented out line in the code to do that for when I need to test things.

Unresponsive motor only occurs when we run it through arlobot from your teleop script. Though numbers/data (supposedly motor speed prop.) flies back to terminal, the motor is idle.
The output of the command "rostopic echo serial" before, during and after you attempt to move the robot would help.

btw here it is, through arlobot_teleop

during
i did a "rostopic echo serial |grep out" and the data is plain 0 in all execute phases(before,during,after)
The constant "out: s,0.0,0.0" is telling the Propeller board to shut the motors off and be perfectly still.
Normally when ROS is running you will not get any of these lines. Whatever ROS node is sending the s,0.0,0.0 is keeping the robot still.
You should see positive and negative numbers for motion.
The command:
rostopic echo /cmd_vel_mux/active
will tell you what ROS node is active and keeping the robot still.
Usually you only get constant 0.0 output if you have the keyboard teleop running.
If a joystick is online it can do this too.

When you build a map the "0" location is the point where you started to build the map.
When you load the map it will always assume the robot is at that same position.
In RViz you can set the robot's current position using the '2D Pose Estimate'

Still can't use the Arlobot/startRobot.sh, but I don't need the GUI so that is OK.  Currently, the robot does not move when I send it a target velocity with the keyboard, but this problem is within the propeller C code and I have a hunch it is a result of not having the relay board, IR sensors, or ultrasonics connected, so I'll go through and try to edit the code. It should work fine without the relay board, especially with the new DHB-10, because it does not rely on the relay board for proper startup sequence anymore. Although a bug is always possible.
Make sure the settings in arlobot.yaml and per_robot_settings_for_propeller_c_code.h in ~/.arlobot are correct.
Also, if you have ROS running be sure to monitor
The two questions are:
on the other hand
There are some details about this in This is all explained in
So if the first number is a 0, then yes, the propeller C code is refusing to move the robot forward because it thinks a PING sensor is blocked.
Also, if the C code is polling a nonexistent PING sensor, or one that is just unplugged, it will get a ZERO distance reading, which would block the robot.
If that is the case, it should be easy to hack the propeller code to skip the blocking sequence and reload it.
It should work by just setting there to be no PING sensors in ~/.arlobot/per_robot_settings_for_propeller_c_code.h and reloading it, but I haven't tested that scenario recently.

P.S. If you can get the web interface to work it will really help. One of the primary reasons I built it was to be able to monitor all of these outputs and inputs from a single graphic interface instead of having to constantly run commands in terminals to pick up dozens of bits if data from all over the place.
Finally got the PING sensors working and keyboard teleop working, but only after i copied the per_robot_settings_for_propeller_c_code.h file into same directory as the propellor .c files.

thanks Chris!
Chris,

This instructions were very helpful.  I got everything up and running in ROS including the web based GUI.  It now sends correct commands to the propeller via serial when I use the keyboard or the web interface.

However, an issue I am still encountering is that the wheels move erratically when I send a command.  For example, if there is a single forward command, they immediately turn on at a high speed and do not turn off when the forward button is released.  If the back button is depressed (or clicked on GUI) then the wheels alternately pulse in a seemingly nonsensical way.
When I ran a simple motor test using the following code, the wheels turn at the correct speed:
int main()                                    // Main function
drive_feedback(0);                          // Disable encoders
drive_speed(20, 20);                        // 20/127 of full power to motors

However, if drive_feedback(0) is commented out, then the wheels turn in a similarly erratic speed as described above.  I think the problem is somewhere in the propeller code as I'm sure it is getting the right signal serially, but I just don't know what is going on.  I modified the arlobot.yaml and per_robot_settings_for_propeller_c_code.h as per instructions but the problem persists.
Thank you for your help. :)
Henry C.
Which motor controller(s) are you using?
The "drive_speed(20, 20);" line is only used in the HB25 code.
If you have a DHB-10, are you sure you are using the right propeller code file?
Chris,
I am using the DHB-10 and I am sure it is the right propeller file.  Appears that the 'drive_speed(20, 20) works for this controller as well.
Henry C.

I dug in more deeply and found that the encoders weren't registering, and found that the black discs were rubbing against the side of the encoder.  Both of them were clogged with plastic residue from the discs wearing off into where the IR emits light.  This problem is caused by poor tolerances in manufacturing.  So, I rigged up a solution by adding extra washers in the hex bolts and a larger washer around the driveshaft to add a millimeter of clearance.  This allowed the encoder connected to motor 1 to work as expected, however, motor 2 still did not register any 'ticks' upon testing.  FYI, here is the code I used:

Thinking the problem was one of the encoder assemblies, I swapped them just to be sure and surprisingly, motor 1's encoder still worked fine but motor 2 did not.  I also made sure all encoder assemblies had power, which they did.  Thus, I believe issue is in the encoder receiving end of the DHB-10 where motor 2 is connected.  I checked and double checked this and I am sure that both encoder assemblies work, and the problem is in the DHB-10.  Re-uploaded firmware to no avail.  Next plan is to bring in my logic analyser (at home, I'm at office) and compare encoder data signals.

This makes two significant issues with the stock kit, on top of the fact that multiple wires, screws, and nuts were missing from the kit when I bought it.  I'm quite displeased this, but really appreciate your efforts in this ROS package and the help here. :)
Happy New Years !
Henry C.
That is very concerning. If I were you in would call Parallax and discuss this with them. They have been very responsive to any quality concerns I have brought up.
Chris,

Parallax sent me a different DHB-10 and it worked immediately.  They also sent replacements for the parts that were missing.  Your code is all up and working and I can drive the robot!  There is a bit of lag driving it with the joystick and the wheels move quite swiftly, but this is something I will tackle and worry about later.  Thank you for your help, and happy Martin Luther King Jr. Day!
Henry C.

issue_title: Joystick control latency and timeout problem
issue_contents: Hi Chris,
Hope you are doing well.  I have a couple questions about the Propeller code.

First, there is a delay of about 0.5 - 1.0 seconds when I use the joystick to drive the base.  To see where this may be cropping up, I edited the following line which is around 590 in the ROSInterfaceForArlobotWithDHB-10.c:
//dprint(term, "o\t%.3f\t%.3f\t%.3f\t%.3f\t%.3f\t%.3f\t", X, Y, Heading, gyroHeading, V, Omega);
dprint(term, "o\t%.3f\t%.3f\t%.3f\t%.3f\t%.3f\t%.3f\t", X, Y, Heading, CommandedVelocity, V, Omega);

Thus, the velocity from the DHB-10 feedback, V, is compared to the CommandedVelocity at each time step on the ROS interface by adding a rospylog line to one of the scripts.  There is definitely a lag going on there--and I'd like to see what I do to fix it.

The next issue is that when I am driving forward on my joystick, the timeoutCounter frequently becomes higher than the ROStimeout timer and it throws a clearTwistRequest(), resulting in an inconsistent halting of the wheels for 2-10 seconds.  This does not happen when I am driving backwards, but it does happen when I send rotate commands, where one wheel or the other is driving forward.  I tried commenting out the clearTwistRequest(), but instead of halting the robot becomes uncontrollable for that time period.  I think the problem is occurring in the serial buffer, and perhaps some characters throw more errors than others.  Do you have suggestions on this before I dig really deep on my own?
Thank you !
Henry C.
Glad to see your interest!
Unfortunately I don't have an answer. I am aware that the code using the DHB-10 controller has issues.
The odometry from it seems to be impeccable, but the control input is problematic.
My best guess is that it is either just slow by nature, or that it has some sort of "ramping" built into it which forces it to respond slowly.
That doesn't explain why it seems to still say it is moving when it is stopped.
Your notes actually helped explain more than I knew before.
I keep dabbling with it, but I don't have a lot of time lately to focus on it lately.
So if you can sort anything out that would be wonderful.
It may be that the Propeller code needs a complete overhaul, or maybe there is just some logic flaw in my setup that is hampering it.
Hi Chris,
Thanks for letting me know!! I will keep you posted if I find a solution.
Warmth,
Henry C.
I am receiving 'could not find a package configuration file provided by "PACKAGE_NAME" with any of the the following names' errors.
I am using Ubuntu 14.04 LTS on VMWare Workstation 12 Pro and ROS Indigo.
I have tried manually installing the packages but eventually i get to a package called "ceres" and can't progress any further.
I have also tried removing and reinstalling ROS Indigo and have not seen any results.
Sorry, I am at a loss here.

Maybe you could try that?

issue_contents: Greetings,

I was wondering if the quickstart board mentioned in the installation guide is necessary? When I try to run the  ./start-arlobot-only.sh or ./start-robot.sh script I get an error saying there is no quickstart board connected.
Is there a way for me to make the script ignore this, since I don't have a quickstart board?
Kind regards.
Sorry for the late reply. I'm not sure why it took me so long to see this.
If you edit ~/.arlobot/personalDataForBehavior.json
and change "hasQuickStartBoard": true, to "hasQuickStartBoard": false,
it should fix that.
Although I'm not sure why it was set to true.
If that doesn't fix it, then the error is in the file:
or on your system:
~/catkin_ws/src/ArloBot/scripts/check_hardware.sh
Where hopefully you can fix it. :)

I believe that some dependencies I was relying on got out of date.
I've since removed them and changed my code. It appears to compile correctly now.

issue_contents: Tried to run scripts from manualTests.txt but got an ImportError: No module named msg. Lubuntu 16.04, installed everything by using quick install script.

Hi. I recently had a similar problem. In my case, I was not getting a clean result from catkin_make due to some missing dependencies in the sweep_ros package.  I worked around it for now by deleting the sweep_ros directory and re-running catkin_make.
You can also try running
catkin_make -DCATKIN_WHITELIST_PACKAGES="arlobot_msgs"
to just build the arlobot_msgs package and see if that gets you any further. Just be sure to clear the whitelist later on if you do this by running
catkin_make -DCATKIN_WHITELIST_PACKAGES=""
There is a "ROS for Arlobot" Google Group you may want to check out.
Good Luck!
Thanks for help, I didn't delete the folder, just run
catkin_make -DCATKIN_WHITELIST_PACKAGES="arlobot_msgs"
and now I'm not getting that error, so I'm closing this issue

Hi, I checked out issue 32 and it indeed solved the issue after rebuilding a clean one. Thank's very much. As for what I meant in the parenthesis, when I run in the terminal the direct2PropSerialTest.sh, I get the return listed above with
instead of getting a stream of i  0. When I open simpleide instead and load EEPROM and run, I'll see the stream of i   0 in the simple IDE terminal.

Although, now I can run my keyboard teleop however I'm running into a new error now.  I can only turn left and right using the teleop. (J key and L key are only keys that work. I'm not sure if this is related to my earlier issue and if I should open a new post for this (Very new to github). Edit: also when I open the rviz, when I hit the other teleop commands, the model doesn't move up/down, etc. Only the turning commands will show up in RVIZ as well.

A quick suggestion as I don't have much time now: possibly check the "blocked" and "safe to proceed" status bits that get transmitted to see if the robot thinks it is trapped. This could be preventing it from moving forward or backward and could be due to some sensor configuration error. I think I may have had a similar problem.

" error when running direct2PropSerialTest.sh

In my case, the problem seems to be with find_ActivityBoard.sh when it does not initially find a "Propeller_Activity_Brd". Some of the text information echoed is being interpreted by miniterm.py as a baud rate which causes the problem.

Great, thanks much for your help to fix the initial issue. I actually have a new different serial issue though, but since this one is resolved, I will close it. With limited ROS knowledge, trying to get this set up has been frustrating. I'm lucky to receive help, though. Thank you.

issue_contents: I am having an issue getting my arlobot to start-up. I previously had my teleop half working (only angular rotation, no vertical movement), but after loading in a code where I changed my sensor configurations to try to fix the issue I started to get this error and teleop will no longer work. Loading in the previous code that half-worked, I still get this issue now when I run roslaunch arlobot_bringup minimal.launch --screen and run the teleop command in another terminal. My new error starts at the Watchdog Timeout Reset line.

I have been modifying and uploading the latest propeller code over the past couple of days keeping an eye out for serial data problems. The only time I have seen problems is when I accidentally have a terminal connected to the serial port when I run roslaunch arlobot_bringup minimal.launch --screen.
Have you made any progress with this issue?

Hi, I took a long break from this project due to being busy with summer classes. I'm returning, but I'm still having no luck with this. What do you mean by having a terminal connected to a serial port? My process is: start a roscore, run arlobot_bringup minimal.launch --screen, and then run arlobot_teleop keyboard_teleop.launch.

I meant having a program with a terminal like simple IDE or an arduino IDE open on the same computer that is running ROS at the same time you are attempting to run ROS. The only time I have seen serial problems was following direct terminal interaction with the propeller board when I forgot to close the terminal program before launching ROS.

Oh, I see. Yeah I occasionally had that issue too where I forgot to close SimpleIDE before moving on; however it doesn't seem that to be the case to the error this time. I'm going to be doing various things to try to troubleshoot today so I'll get back here with my efforts soon.
I've not fixed the problem but I've found something new that might be interesting.

I was running arlobot_bringup minimal.launch --screen and saw I had forgot to turn on the MAIN and the MOTORS rocker switches. I wasn't getting the serial issue and the terminal just stayed static with the regular:
[ INFO] [1529470291.636239200]: CmdVelMux : (re)configured
[INFO] [1529470292.581021]: Starting with serial port: /dev/ttyUSB0, baud rate: 115200
[INFO] [1529470292.581247]: Starting OdomStationaryBroadcaster
[INFO] [1529470292.581683]: Serial Data Gateway starting . . .
[INFO] [1529470292.582722]: Serial Data Gateway started.
[INFO] [1529470292.582893]: Propellerbot_node has started.
[INFO] [1529470292.611700]: No USB Relay board installed.

The same happens and I don't get the error when I turn on the MAIN rocker switch and keep the MOTORS rocker switch off. As soon as I try running minimal.launch --screen with the MOTORS rocker switch on, I will start to get the continuous errors as seen on the first post. Also, I let it run for a while and I saw I got a line in yellow stating
[WARN] [1533791923.129673]: Short line from Propeller board: 1688.
I'm not sure what this means, if I have some sort of short? This is new. Because of this, I'm thinking it /may/ have something to do with the motors or the motor controller board.
I ran all of the connection tests provided by Parallax and all of them passed. I don't think there are any errors with the board or the motors.

UPDATE 1: I just re-installed Ubuntu 16.04.4 on a different laptop, ran the quick install script for ROS all over again. Removed Scanse Sweep and ran a clean catkin_make. Error persists before and after updating per_robot_settings_for_propeller_c_code.h.
Hi,
A couple of ideas, probably long shots.
Sorry I can not be more help.
Hi Vatbrain,
Yeah I've added my id to dialout already (it was already added during the quick install too), so I don't think that is the problem too much.
I haven't actually done the disable USB power; I'm just the robot to my computer via the mini-usb. I tried multiple mini-usb to see if that was the issue yet no.
Yeah, the board is set at 2 as well. I tried it at both switch positions.

Looking at a previous opened issue, Chris stated that the Watchdog Timeout Reset initiated signifies that the serial communication doesn't work, and times out and resets while waiting for data from the board and tries again. It seems fine; I can still load in code properly. When it's connected to ros and I have teleop running, hold down some keys, I have both the RX and TX lights flashing, and the serial light is on too; until it times out for a bit.

I was thinking something was on in the per_robot_settings_for_propeller_c_code.h, so that when I turned on the motor switch making the DHB-10 turn on, something became initialized and the propeller board was constantly waiting for information back from it, since the timeout happens only when when I turn on the motor controller; however, I ran all the encoder and motor tests and they seem to all be communicating well. When it's off, the four ping sensor configuration still flashes its green lights signifying its working.

I thought my board might be the problem so I just got a new Activity Board, hooked it up, loaded stuff in, but still no luck. The only thing I need to be changing is the per_robot_settings_for_propeller_c_code.h right?

Thanks for staying in communication and lending me some suggestions I really appreciate it. I just need for ROS to be able to connect with the board so I could move on to use it with my own research at my university. It's becoming extremely frustrating because this is just the only step I need to work before I can move on, yet I've no clue how to fix this issue.
Hi,

If you post/attach your  per_robot_settings_for_propeller_c_code.h, I'd be happy to compare it to mine and see if anything jumps out at me.  The other files that might be interesting to compare would be propellerbot_node.py and SerialDataGateway.py just to see if we are using the same versions.
Great; I will do that first thing tomorrow morning when I get back to my work station. Also, I'm quite new to github. What/where is the best way for me to upload this code for you to view it?

I'm pretty new to github myself. I see the note at the bottom of the box where I am entering this that says "Attach files by dragging & dropping, selecting them, or pasting from the clipboard". That sounds like the simplest way to me. I just tried to drag and drop my per_robot_settings... .h file and it gave me a message that it does not support that file type. It did list ZIP as a listed type, so you could try zipping the files together and then dragging and dropping. I suspect the correct way would be for you to fork Chris's repository and upload your changes to your own fork. I have done this, but it is more involved.
I can't promise that I will get to comparing the files quickly, as I am going to be quite busy the next couple of days, but I should have more time after that.

That's completely fine with me; I already appreciate all the effort you're putting in to help me. Thanks very much. I've attached a .zip file with the per robot settings file as well as the propellerbot_node.py and SerialDataGateway.py.

For the robot settings, simply all I did was edit the ping sensor configuration. I am using the Arlo Complete Robot Kit provided by parallax, with the 4 ping sensors connected directly to the P14, P15, P16, and P17 headers. I also changed the ROS timeout and increased it to see if that would have made any difference.
Hi.
What strikes me about your configuration is that your front ping sensors are not contiguous.
#define FIRST_FRONT_PING_SENSOR_NUMBER 14
#define HOW_MANY_FRONT_PING_SENSORS 3
#define FIRST_REAR_PING_SENSOR_NUMBER 15
While I don't understand how this could cause serial communication problems, I believe it will cause other problems. I would recommend changing the rear ping to P17.
Also, I assume you have the jumpers next to the servo headers on the center pin and the 5V pin and not on the center pin and the VIN pin?

#define ROS_TIMEOUT 1000   Probably not an issue, but maybe try setting this to something < 127 in case it is somehow being passed through a byte and being truncated? Don't have time to study the code to see if this could be a problem.
One other difference I just noticed. Your file has the following:
// Quickstart Board Settings
// I have a SECOND Propeller chip on a Quickstart board that polls the PING and IR sensors, so this is settings for that.
// Which pin on the QuickStart Board is the RX pin connected out to the Activity board?
#define ACTIVITYBOARD_RX_PIN 5
// Which pin on the QuickStart Board is the TX pin connected in from the Activity board?
#define ACTIVITYBOARD_TX_PIN 6
My file does not have this. This is related to serial communications and merits further investigation but I do not have time right now.
I have to get ready to go to work  now, but will look again this evening.
above should not be an issue.
Forgot to mention that the propellerbot_node.py and SerialDataGateway.py you uploaded are identical to what I am using.
I'm at a loss. Spent some more time looking at your configuration versus mine and did not find anything other than what I have already noted above.
A few more miscellaneous questions:
Hey Vatbrain,
I've tried many different laptops.
I tried running off a Dell XPS 13, Aorus X3, Razer Blade 14, and a few other low-powered laptops. And yes, find_ActivityBoard.sh and check_hardware.sh both run properly.
Sadly, I've given up on this package for it since I cannot afford to waste more time. I've been using an Arduino Mega and the rosserial library in order to publish my data.
I appreciate all the effort you put into trying to help me; hopefully this can get resolved in the future for others that want to use this ArloBot package.
Best regards,
Matthew
This was a great discussion. I apologize that I was not able to get involved at the time.
I'm going to close this as it is old now. If you feel I can still contribute to a solution for you please reopen this issue or open another one.
Thank you!

issue_title: Issue using start-robot.sh and starting the web interface
issue_contents: When I run start-robot.sh, I get several errors printed to the screen. First the arlobot_goto.py script gets the error 'ImportError: No module named hector_nav_msgs.srv'. Then after initializing the nodelets, I get messages saying that 'No matching device found.... waiting for devices' and 'Invalid device number 1, there are 0 devices connected.' In addition to this the script causes the wheels on the arlobot to rotate, and they don't stop rotating upon killing the script, I have to manually restart the power to the motors.

When starting the web interface with the desktop shortcut, the webpage appears with the repository url as well as stating that no robot is found. When running the start-robot.sh, this screen changes to the actual GUI but after several seconds reverts back to the no robot is found message.

I have already compiled the firmware with SimpleIDE, and have performed the direct2PropSerial.sh script, with both being successful. I'm using the ArloBot kit, and all of the basic ArloBot-provided tests have worked successfully as well. I'm running all of this on the UbiquityRobotics image whch is Ubuntu 16.04 with ROS Kinetic on Rasberri Pi. This is my first time working with the ArloBot, and I'm relatively new with ROS, so I'm not sure if there is something obvious I'm doing wrong. I've attached the messages printing while running robot-startup.sh if that helps at all.

So I was able to resolve the hector_nav_msgs.srv error. I was missing package that I had to find and install. However, the rest of my issues are the same. In addition to this, I'm receiving two warning messages: "Unable to start server: [Errno 98] Address already in use." and "Joint state with name: "left wheel_joint" was received but not found in URDF." I'm doing everything the same as before, and I've attached the messages I was getting.
I apologize that I was not able to respond when you posted this.
Are you still using this code, and if so, is there still anything I can do to assist?
If not, I will close this issue.
I'm sorry that I didn't have an answer for you at the time.
Closing due to inactivity and the amount of changes that have happened since this issue was opened.

issue_contents: Hello,

I have a problem bringing up arlobot. When I use the command: "roslaunch arlobot_bringup minimal.launch --screen", I get an error saying there is no module named "msg" : "File "/home/pixy/catkin_ws/src/ArloBot/src/arlobot/arlobot_safety/scripts/arlobot_safety.py", line 7, in
from arlobot_msgs.msg import arloSafety
ImportError: No module named msg".
I am using ubuntu 16.04 and have installed everything using your quick install script. My python version is 2.7.12. Arlo was bought as a complete package and was assembled using Parallax guide.
Hi. See issue
. Better to delete the offending package and get a complete build and clean catkin_make rather than white listing the arlobot_msgs package as mentioned in issue
Hello, that did work around the issue and I apologize for not seeing issue

. However I am still unable to get teleoperation working. When I launch teleop I can't get the robot to move. I can change speeds with "q/z/w/x/e/c/" but can't get the robot to move. I also tried using the "quick start" script, but had no luck. I even tried the option to ignore ping sensors, but it didn't work either. While running the script I kept getting this error: "Error connecting to RosLibJS server: [object Event]", is that normal?
Lastly, thank you for your quick response.
Hi, No need to apologize. Glad that helped.
Have you run the basic parallax arlo tutorials to make sure the motors and encoders are wired and work properly? If not, that is the first place to start.

Next, I would try getting the robot to move running the ROSInterfaceForArloBotWithDHB10.c propeller code and sending it commands using a terminal program as outlined in direct2PropSerialTestLines.txt  I had better luck using the terminal from the Arduino IDE than other methods. This is a key step. Let us know if you can move the robot this way. Good luck!

Hello, yes I ran everything you mentioned and it all works fine. The robot even moves back if I put my hand to close to one of the ping sensors. When I run the "quick start" script I don't get true/false for atributes for keys in "telemetry", but I guess thats because I disabled those modules like it is suggested in isssue
. Also I don't get anything in "relays". Thank you for your help.
I'm not sure whether I have ever run the quick start script. I have never been able to get the robot to move using the arlobot desktop icon and web interface.   What has worked for me is:

The last thing I did to get that to work was to add some DEFAULT_MOTOR_ADC_VOLTAGE code to per_robot_settings_for_propeller_c_code.h and ROSInterfaceForArloBotWithDHB10.c to cause a non-zero voltage to be sent to propellerbot_node.py, but these changes have been merged for some time.
I have tried:
roslaunch arlobot_bringup minimal.launch --screen
roslaunch arlobot_teleop keyboard_teleop.launch
again and just realized something I should have said already, when I start: "roslaunch arlobot_teleop keyboard_teleop.launch" in a new terminal I get an error in the 1st one:
File "/home/pixy/catkin_ws/src/ArloBot/src/arlobot/arlobot_bringup/scripts/SerialDataGateway.py", line 65, in Write
self._Serial.write(data)
File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/serial/serialposix.py", line 517, in write
raise portNotOpenError
SerialException: Attempting to use a port that is not open.
EDIT:
I seem to have a simillar issue to what geistmate had in issue
, where all of the commands are registering when I run "rostopic echo /cmd_vel", but I guess they are not being transfered via serial port.
EDIT2:
Could it be that another process is using that port, when I run "ls -l /proc/[0-9]
|grep /dev/ttyUSB0" to see which processes are using USB0 port I get the following:
ls: cannot access '/proc/10378/fd/255': No such file or directory
ls: cannot access '/proc/10378/fd/3': No such file or directory
Note that while I was running this I didn't have roslaunch running. I don't know why it would list those 2 processes because when I try killing them it says they don't exist.

There is also 1 other thing I wanted to mention: When I run direct2PropSerialTest I says I should be getting a steady stream of " i 0", but I seem to be getting just one "i 0" combination. At first it looked like the next line was just overwriting the first one, but I am not so sure now. Also when I copy the suggested line for DHB-10 I am getting the expected odometry output, but the safety line seems to exist for only half a second or so and then it gets overwritten. Despite it, when I run the commands for the robot to move forwards/backwards/turn it still does so normally. I am plugging my activity board directly to a usb 2.0 port on my desktop pc.

I have looked at some other issues and the google group and I found out I wasn't the only one having an issue with serial communication. Can you please test teleop on your own setup and if it works can you please tell me what configuration are you using (pc, laptop, Raspberry, etc.. and what os)? I have been looking through the scripts for serial communication and it looks like "SerialDataGateway.py" is trying to read from the activity board, before it is reset, but that doesn't stop the script and it continues forward. I assume it is supposed to constantly print out messages:
[INFO] [1536078851.143213]: Watchdog Timeout Reset initiated
[INFO] [1536078851.143887]: Serial Data Gateway stopping . . .
[INFO] [1536078851.144469]: Stopping serial gateway
[INFO] [1536078851.245311]: Serial Data Gateway stopped.
[INFO] [1536078851.245865]: 5 second pause to let Activity Board settle after serial port reset . . .
In the same way "propellerbot_node.py" is trying to write data via serial when the activity board is not ready, but the script still moves on.
Just now I finally found out what is wrong:

The error is in "propellerbot_node.py" in "handle_velocity_command" function. I believe that "self._clear_to_go("to_stop"):" always happens. It seems like the robot always "thinks" that it's not safe to move. It might be due to the same issues I had at the beggining with "no module named msg", especially "ArlobotSafety". You can work around it by copying the code from "self._clear_to_go("forGeneralUse")" to "self._clear_to_go("to_stop"):", but be WARNED that the robot won't stop if its near an obstacle and will crash into it unless you stop it.

Also my problem with serial connection still persists and it is limiting my teleop. I have to be very gentle with it as it can easily get stuck in a loop and I can't get it to stop with teleop anymore.

Hi. My teleop works. I was driving the robot all weekend and just now. I am using a lenovo thinkpad laptop running lubuntu 16.04.1 I am connected to a USB 3 port.  Originally, I was getting tripped up at the top of the clear_to_go routine. I put in a bunch of rospy.loginfo statements and eventually figured out that it was the _leftMotorPower and _rightMotorPower that was preventing my robot from moving. You should be able to do the same and figure out exactly what is causing a problem in this routine. I would start with the conditions at the top.

Hello, thank you for your help. I took a look and it seems motorsOn and left/rightMotorPower are false all the time. Also, the serial connection seems to work for 20 seconds, then resets for 5s and keeps doing it all the time. It looks like it is supposed to be like that, but just wanted to confirm. If it is intentional, do you know why is it like that. Does ROS send too much commands to the activity board so it overflows its buffer, or is there another reason? You can contact me at
if you don't want to prolong this thread.
Hi. The robot will not drive if left/rightMotorPower are false. Chris accepted a pull request of mine that was supposed to fix this under certain configurations.
I just found a link related to some potential serial port issues under linux that I had used before:

Check out what it says about Permission Issues and ModemManager. I took the actions outlined there and have not been having the serial port issues others have been having recently. That may or may not the the reason. Worth a try though.
Hi MStojkovic. I just wanted to know if you were able to solve the serial timeout issue?
Hello geistmate,
sadly no. I have tried everything I know butt the connection still breaks after a couple of secconds and just repeats the final command.
I apologize that I was not able to respond when you posted this.
Are you still using this code, and if so, is there still anything I can do to assist?
If not, I will close this issue.
I'm sorry that I didn't have an answer for you at the time.
Closing due to inactivity and the amount of changes that have happened since this issue was opened.

roslaunch arlobot_bringup minimal.launch --screen
<New Terminal>
roslaunch arlobot_teleop keyboard_teleop.launch

issue_contents: Hi,

I was testing with ~/catkin_ws/src/ArloBot/scripts/PropellerSerialTest.sh, and I noticed that when I moved the robot forward with keyboard, the heading number increased from 0 to 2.0 very quickly, then it overflew and jumped back to 0. I would expect the heading to maintain around 0, since the robot moved forward, without any turning. Also, is the unit here in radians? if so, shouldn't it overflow when it reaches pi*2? I also saw "Received ERROR: GOSPD: previous ... new ..." every time when I pressed the keyboard, is that normal?
In Rviz, when I drove the robot forward, the robot actually turned, and suddenly jumped to a new location when overflow happened.
I confirmed that my encoders were working properly with:
. Any ideas?
Thanks!
OK, I found the bug. In broadcastOdometryAndRunMotors.h, change uint8_t dhb10_ticksLeft, dhb10_ticksRight... to int64_t ..., since the encoder value can be +/- and way beyond 255
Yay, bug fixes!!
I'll try to update the code this weekend with your fix, or you can send me a pull request if you want credit on github. :)
(Currently a ROS topic)

issue_title: Gripper joint state publisher is reversed
issue_contents: For some reason, when running the Blue stack on an actual arm, closing the gripper manually leads to the joint_state_publisher reflecting that it is open.
Opening the gripper manually also results in the joint_state_publisher reflecting that it is closing.
I suspect that there is a missing sign change somewhere, but I'm not sure which file to edit. I'm running the stack at
This issue has been resolved in
Pending merge.
let's make this more readable!

Hi, everyone,  great work. I wonder if your compliance control algrithom code is open source, because I can't find them on github, but the lead through and compliance effect if impressive on berkeleyopenarms.github.io.
Hi!
You can find the lead-through code we used for the video
. There's no specialized control algorithm for it: during the "record" stage, we just disable all our controllers and send feedforward gravity compensation torques.
Hi!
You can find the lead-through code we used for the video
. There's no specialized control algorithm for it: during the "record" stage, we just disable all our controllers and send feedforward gravity compensation torques.
Thanks for your replay. I also noticed that the arm's compliance respond to human disturbance. Which controller are you using to accomplish that? The soft position controller
Yep, that's the controller we were running in the video. :)
Yep, that's the controller we were running in the video. :)

I mean, this seems to be a regular computed torque controller with position feedback, right? Why are the joints so soft to the disturbance, just because of the low gain? Did you try anything like impedance control or some other force control method?
Yeah, it's pretty much just the transparent transmissions + lower controller gains.

The position controller you linked above implements joint-space impedance control, but there's a separate computed torque controller in the same directory (which linearizes the control space using our robot dynamics model). Both are pretty standard/simple.
Thanks!
issue_quotes: You can find the lead-through code we used for the video
. There's no specialized control algorithm for it: during the "record" stage, we just disable all our controllers and send feedforward gravity compensation torques.
Yep, that's the controller we were running in the video. :)

issue_contents: Hi,
Today I try to run your free_gait and found this repo is not open for normal user and only for developers like you.
I guess the
should be a repo like msg files. But we can't use it for you did't publish it as a dependency。
And what shocked me is that there has been many issues asked this problem and there was no official response for more than a year.
Maybe we should end this.
In fact, an answer won't take you many time. Hope we grow more open.
I followed the ros wiki and set
to a 3D point cloud that I'm assembling from a lidar sensor. However, as can be seen in the screenshots below, footstep planner puts the feet inside the obstacles.
What could be the reason of it?
I'm pretty sure thats because your point cloud ist not dense (there are huge gaps between the voxels). Either collect more data or reduce the terrain model voxel resolution.

If the terrain model does not provide any 3D data of a region, the planner assumes incomplete world model representation and copies the alignment from previous footstep. That has been implemented this way as we would like to ensure to get any planning results in case of occlusions.
Either use grid map collision check additionally or use the return variable of the terrain model in the state generator. For latter just change the line
to check the returned boolean value (true -> success).
Since we are going to develop a separate
, which was before incorporated in the
, so we need to decide its organisation. For now, I have made a basic layout of the layer which can be used as a starting point to work on.
Shouldn't
and
just be libraries? In that case, all of that would come under
directory, right?
Yeah...Right, all will be under
. Then the layout will be..
How is each task being dealt with in this case?
will be responsible for getting all the features from an object like its coordinates, contours, etc. It will contain the target specific code to get the info about the targets like
, etc. The main code will be written inside
which will sequentially send the information to the
using the
lib.
Hm so how about we have a separate package named

which will have all the common libraries that we create and then separate packages for each task? Also, I was thinking of using service-client nodes for tasks instead of normal subscribers-publishers.

Instead of making separate packages, why can't we make special classes for the tasks and include those classes in the main vision code. So, there will be no separate packages for doing the tasks but one main vision code where we can create objects for handling all the detection related work and executing them sequentially according to the motion plan.

Also by making separate packages we will repeat the same thing again. One of the things that I felt wrong with the previous code was a lot of repetition. Even for different tasks containing 300 lines of code there is literally very few lines of difference. By doing the first way we can use the inheritance property of C++ and develop a base obstacle_detector class and derive the other classes from it.
Anyway, I will make a foolproof plan of the whole thing that I have in mind, with all the pros and cons and get back to you
In my opinion, this should be the package structure
This is essentially what
said.
I don't see the point of making an entirely new package only for the libraries, since we are writing those files in
and this library won't be used anywhere else except
. I agree with

that we can use a client-service system instead of subscriber-publisher because we will need only one type of data (buoy, gate, marker dropper...) at a time and not all types of data at all times. What type of data is needed at a particular moment will be decided by
The only reason why I suggest to have different packages is to avoid having too many nodes inside one package itself.  But it's fine. It doesn't really matter where you put it.
The service messages would be added to the
package since it is a recommended way to organize a ROS repository.
Hmm... We will not need too many nodes or packages. According to the plan there will separate classes ,for each mission element, to handle all the operations to get the necessary information, under
Dir. We can apply
functionality in the classes too, i guess, by initialising a
inside the classes. So, we will not need distinct nodes for each task, but just separate objects to handle each task, which will be included in a single vision code.
just wanted to know that is this organisation of vision layer being followed for our new vehicle........?????
I wanted to have separate branches for the repo to have a different purpose. So, for now we will have a
branch which will have the code specially pointed for NIOT. We can do this for all the competitions and we will develop the
such that it works irrespective of any competition and only properly tested code to work in all conditions with a proper structure.
We can close this issue I believe.

issue_contents: The level_mode_controller uses a Thruster::mode(1) function whose return values are used in Thruster::calibartion(2) only. Since the return values of mode(1) are used nowhere else, we can remove it completely if it won't be used in the future. The attached diff file shows the suggested changes for cleaner code.
I'll take a look at it. It is better if you
to share files since they can be viewed easily compared to txt files.
Please close this issue. This is redundant since the entire
is gone.
Since we now have an underwater light also, so we need to include its code also in our present arduino code to run it.
we need to just get the pin numbers from the electrical subsystem and then declare them in
and use
to turn the light on depending upon the intensity.
what is the status on this issue ???? This is a fairly straight forward issue so it need not take much time ...... if its completed, then close it
Forgot to test the code in the ongoing testing. Will test asap.
I think we should close this issue since it has been resolved from the software side ...
It is very annoying to do thruster testing by writing each and every command on the terminal to test it. We can do it easily by dynamic reconfiguration.
the GUI has already been developed ...call saini ..... !!!!! also you can use the rqt monitor to change the values on topics....
For rqt monitor use rqt_publisher ...... all topics will appear one by one and u can change the values being published by just one click !!

But that is in the development stage, we don't know how stable that is and creating a gui using dynamic reconfigure is very easy. We will also not require any other dependency, plus it is. For using rqt, we will need to install Qt.
I am confused what exactly is wanted from the thruster testing GUI? By testing, you mean just to put PWM and see if the thruster works or not? In that case
had made a GUI for this. It is available

Dynamic reconfiguration can be done but again it is used for parameters to your node instead of data to which your node subscribes to. Now, PWM would be topic messages while PID parameters are best suited for dynamic reconfiguration. So using dynamic reconfiguration is not suitable if you just want to pass PWM values to node.
What would be better to have a joystick controller for our vehicle through which we can give motion commands like (surge/sway/heave/roll/pitch/yaw) instead of each thruster individual PWM.
Also for checking if the thruster is connected or not, we can use the status pins in motor drivers to check whether everything is fine at hardware level or not. While this was missing in
, I believe Nilay and Saksham are doing that in the new actuation board for the vehicle.
I think GUI which
has made is a keyboard controller, as I can infer from
, to control the motion. So, it doesn't control individual thrusters. We need to dynamically set the
sent to thrusters too, for our testing purposes which we are unware of. The issue topic is misleading, sorry for that. Changing it right know.
As pointed out by
there is already a
package
can be used for dynamically publishing values on a topic. So, closing this issue.
there is another
package of
to monitor that ..... just see that
PR

fails Travis CI check and yet is merged which destroys the purpose of using CI in the first place. We need to either fix the code or fix the CI (if that's the issue) but in the end we need to have that green tick so that future PRs aren't incorrectly judged.
CI is the issue. We will try to fix it when we get time. Actually now we don't have that many contributors to the software stack, so we are ignoring it. You can try if you have time.

issue_contents: The
uses two custom-made messages included from the package
. There are problems including the header files generated due to
can you look into this, as I don't have much experience with
As far as I remember, I did add those statements.
According to the

, to add custom messages for Arduino you need to add them first to the ROS library which arduino refers to and build them there.  Only then the arduino node can use them. However, this reduces the portability of the code.

However, for linking through CMake it is another story. I'll have to check again but it wasn't working as well at the time I wrote the code. The easiest solution that I can think of to use standard messages in arduino cpp node and then have another node which converts them into our custom messages.
I shall also add that when using sensor messages, it is advised to have
so that's why I believe using those custom messages are a good practice. I'll keep you updated if I find a better solution to this issue.

issue_title: Fix issue of rosserial_arduino losing sync with device
issue_contents: We have changed to a single message for Thrusters, but we have not tested it yet. We need to find a way to launch the node again if it loses sync.
Currently, we manually launch the code again when it fails, and the thrusters lose on control till then.
I was thinking of implementing something like a Bash script which is capable of this because even if we find something that lowers this occurrence, I dont want to risk it.
I think a script like this would work. Would add it in the
directory. And this can be combined with the bash script that launches the entire
We easily relaunch it by setting the attribute
true in the roslaunch file used to launch the
I read that. But

will only relaunch the node if the node stops entirely. Which actually is not happening in our case. The node is running but it gives an error, which does not allow us to control the thrusters anymore.
close this? As we have already found a solution for this.
Solved. Closing this.
issue_code:
#!/bin/bash
while : 
do
        if rosrun  rosserial_arduino serial_node | grep -m 5 'Losing sync with device'; then
                echo "Error occured, relaunching again"
        fi
done

issue_title: Using base classes to reduce the redundancy
issue_contents: In the packages like

, there are a bunch of classes designed to do specific tasks, but the design of every class is more or less like others. So, more often than not we just copy paste code when creating a new class which feels stupid sometimes as to why bothering to write so much code for a class which is very little different from other. I propose to create a single base class which has the basic requirements needed by all the other tasks and the specific tasks are derived from it. This way will give the code base better structure and scalability.
Yes, I agree with that. Too much of redundancy.
Completed with
's PR

issue_title: md5sum mismatch on kinetic, between laptop and RPi3
issue_contents: I'm trying to setup Nimbro, but am getting errors with mismatching md5sum. The setup is as follows:
When I try to (by hand or code) publish to a topic, e.g. /odom, from the Raspberry Pi 3 I get an error message that the md5sum does not match. For nav_msgs/Odometry:
Similar for sensor_msgs/Image (I relaunched and published a different type of message):
I've checked the md5sum on both with
and
, they are identical. If I export ROS_MASTER_URI and skip nimbro it works.
If I publish to /am02/cmd_vel from the laptop, I receive the message on the RPi3 without any issue. If I try the other way, it does not work.

Adding some information: Through logging I've tried to figure out where the problem occurs, and it seems to be in topic_info::packMD5 or topic_info::unpackMD5. If I add the following to tcp_sender.cpp, directly after line 336:
I can see that it works on my PC, giving the same input as output. On the Raspberry Pi 3 it gives different MD5 sums. Example output on computer:
On Raspberry Pi 3:
Hi, this could be an overflow in the long int type, which is 32 bits on the raspberry pi and 64 bits on a 64 bits machine.
Could you try replacing
with
in

Thank you, I tried it on the Raspberry Pi 3 separately, and laptop separately, and it seems to solve the problem. I'll try it between PC and raspberry pi during the day, to see that it also works across the network.
: Tried it between my laptop and two Raspberry Pi 3, now I'm not experiencing that issue. Does it make sense to merge the change into master, or could it cause issues?

issue_title: Hydro changelogs contain changes from indigo which is breaking the debian building
issue_contents: The changelog on they hydro branches include changelogs for indigo releases. (0.6 series)

When debian builds it's debs it uses the latest changelog as the version of the pakcage. All the new releases of hydro are building invalid versions which is causing infinite looping on the buildfarm.
The hydro branch needs to have the changelog stripped to reflect only the hydro changes and rereleased otherwise the buildfarm will continuously loop.
