The transition of servos is jerky if used in combination with the joint trajectory following controller.
Since the joint trajectory following controller is configured to use the position interface of the robot, no PID gain values can be specified.
Changing the rate of the pxpincher node did not improve it significantly.
But if used with the joint trajectory interface gui:

The movement is slowly. They send the message using the command interface instead of the action controller and update their values frequently. Therefore it could depend on the number of interpolated samples of the resulting trajectory.

Using the linear/cubic/quintic interpolation strategies provided by the joint_trajectory_controller, it is possible to improve the smoothness of the transition. But the movement is still somewhat jerky.
Maybe we should update the compliance slopes and margins of the arm
Commit
reduces the jerkyness noticeably.
The behavior is now sufficient for our applications. I close the issue for now.

PS: Just for the archive: there is still some jerky behavior, if the robot moves from the ground to its default position. This might be more related to the underlying controller configuration rather than the servos.

If the pxpincher_hardware node is started in simulation mode, all actions are performed using a simple integration model. The integration model is executed much faster than the rate of the actual hardware node (e.g. 3x). But there are still some discrepancies.
If the action server is used with a specified trajectory, the execution cancels after the desired trajectory duration is finished regardless of reaching the actual goal.
This can be also be identified using the testKinematicModel method of the pxpincher_lib (see pxpincher test node): the desired positions are not reached.
But if the simulator is modified in order to execute the trajectories with a much higher velocity than specified, the goals are reached perfectly (using testKinematicModel).

On the other hand, this might be not a valid solution, since the simulator would not mimic the actual transition. Obviously, it is not possible to mimic the actual real-time behavior, but maybe it is possible to improve the timing, since the simulator can be executed much faster.
The issue might be resolved by introducing a conversion factor that transforms the raw speed (used by the dynamixel servo) to the actual position difference in ticks).
The internal unit of servo speed is not [tiks/s], is this correct ?
The factor is obtained by:
Unit(P) = [ticks]
Unit(conversionPos) = [rad/ticks]
Unit(v) = [rad/s/]
P_k+1 = P_k + v [rad/s] * dt / conversionPos
P_k+1 = P_k + V [ticks] * conversionSpeed/conversionPos * dt.
The factor is approx. 2.2 ...
After this change (commit
the testKinematicModel method runs perfectly without issues.
However, If I check the response of the action server:
I still get error code -5 as response which indicates:
The issue does not need to be tracked anymore, since the simulator model operates in radians now rather than in ticks.

From the mir_robot which provides IP bridging, remapping and removing of topics,... stuff that makes possible a good connection between my computer and the robot.
Now I roslaunch this launcher I have created to execute gmapping, rviz and setting use_sim_time = false:
And finally the last thing I do is:
The problem comes when I try to publish the points in RViz, there won't appear any of them RViz so they won't be published and your algorithm won't run. What am I doing wrong?
Hi chbloca,
I would first check the topic names on which Rviz publishes clicked points, which you use to define the area. The global and local detectors expect the points to be published on
. This topic is by default the topic name Rviz publishes any clicked point. Most likely this is not your problem.
The second thing you need to check, whether you visualize
on Rviz. The detectors publish
messages on
and
I have added a
in the
package, for launching a robot without name prefix. It uses a
to visualize everything correctly. You may need to make changes according to your topic names.
For example, the laser scan topic name of yours is different. You may optionally change it to
, Or modify the Rviz config file, line
. (but this is not necessary, only if you wish to visualize the laser scans)
If the problem still persists, can you show me all the topic names when you run your system?
I just added this line in the launcher I posted:
Now with the RViz running your custom configuration it works! Just the rrt algorithm, but the robot won't move.
Here are the list of topics:

Thanks for your quick answer, Hasauino.
PD: I don't want Gazebo to open, I don't need it.
Can you also show me your tf tree, all the frames? and also your
Why is the global costmap not showing? in your first picture, Rviz is showing an error or a warning for the global cost map (marked in orange)?
When you publish Nav goal, what topic do you use?
why do you have two actions for the move base,
action and
I will try to answer your questions and provide your the rosservice list tomorrow when I have access again to the robot.
Meanwhile, here I provide you the tf tree and the frames.

relative_move_action is a feature built-in the robot which provides the posibility of moving it with a virtual joystick as if it was a "rosrun teleop_twist_keyboard teleop_twist_keyboard.py" but smoother.

It looks like both the
and the
nodes are not running. I first will list what both of these nodes depend on. Then I will try to expect what your setup is missing.

it depends on:
service.
In your
it was not there. I also don't see other navigation stack services. They are not required though.

Ok, problem solved. The problems were that I didn't include the move_base node in the launcher and that the resolution of the gmapping was too high (delta parameter) so it had a tremendous impact laptop which caused lags and TF OLD DATA. issue_contents: When using the particle tracker with kinect v2, the object starts moving towards the camera until it reaches the camera origin. Has anyone got it to work with kinect2?
Turns out that there have been two issues with Kinect2.
This had to be fixed in dbot and dbot_ros. Should be fixed now for 16.04. Couldn't test for 14.04 though. Would be great if someone who still runs 14.04 + KInect2 could test these fixes.
Thanks for the fix

issue_title: is this suitable for any object that is in dynamic state?
issue_contents: hell all, hope you are doing well.

I'm interested to use this package for tracking objects with depth image.  I have a depth sensor. I want to throw a cube or any solid object and track that using the depth image in ROS. is it possible to use this library for that kind of application?
Waiting for kind reply.
Cheers
Prasanna

In principle this is possible. The bottleneck is the sampling rate of the camera sensor which is only 30Hz. The faster an object moves (for example when it is thrown), the larger the change from frame to frame and therefore the more difficult to hit the right pose with a sample.
For now, the hyperparameters of the filter are tuned to work well for manipulation. For these dynamic movements, you may need to tune the process model accordingly.

issue_title: Some questions on tracking the specificed object?
issue_contents: Hello!

Firstly, I appreciate that you share your excellent work here. These day, I tried to use those pacakges in ROS to do something objects-tracking.Here I have some questions on tracking the specificed object?

1.  When tracking the specified object, it seems that we need to set the original pose of the object.In practice, does it mean that we need to send the real pose of the object to the service to realize the tracking?
2.   In practice, can I leavage this work to track multi-object?And how?
Looking for your response.Thx!
Hi! Thanks for your interest in our work :)
May I point to the

, which explains how to run in practice an object tracking example. This is the basic usage of the tracker. As you'll see, the initial pose is given through an interactive marker. The initial pose doesn't need to be perfect, but close enough. You can try it yourself to get a sense of how close.
It is also possible to programatically send an initial pose to an object tracking
, but that's more advance usage. (I'm not sure if your question was actually along those lines).
The same basic example should work with multiple objects by specifying multiple objects in the list of the yaml file.
May I suggest that from now on you open different threads for different questions. If you run into problems, please always explain the behavior you obtain when running the getting-started example.
Thanks!
Thanks!

issue_title: Did you try to send more than one object's information to an object tracking service to realize multi-objects tracking?
issue_contents: Thanks you for responding on my previous problem. For now, what I want to do are:

The service_call script(~.py file) you provided seems can only track one object. If I want to proceed the second work described above, it seems I need to change the code to let the service get more message.I am going to do this. But I want to know did you do something like that before?Or do you have some good idea to share with me?
I am sorry maybe some sentence above are not smoothly. Hoping you can understand what I mean.
Looking for your response.Thanks!
You are right: the service we provide takes only one object as input. We never used it for more than one object. However, the tracker itself can handle several objects.
As you suggest, you could write and extended version of the
that can handle several objects.
Don't forget to add the corresponding definitions of messages and services in the
repo.
PS. I'm sorry I can't be of more help. I was not the author of this code, so I don't know it in much detail. Please take these hints with a grain of salt.
Well, thanks for your useful advise.I will try something in the following days.
Thanks again. Best!

There has been multiple implementations to simulate a dVRK arm, some completely parallel to the cisst-SAW implementation.  In the recent past, I added a simple geometric simulation mode within the cisst-SAW classes.  I just updated the dvrk_robot README.md to show how to create a simulated arm:
I also updated the main dvrk_ros README.md to document the content of each directory.

) to build the cisst workspace. After I cloned the master branch of dvrk-ros and tryed the following command:

Ps I am using ROS indigo on Ubuntu 14.04.

This issue is related to the ecm.xacro file missing in the dvrk-ros/dvrk_model/model/ecm.xacro folder. There has been a lot of changes at this repos and some resulted in broken launch files. This needs to fixed.

As far as your issue is concerned, there are a few ways to get around this problem. The easiest is to open a text editor and change your launch file, change the instances that read "ecm.xacro" to "ECM.urdf.xacro". See if this solves your problem.
For kinematics simulation, please follow the doc here

Could you help me look into this problem? I believe this is a problem of converting the command message into the low level PID control target. We are sending the effort message with length of 6, but we have 7 DoF on the PSM. Thank you so much for your help in advance.
Best regards,
Zerui

Argh, we recently decided to maintain two sets of data members for joint level data in the arm class.  One for the PID that matched the total level of joints controlled including kinematic chain and jaws.  The other set is for the user API so the number of joints is based on the kinematic chain.  Internally the class should agglomerate the 6 for kinematics + jaw effort to send to the PID.
So what should I do in order to use the set_effort_joint command? Or it's supposed to be no problem?

I managed to solve the problem. Currently, there is a bug in the master branch, so if you want to install dvrk and cisst-saw, you need to clone from the devel branch.
git clone -b devel
--recursive (cisst-saw files)
git clone -b devel
(dvrk files)

issue_title: dvrk_python commands block and do not move the robot
issue_contents: I think after a recent update, (I am guessing the update for broadcast of current state of robot) the python interface is not working as expected. The dmove commands block and fail to move the robot.

I am suspecting that this issue might have to do with us using multiple machines on the local network (one connected to dvrk and another where we are using python api) and not updating the host in /etc/hosts file. I shall keep an eye on it to see if it pops up again if we set up the hosts correctly
This is not strictly ROS related.   For a distributed ROS master to work on Linux I found that if you can ping your host without the complete domain (e.g.
vs
) then ROS works fine.   You can create an entry in your

for each computer you might use but this is not always the best solution (specially if your computers are using DHCP).   You can instead set a domain search path in your network configuration.  On Ubuntu, edit your network configuration, then pick IPv4 Settings and enter "jhu.edu" in "Additional search domains".

Ahh that's a much better way of handling the dynamic allocation of host ips by the DHCP. Luckily all my workstations are connected via ethernet and the lease doesn't expire for a long time but that's not the case with the wifi machines. I shall try to adopt these changes
xacro.py is deprecated.

This is the issue tracker for the
package. Unfortunately, we cannot provide support
for high-level tasks like this.
Please refer to
or
for questions regarding image manipulation.
You can control the pxpincher either using
(check the available topics and services) or by using our self-made
(either velocity or position control). See

means, that this command waits until the action is finished (e.g. moving to a certain joint or task space pose. So if you want to define sequence of actions, blocking ensures that they are called one by one.
Accordingly, a non-blocking call detaches the action thread.

means, that the pose you specify is not absolute, but it is an increment w.r.t. the current pose (e.g. task space pose). E.g. x_new =  x_current + x_inc (where x_inc is the pose you pass to the function in relative mode)
Thanks, really helpful.

issue_title: teleop_v1 doesn't work with new ros_canopen controllers on indigo
issue_contents: We can't use teleop on our cob3-8 with the logitech joypad at the moment. Should we try using teleop_v2?
This is a namespace problem. please use _v1 and add a remap to the new namespace in the teleop launch file in cob_bringup.
But I think the "/component_controller/command_vel" topic of type "brics_actuator::JointVelocities" that is published by teleop_v1 doesn't exist in the new controller design or am I wrong?
I thought you were talking about the base.
You're right, there is no more joystick control for the arms. In case you'd like to use something for fast teach-in I can recommend rqt with the joint_trajectory_controller plugin.
Well, the publishers for brics_actuator message (command_vel) are still in the code.
Thus, I guess it is a namespace problem for components other than the base as well!
We introduced parameters that help us with handling this kind of things, maybe we just missed something in the cob3-8 yamls?
Are you referring to a component in particular?
What code version are you using? Hydro/Indigo? Releases or Source?
If you provide us with more details, we might be able to help.

As a side note, the joint_trajectory_controller plugin is only applicable for components using the JointTrajectoryController from ros_controllers...and I guess, cob3-8 does not use those but the cob_trajectory_controller instead

The rqt_plugin is working but it's not a good replacement for the joystick. What are the advantages of ros_canopen to the old ipa_canopen?
Another question: Have you tried the cob_twist_controller or cartesian_controller on a cob3?
P.S.: You have to edit the Indigo installation manual. The peak can driver installation isn't correct explained for the new socketcan interface.

Would it be possible to achieve the discovery using
and enable hosts on the go for the nimbro network?
Did anybody already tried that?
Do we need one node per host to synchronize?

nimbro_network is designed for static setups with explicit configuration. This provides robust operation in the challenging network conditions that we aim for. Relying on automatic discovery, which may fail, is not an option for us.
If your network is good enough for zeroconf/avahi discovery, then you can probably use multimaster_fkie directly and be happy.
I'll close this issue, since I don't see this as an appropriate feature. If someone comes along with a PR, I'll consider it, though.

issue_title: How to deal with "Could not bind socket: Address already in use" error & choose ports
issue_contents: Hi,
once again thanks for sharing this great tool!
I was wondering if there was a more systematic way to choose the TCP/UDP ports to be used in the launch files.

I saw that if the nimbro_network nodes are launched after the other ROS nodes are already running on the robot, sometimes it may happen that the TCP or UDP ports hard-coded in the launch files are already being used by some oder nodes, resulting then in the error:
and then the corresponding nimbro_network node that tried to use the occupied  port dies.
So far the best thing I could think of, is to: (a) launch regular launch file on the robot, (b) use the solution proposed
to scan available TCP or UDP ports in private range (49152-65535), (c) pick available ports for the nimbro nodes.

Of course this is not ideal and does not ensure that the launch files for nimbro will always have the selected ports as available. Therefore I was wondering if there's another way/method to deal with this problem.
Or maybe should I just use ports within the "registered ports" range (1024 to 49151)? I saw that the TCP Receiver/Sender example uses ports 17001 and 17002 and with these two I have never problems.
Regards,
Marco.
Thanks for the report :-)

As far as I know, dynamic port numbers (such as the ones used by ROS) are above 49152. As long as you use a port number below this for nimbro_network you should not have collisions between ROS nodes and the network stack.
Any dynamic solution will not work well since both sender and receiver need to know the port number.
ok, this makes sense. I tried to stay "close" to the example port number 17001, and had no issue at all.
Thanks a lot for the clarification ;)
Marco.

issue_title: Minor bug in youbot_oodl concerning visualization in rviz
issue_contents: There is a minor bug in the youbot_oodl which I came across recently.
In the file "youbot_oodl / src / YouBotOODLWrapper.cpp" lines 797 - 803 currently are:
Yet another hack to make the published values compatible with the URDF description.
We actually flipp the directions of the wheel on the right side such that the standard ROS controllers
(e.g. for PR2) can be used for the youBot
baseJointStateMessage.position[2] = -baseJointStateMessage.position[2];
baseJointStateMessage.position[4] = -baseJointStateMessage.position[4];
These indexes are wrong, they should be 0 and 2 instead of 2 and 4 so then the wheel turn correctly in rviz.
Can you just send us a pull request? We will then merge it into the repository.
Thank you very much.
Best Regards,
Frederik hegger
Pull request has been sent and merged. Thank you.

issue_contents: Any word on if Groovy has been looked at with the youBot or if consideration has been made to look into migrating to catkin?

Also, might it be better to break up all of the various stacks (metapackages) into separate repositories and adhere closer to the branching strategies in ROS (e.g., groovy-devel, hydro-devel...). This would also make it a lot easier to eventually add support to integrate into the ROS build system to create debian packages for the youBot.
Thoughts?
You can find some provisional catkinized versions for groovy on my account:

In the youbot-ros-pkg only the ROS wrapper (i.e. youbot_oodl package) is catkinized. There are still some things and tests missing. I used some workaround to get the dependencies on brics_actuator and pr2_msgs in catkin which are not so nice.
I think it could make much sense to break up the stacks as you suggest, we will look into that.
Great, thanks for the update

. We stumbled upon your catkinized version of youbot_driver yesterday and already merged it into our fork. Our group currently is working on getting youbot_driver into a stable state that can be built on the ROS build farm and distributed as packages for Ubuntu. The work you have done with catkin has helped a great deal.
One change we did make to the basic code was to read the folder location of the config files from a environment variable rather than a relative path (e.g.,
). We also added the
folder back into the build script. For next steps, we wanted to clean-up the package structure a bit possibly by creating more-standard
and
folders.

I noticed that some of the CMake files are configured to allow both a catkin and non-catkin build. Since catkin really is just a build system that can be installed independent of ROS, can we not just support the catkin conveniences? Just a thought.
Let us know if any of these suggestions are worth pulling in as we'd love to contribute back and get involved with the youBot community.

issue_contents: The
needs to be updated to use the
Python utility rather than the
folder which was removed as of PR

We need an easy to use command line tool for validating the thruster mapping and function prior to running the vehicle. The tool should be easy enough for any team member to run it and interpret its results.

Need a node which monitors all safety related data (battery info, kill switch status, is the computer crashing, etc) and provides logic for handling different safety scenarios. This will later be integrated with the state machine.

issue_title: Account for buoyancy in thruster controller
issue_contents: We should be accounting for buoyancy in the thruster controller. Not doing so gives all maneuvers in the z axis a constant offset

Thrusters have been recalibrate with the copro. The thrusters were firing in the wrong direction because the vehicle experiences a force in the opposite direction as the thrust - the exact sign convention used for the thrusters was initially unclear. This has now been addressed and taken care of in the thruster controller before it publishes the command/thrust message.

We need to publish more data about what is going on inside our controllers in order to know why they are failing. As of right now, the input command and output command are plottable, but the error signal is not.
So, need to add publishers for the error signal in each controller.
Status messages setup in all controllers
Processing the depth/switch messages one byte at a time is causing a huge bottleneck in that data stream. Need to process the data coming from the co-processor one
at a time using
. This should speed up the signal significantly and remove the delay.
Addressed in
. Needs tested with copro
Tested. Working AFAIK,

The teleop stack needs updated to be compatible with the latest code. It hasn't been tested in ages, but would be useful for collecting video at the pool without needing the control stack to be fully functional.
We should be able to drive the robot without going through the attitude or depth controllers.
Nah, the new PS3 controller uses the controllers, since they work.
Not a bad idea to keep a node around for "open-loop PS3 control", for when one of our sensors inevitably stops working or our mechanical design changes and the controllers need re-tuned

issue_title: Improve organization of the Riptide vision library
issue_contents: There are only a handful of functions in
right now, but many more will be added in the coming months. To accommodate this, the functions should be broken out into task-specific classes.
i.e. RiptideVision.GateDetector(); RiptideVision.DiceDetector() etc.
There's like 2 config files per controller, when really they could just be in one file. This would improve readability and make the package more cohesive.
Need a mechanism for dealing with dead thrusters on the fly.

issue_title: Make use of URDF for setting physical vehicle parameters
issue_contents: This will make simulation easier in the long run, and means we can change vehicle params in a single place, rather than having things like mass, moments of inertia, etc. defined in multiple places.

My system:

The frame_id for the raw IMU data originates in firmware, which is where that topic comes from, via rosserial. So a firmware update would be necessary to change it there unless you don't mind hacking the madgwick filter.

The reason this has never come up before is that 99% of tf_prefix usage is when simulating multiple robots under the same Gazebo instance and ROS Master. In that scenario, it doesn't matter because the madgwick filter isn't in the picture at all— the imu data is generated by a tf_prefix-aware Gazebo plugin.
Are you trying to run multiple physical Jackals on a single ROS master?

I see, that makes a lot more sense then. I'm planning on running multiple physical robots, but not necessarily all of them Jackals. Everything in Gazebo works fine with the proper namespaces being used, as you mentioned. We currently have one Jackal and one Ridgeback and will be running them under one ROS Master.

The Madgwick fix wasn't anything too in the weeds, so that may be sufficient. If you have any other recommendations, I'd be open to hearing them. Otherwise feel free to close the issue - I really appreciate the help!
Sounds great! Good luck with your project.

issue_contents: The present scheme of publishing UTM coordinates and having another publisher to publish the UTM zone letter and number will be problematic if the UTM coordinates published lie in different UTM zones.
The competition area lies within a UTM zone, so this will not be a problem during competition.

issue_title: Passwords shouldn't be stored in the ROS parameter server
issue_contents: We should not store the interop server's password in the parameter server, since that can be a potential security risk. We currently support loading it from an environment variable but that's still then loaded into the parameter server.
We could load the password from the environment variable directly in the code if the parameter server turns up empty (or the fallback could be reversed).
I think we should still support the parameter server, but mark it as not recommended in the docs.

issue_contents: Hi,

First, I apologize if this is not the right venue to discuss this, but Optris told me you were the maintainers for the Linux drivers.  My issue is not necessarily ROS-specific, but we have problem connecting our PI-640 camera on various recent laptops and Mini-ITX computers running Ubuntu 14.04 (64-bit).

As you suggest, we tried isolating the camera on its own bus and other uvc options, but we just cannot make it work. In some cases, the camera works correctly in Windows, but not Linux on the same laptop.

We did manage to locate two older laptops that seem to work with it in Ubuntu 14.04, but on our robots we would much prefer connecting the camera directly to their embedded computers instead of having to use a separate computer just for one sensor.
Thanks in advance for your help!

feel free to contact me directly. In order to help you, I need more

in a high frame rate? If not, this issue is related to the uvcvideo
module. If yes, I need more insight in your system (installed
calibration files, xml configration, file permissions, user permissions,

Yes, the problem is related to uvcvideo, i.e., guvcview cannot grab anything (high frame rate or not). On PCs that work correctly everything else is fine. The only thing we noticed about those working PCs is they tend to be slightly older, I would say roughly 3 years old. Dear Alison,

from your post, I just can see, that the process died and that there is a problem with UVC. These information are not enough to analyze the problem. Did you succeed in running the basic examples of the irDirectSDK (without ROS)? This is the first step in approaching the problem.
Best regards,
Stefan May
Hi stefanmay,
Thanks for your response, my colleague got it working, had to upgrade the GNU compiler version!
Thanks
Ali

issue_title: Detailed description of parameters and topics
issue_contents: Hi,
is there a detailed description of the parameters in the .launch file and in the .xml configuration?
For example I don't uderstand the difference of temperature min-max in the .xml and temperature min-max in the .launch.

Also how the raw data is saved on the thermal_image topic is not clear. The documentation says:"Temperature data is encoded as: float t = (float)(data - 1000) / 10.f.", but what is data? Is the temperature in the defined range scaled into 0-256?
I checked the topic and there are values between 0 and 256 (8 bit) alternated by 4. What is the 4 for?
Temperatures are represented as unsigned short value. That is why you
get these alternation of 4 and 2xx. If you read it correctly your
example value is: 1024 + 255 = 1279
Sorry, I'm not understanding this part. Where is the 1024 coming from? And what is the 4? A multiplier?

For example I have the calibration range -20°C / 100°C. How is the 100°C represented and how is the -20°C represented? Using 8 bits there are only 256 representation, so is the resolution around 120/256 (around half degree)?
I was expecting that a 0 represents -20°C and 255 represents 100°C, but it is not.
Thanks
Hi,
I'm also interested on how obtaining temperature value from the yuv422 format. Currently, I'm decoding the data using unsigned short value (16bits, BigEndian), then I apply the formula :
t = (getUint16 - 1000) / 10 then the values are very high, nearly 100x the correct values.
For example I have a getUInt16 value on the image center which is 35325 then the formula give me 3432.5 whereas the Optris PI connect software give me 28.60
When I try to display my temperature values using false color (i.e between [0;1]), then my image is nearly correct so I think I'm missing something.
Could you provide us some real example, or could you give us access to the code _iBuilder.convertTemperatureToPaletteImage or _iBuilder.yuv422torgb24 ?
Thanks
Ok, now I got it...I feel dumb :)
are you sure you're parsing correctly the data. Is your getUint16 correct?
Hi stefanmay,
Could you, please provide us the code to process directly the yuv422 ?
Do you have any sample data that could be used with your sdk and your examples ?
Thanks
Dear Stefan,
I try to use the SDK & samples from /usr/share/doc/libirimager/
but then I obtain the same temperature value maybe my input data is wrong. Here
is the link to my frame
Using this frame as input, the SDK getTemperatureAt(191,144) returns 6390.5 whereas the OptiPI Connect returns 28.60
Regards,
Fabien
I was able to get the temperature data from the raw /thermal_image.
But I have a few questions:
thanks
No I'm working with ROS,
is working with the SDK.
In ROS I changed the setting in both the .xml and the .launch to have the 150-900 range. And I was getting for a 400 degree item 124.
BUT now I tried to call the service set_temperature_range and that worked.
So aren't the parameters in the .xml enough?
Hi.

I work with Optris-450 in Raspbian. I capture the image in format ppm with DirectSDK. But I want calculate temperature from ppm file use data color in RGB because I need app that process only image. Then, How I can calculate temperature from ppm image obtened from Optris?

Thanks for fast answer. I tried it.

get these alternation of 4 and 2xx. If you read it correctly your

I tried to set the range 150-900 degrees, with the soldering station in the frame (>400 degrees) and I still get the 124 degrees. Aren't the ranges working?

issue_title: No thermal image received after the shutter flag events
issue_contents: This was noticed with xi80 camera on ROS, ubuntu and phytec am355x with yocto build on it. The image was seen as blue or red after the shutter flag event and remains same for several events and doesn't recover from it. It happens both auto and manual mode triggering of shutter flag. Please let us know if this is known issue or might happen due to some configuration/calibration issue. Btwn, we don't see this with windows PIX sw.
Hi,

We are really close to our release and found this critical issue with the camera. Our linux application uses two cameras and streaming from both. The issue is, we misses too many frames from either camera at random times with 4.1.1 SDK. I tried the 6.0.0. SDK whether it helps. But the issue still appears, with irimager_twin_show example, one of the camera frames are corrupted or empty.
Whenever the issue appears, here is the error am seeing from the example application.
ERROR [OpFlag.cpp:376] @ 35.6768s :ImagerError_FlagTooShort
ERROR [OpFlag.cpp:376] @ 140.915s :ImagerError_FlagTooShort
ERROR [OpFlag.cpp:376] @ 186.023s :ImagerError_FlagTooShort
It would be great, If you can suggest any flag setting etc., that would quickly help.
Please provide your input.
Hi, any suggestions to get rid of this error?

Your error description lacks of information. Please provide information about the platform you are using. Otherwise, It is difficult to help you. The error you posted normally states that the frame rate of the loop that is triggering the processing method, is too slow.
I am testing it with libirimager-x.x.x-amd64 version . This was observed on our product based on armhf too. The issue is reproducible with 4.1.1 as well 6.0.0 imager direct SDK.
·         Target System
o   processor architecture (X86-64)
o   operating system (Ubuntu 14.04)
·         Camera Model + Serial Number + Firmware version = Optris - 18104018 - 3008, Optris - 18094031 - 3008.
·         IR Imager Direct-SDK Version (4.1.1,6.0.0)

Please let me know if any more information is required.  To explain the issue again, we see corrupted or frame filled with high/low temp values at random intervals from one of the cameras. (Our setup uses two cameras). Thank you

The information I need is about the loop which calls the process method. If this loop is too slow, or e.g. if you do intensive calculations in the callback routines, the flag procedure cannot be handled. You need to post the code snipped, in which process is called as well as the callback routines.
Btw. Ubuntu 14.04. is not supported anymore (April 2019 was end of life).
Thank you for the quick response. sorry, it was ubuntu 16.04.  This issue i reproduced with the imager sdk example application. Please find it attached.
The shutter flag settings are auto, min and max interval as 15secs.

I tested the twin show application on an x86_64 platform and was able to reproduce your issue, but only if I attach both cameras to the same USB hub. You need to attach both cameras to different USB host chips. The IR imagers claim almost the full bandwidth of a USB 2.0 interface. Two cameras cannot be driven on the same USB 2.0 interface. I hope this resolves your issue. Please give me a feedback.

We recently bought the Optris Xi 400 and want to integrate it into ROS in a Linux OS. I followed the README and was able to catkin_make the package. However, when I run the optris_drivers.launch, it sends out a warning saying my camera_info_url does not contain calibration data. It's looking for that optris_imager.yaml file which I can't find. All I have are the calibration files in XML, DAT, and PRN files. Also, topics like the /optris/thermal_image_view is publishing image data, but the /optris/camera_info is publishing 0 for almost everything (e.g. height, width, offsets, etc.).

This calibration file is for your optics. It has nothing to do with thermal data conversion. You need to perform the calibration for your specific camera on your own, if you desire to do photogrammetric corrections. See here:

I see what you mean, but shouldn't the mfg provide this yaml file for the Optris Xi 400 thermal camera? I ask because the calibration tutorial you sent only works for RGB camera. The thermal camera will not be able to see the chess board. It seems like I'm still missing something here.

the vendor does not provide this calibration file. The community cannot do this for you, since this file is individual for each camera. So, it is up to you, to do this calibration. Most users do not need such a calibration. That is why Optris does not feel this is worth spending effort on, which would make the cameras more expensive. For thermal calibration you can find several publications. What you need is a calibration target, on which you can identify patterns in the thermal image.
Ah, I see. Looks like this yaml file is optional. It makes sense since it's throwing a warning not error. Thanks for the help,

issue_title: Duration is out of dual 32-bit range
issue_contents: When I connect my optris device (Optris PI) and run these drivers, I have the above issue.
I'm having the same issue with the Xi-400. It looks to me like the error is caused by
in
in OptrisImager.cpp.
returns
which isn't a very useful value for a maximum framerate :D This seems to be the case because in the constructor
the
method is called and returns the value
, i.e. the initialization failed. This isn't handled or by the OptrisImager class.
I'm not sure why this error suddenly occurs, as I didn't update libirimager or optris_drivers. I looked into the documentation of libirimager

but I didn't find any specific information about why the init method failed. One of the linked examples states the reason may be an error with the configuration or the cameras connection to the computer. However,
and
are created without any errors in optris_imager_node.cpp.

Exactly, I have the issue at the same place, I came back to this package after an year or so, now it is not working. I have more than one of those cameras, and I am facing this issue suddenly. It is strange to have zero at that parameter.
It would be nice, if the contributor to this package responds to our issue.

There are plenty of possibilities why the init method could fail. There might be an issue with the uvc interface. This you can check with standard tools, e.g. guvcview. If you receive a green image in the desired update rate, this is fine. Then there could be something wrong with the parameters, you pass. Also the calibration files could be broken or some of them might be missing. Did you activate the log mechanism? How you can do this, is described in the documentation. The init method will print a message before returning with a zero value. Please post this message in order to have a chance to find a solution.
Thank you for the response, I will try to update you about this on Monday.
I use the Troubleshooting section to add the debug line from here :
After adding the debug line, I have this as output:
I found that I am missing the xml file in the /usr/share folder, I have all other calibration files, but this is missing.
Thanks for the help!!.
I tested the download of your files with the following command:
ir_download_calibration -t /tmp -d 17040086
and find all files (also Cali-17040086.xml) in my /tmp directory.
Would you please attach the camera and execute:
$ sudo ir_download_calibration
and check whether this file is added.
Yes yes I have already executed it, and the camera is working now.
thank you for your help.
After enabling the debug output by calling
at the beginning of my program, it turned out that I had a problem with the file Formats.def.
My Formats.def file didn't have an entry for the Xi 400 series I was trying to use and my ROS node also wasn't able to read the file because of missing permissions.
I downloaded a new Formats.def file using the Windows software PIX Connect. In the menu bar click
. The new file was downloaded to
and after I copied the file to my Ubuntu machine and made sure the permissions were sufficient, everything worked again.
Thank you for the update on the issue. I will close the issue as both of us have solved our issues.
Thanks again!!

Did you try the "nodrop" option?
$ sudo rmmod uvcvideo
$ sudo modprobe uvcvideo nodrop=1
Then, try guvcview. Options can be made permanent, if this solves the problem (see documentation)

Thank you for your comment.
Regards

issue_title: rsmake (update_analysis_engines) fails without helpful information when a folder is missing
issue_contents: When there is for example no annotators folder (which should not be the case at all), rsmake fails without giving any valuable information. It should at least output that it could not find the/a folder that is necessary to complete.
fixed with PR

issue_title: error: ‘_mm_cvtph_ps’ was not declared in this scope
issue_contents: Hi
I am trying to setup robosherlock on my Ubuntu pc but when I try to compile using catkin_make or rsmake i get this error.
../src/robosherlock/src/io/src/UnrealVisionBridge.cpp:73:94: error: ‘_mm_cvtph_ps’ was not declared in this scope
make[2]: *** [robosherlock/src/io/CMakeFiles/rs_io.dir/src/UnrealVisionBridge.cpp.o] Error 1
make[1]: *** [robosherlock/src/io/CMakeFiles/rs_io.dir/all] Error 2
make: *** [all] Error 2
Invoking "make -j8 -l8" failed
Could someone help me
Hi,

could you be a bit more specific pls? As specially about your system. I did not have any problems on several machines running Ubuntu 14.04.  _mm_cvtph_ps comes with GCC so it is strange that it is not found in your case.  Coulld you check that the file is found in your include path.
Hi,
that are instructions to convert 16 bit floats to 32 bit floats. That is only supported on IvyBridge or newer.
Could you add a ifdef to check if it's supported or not and if it is not supported giving an error if the UnrealVisionBridge is used?
Yes indeed. Was reading through the docs for this and saw that it's 3rd gen intel and up. Managed to recreate this on my i3-2365. I'll add a check in code.
what is your CPU?
Hi
Thank you for the reply, Here are the details
System 1
Ubuntu 14.04.3
Intel® Core™ i7-3632QM CPU @ 2.20GHz
Graphics AMD Radeon HD 7600M Series
System 2
Ubuntu 14.04.5
Intel® Core™ i7-4810MQ CPU @ 2.80GHz × 8
Both the laptops have the same error.
i also have the same error while building.
error output:
CPU: Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-4200U CPU @ 1.60GHz
All of the CPUs that you guys listed are Ivy bridge and up, so FC16 should be supported by the CPUs. Try exporting the necessary compiler flags. For instance I have an i7-4770 and I have:
export CFLAGS="-march=core-avx2"
export CXXFLAGS="$CFLAGS"
Also try
and see if this works for you.
The latest changes to master should fix that problem, even if the flags do not work for you. Otherwise, please reopen this issue.

issue_title: Same Timestamp read twice when storing data from a Bagfile
issue_contents: When running the storage pipeline with a Bagfile I frequently get two images in a row which have the same timestamp. This leads to the cameraInfo being deleted in Line 399 of the Storage.cpp. Since the cameraInfo is only being written in the first run, I end up with a database without cameraInfo. I checked the timestamp in Line 383 in Storage.cpp and it does exist in my database, so it seems like the CollectionReader is reading the same image twice. A quick fix i did was to change Line 396 to the following:
That way the camera info never gets deleted and i end up with a working database, but this doesn't fix the issue.
Thx for the report. At first glance this looks like a bug in CollectionReader, that I am unable to reproduce so far on my machine.
@Surxz do you think you could give this a quick try?
tested this and it works for me.
thx, closing this isse and merging

issue_title: TFBroadcasterWrapper thread is initialized but it is never joined or detached in CollectionReader.cpp
issue_contents: As the topic title stated, the bug makes unit tests broken. The unit tests call and destroy the pipeline manager once for each test, which makes the thread object of TFBroadcasterWrapper goes out of scope:
Therefore, the unit test are broken.
thx for the notice. I'll fix this asap. I see you did it in
for the collection reader, but I think I am using TFBroadcaster in other places as well
That is good to hear :) Hope the bug does not occupy so many part of the code
you just fixed another occurence of this in
; could you pls check for other uses of TFBroadcaster in the source code and put those in the PR as well
sure :) I will make a ticket on trello for this debug
Fixed and Merged PR

, maybe it's the visualization windows that RS opens. Are you running this from a native Ubuntu? VM or VPS?

issue_title: tictactoeBrain tries to lock pthread mutex before initialization
issue_contents: I tried the baxter tictactoe package on Baxter and encountered an issue during calibration stage. The tictactoeBrain node randomly gets stuck in its the constructor and the process doesn't exit gracefully after Ctrl-c is pressed.
I think there is a problem that the "setBrainState()" function tries to lock "_mutex_brain", which is a pthread mutex, in the class constructor before it's properly initialized.
Quote from
"If mutex does not refer to an initialized mutex object, the behavior of pthread_mutex_lock(), pthread_mutex_trylock(), and pthread_mutex_unlock() is undefined."

Interesting. This never happened to me; neither with or without the robot (I just tested in both cases). Overall, this could be the right occasion to move out from POSIX threads and use more andvanced C++11 features such as shared pointers.
I just moved initialization of the mutexes
setBrain state (see
), can you please test it on your robot and report to me if that does not work?
Also, feel free to contribute to a README of sorts on how to run the demo. We are the only users right now and it's difficult to gauge the README's efficacy without external users.

I've tested the solution on Ubuntu 14.04 and ROS Indigo before I created the issue. The problem has never occurred in the first run in a brand new terminal, but would occur in a indeterminate manner if the group of nodes are killed (Ctrl-C) and relaunch in the same terminal. I could sometime find "roslaunch" process is still running after Ctrl-C with ps command. The sensor calibration usually takes 30 seconds to forever before the solution. It's literally done immediately after the fix.

My guess is that the pthread runtime is trying to recycle used mutex objects. Locking an uninitialized mutex may succeed but would possibly create issues on its destruction.  This in turn would fail the lock attempt next time and stop the node in its constructor.

Quote: "The pthread_mutex_destroy() function shall destroy the mutex object referenced by mutex; the mutex object becomes, in effect, uninitialized. An implementation may cause pthread_mutex_destroy() to set the object referenced by mutex to an invalid value. A destroyed mutex object can be reinitialized using pthread_mutex_init(); the results of otherwise referencing the object after it has been destroyed are undefined. "
I am a student from University of Canberra and I've finished my study on Baxter. New students are coming to take over the project and I'll make them involved in improving README.
sorry if I don't understand, so now it works? and we can close the issue?
Another question, what do you mean with "sensor calibration"?
I am a student from University of Canberra and I've finished my study on Baxter. New students are coming to take over the project and I'll make them involved in improving README.
That would be great!

Also, if you want to request new features, feel free to ask them, we can easily integrate everything into the main repository (e.g. make the user move first instead of the robot, as you did in your personal copy of this repo).
Sorry to make you confused. I had the same fix as you did in my workspace and tested before I created the issue. It works with the fix and issue can be closed.

I used the term "sensor calibration" to refer the STATE_CALIB state in board_state_sensor node. The board_state_sensor node would not finish calibration until tictactoeBrain node reaches certain state. So the Baxter looks like doing sensor calibration forever.
Ah okay that makes sense.
Thank you for the help!
issue_quotes: I am a student from University of Canberra and I've finished my study on Baxter. New students are coming to take over the project and I'll make them involved in improving README.

issue_contents: The current arm service provided in baxter_collaboration::ArmCtrl class is blocking, and in turn the ArmCtrl::serviceCb() is blocking as well. It gave me hardship when I was trying to move both arms at the same time or make Baxter doing other social actions at the same time. I made an non-block arm server to do the job in worker threads and join them later in user code.  However I feel an action server could be a better solution.
Maybe baxter_collaboration is the better place for this issue. Feel free to move it.

A service callback is blocking by definition. You should change ROS to change that. What did you do in order to overcome this issue exactly? Where does the code blocks? If you can share some code snippets it would be great.
Action server might not be a bad idea, but again it requires some time (which I don't have right now).

You are right that a ROS service is blocking by definition. Plus Baxter SDK expects to receive joint command at 5Hz minimum, which requires the callback function keeping sending joint command, and this is blocking.
Quote:

"A control rate timeout is also enforced at this motor controller layer. This states that if a new 'JointCommand' message is not received within the specified timeout (0.2 seconds, or 5Hz), the robot will 'Timeout'. When the robot 'Times out', the current control mode is exited, reverting back to position control mode where the robot will command (hold) it's current joint angles. "

What I did is a temporary patch up to make the request to server return ASAP by making the service callback function return ASAP. It's not non-blocking indeed but quite close. The user code checks the internal controller state in RobotInterface class later to determine the current state of the service and joins worker threads. My fix is definitely undesirable and only works where arm controller and tictactoeBrain are running in the same node.
An action server would make user code nice and neat.
I agree with you. I'll see if I find some time to work on this. Basically what I have right now is a sort of action server internal to a node, it's just a matter of improving it a bit I think.
I am closing as wontfix right now since I don't have time. Can you please me link me to your temporary patch so that I can understand it a little bit more? Thanks!
issue_quotes: "A control rate timeout is also enforced at this motor controller layer. This states that if a new 'JointCommand' message is not received within the specified timeout (0.2 seconds, or 5Hz), the robot will 'Timeout'. When the robot 'Times out', the current control mode is exited, reverting back to position control mode where the robot will command (hold) it's current joint angles. "

issue_title: Can fastrack be applied to autonomous driving, and how to modify it?
issue_contents: Yes, but (as with any serious problem) there will be some challenges.

Just emphasizing this point again: FaSTrack gives you a safety margin around a planning algorithm that can be used for collision-checking during motion planning. It also gives you a safety controller that will definitely keep the vehicle within that safety margin. It works very well for low-dimensional (< 5) systems and has been demonstrated in slightly higher (7) dimensional systems. It
tell you what planning algorithm to use, and it will not automatically guarantee safety if the environment is uncertain or the planning algorithm is not recursively feasible.
Hope this helps. I'm happy to discuss more.
Hi David, based on your response I would like to ask a further question if possible.
From the paper 'Planning, Fast and Slow: A Framework for Adaptive Real-Time Safe Trajectory Planning', we have the quote "This provides autonomous systems with the ability to
, and the flexibility to maneuver differently in the presence of obstacles than they would in free space, all
while maintaining a strict safety guarantee."

Unless I am reading that wrong, shouldn't FaSTrack be applicable to receding horizon planning? Thank you for any clarification. I am currently looking into applying FaSTrack for an underwater robotics simulation application, which is why I ask.
Hi David, sorry to reply late, I am still working on the theory and algorithms, and not very sure about your opinions.
As in the ans,
that is to say, Receding horizon controller is not suitable to FaSTrack?
If I choose the simple PID controller, can FaSTrack achieve good performance if applied into autonomous driving?
And, I notice that the obstacles are represented by spheres, does it easy to represent them by boxes?
Ok so I think the receding horizon part needs some clarification. As I said before, in general,
is
recursively feasible although there are ways to make it so (e.g.
from U. Rosolia, a colleague of ours at Berkeley). In our work
, we indeed claim that our work provides a strict safety guarantee even when we replan. However, if you the proof of that claim in Section IV, you will see that we rely upon the specific

used throughout the paper. Essentially, the proof boils down to the fact that the planner can always just decide to stop and hold position at any point in time; this implies recursive feasibility. Moreover, it can retrace any previous plan back to the starting point; this implies liveness. Of course, these properties do not hold for more general dynamical systems (e.g. any with inertia). The main idea behind FaSTrack (and Planning, Fast and Slow, for that matter) is still totally viable for such models; you just can't expect them to guarantee recursive feasibility if the underlying planning model is not recursively feasible.

To summarize: FaSTrack provides a low-level controller and a guaranteed tracking error bound that quantifies how far away the real system will ever get from a hypothetical dynamical model used for motion planning. This error bound can then be used by the motion planner to collision-check its trajectories. That's it. If the planner is recursively feasible, wonderful. If not, that's fine - using the tracking error bound is still (we would argue) a strictly better idea than not using it. Does this make sense?

, you're asking if PID control works with FaSTrack. The short version is that yes, you can totally use PID (and we do - we just call it LQR but LQR is just a fancy PD controller...) and wrap it with the safety controller from FaSTrack in a least restrictive control framework. I believe we explain this in the
. However (as per this subheading title) I suspect there may be some misunderstanding underlying this question - let me emphasize:
. In pretty much any robotics application, motion plans are generated (e.g. with an RRT, or iterative LQR, or some other technique) and then
or
by a low-level controller of some kind. In FaSTrack, we provide a reachability-based low-level controller. The
can be whatever algorithm you like, provided that the trajectories it outputs can be expressed as the solution to some ODE defined by a
. I hope this helps.

Obstacles can be totally generic. We used spheres because, in all honesty, it was the easiest thing I could think of that wasn't totally useless. Boxes are cool too. Occupancy grids. You name it. As long as you can do things like collision check everything should be fine.
Thanks for your patient explanations. So receding horizon planning is not suitable, but RRT and the like in OMPL which are recursively feasible and can be applied into fastrack, that is right?
I'm happy to explain - no worries.

Let me attempt to draw a distinction here between receding horizon / MPC planning and RRT-style approaches. In MPC, typically you plan for a short time horizon using some dynamical system model and design a sequence of controls whose corresponding state trajectory over that time horizon yields low cost; execute part of that trajectory; repeat. In RRT-style approaches you typically plan all the way to your end goal and just go - if you need to replan then you can, but that's not always necessary (e.g. if you know everything about the world already). RRT-style approaches are also typically,
or
approaches meaning that the underlying dynamical model they assume is something like
. In this case, they are
because setting
keeps the planner's state
constant. Recursive feasibility issues (in static environments as considered here) pop up only when it is impossible to maintain a constant state.
In our example in
, we used an geometric RRT to plan all the way to the goal and we replanned whenever we saw a new obstacle. This is recursively feasible because we can always set
for the planner and just hover inside the resulting tracking error bound.
However, we could equally well have used a more complicated

planning model, either with RRT or MPC or what have you. We just would not inherit any recursive feasibility guarantees if those planners (with that model) did not have them to start with. Using FaSTrack in such situations
because it will still avoid any collisions due to errors tracking a planned trajectory. It just won't stop the planner from getting into situations where no safe plan exists.

I should also mention that several of us are working on an extension to FaSTrack that explicitly incorporates high-level logic to force receding horizon planners to be recursively feasible. Details will be forthcoming.
Thanks David, your insights are very helpful. I have a question related to a couple of the last points you made, in part related to my specific application.

The idea would be to utilize D*-lite path planning to plan a path in a partially unknown 3D underwater environment. D*-lite is a geometric planner, like with the example used in Planning, Fast, and Slow.  Obstacles would be augmented by the safety margin determined by FasTracks offline reachability analysis for a vehicle. Clearly there is no recursive feasibility in my case due to the vehicles inertia. If I used the hybrid tracking controller, as described in the
, am I correct in saying that FasTrack
guarantee that the vehicle will not impact obstacles but it

guarantee that the planner will only put the vehicle in situations where it is still feasible to reach the goal location? The later restriction being due to the dynamic restrictions of the planning model.
Thank you for the help. I look forward to the extension you're talking about, it sounds interesting!
Aha so actually FaSTrack can do one better than that! Your planner (D*-lite) is
which means that it
. The fact that your actual vehicle model (in FaSTrack, the

) has inertia will get accounted for by FaSTrack's tracking error bound. That's the beauty of FaSTrack! Bottom line is - you can get recursive feasibility by using a geometric planner and still guarantee collision avoidance by using FaSTrack to follow the geometric planner with the actual system. Does that make sense?
That does make sense and is great to hear!  I think I will move forward with trying to utilize FaSTrack for my application then. Thank you for all your help David
contents_details_more: If you're using a serious, industrial dynamical model of the car, it probably has >6 states, which means you'll have to approximate the offline computation component of FaSTrack (there are some ways, e.g.

The type of safety guarantee you'll get out of FaSTrack is highly dependent upon the type of planning algorithm you're using, and specifically if that algorithm is receding horizon or not. Receding horizon planning is generally

recursively feasible, regardless of any guarantees provided by FaSTrack, so if you care about viability, liveness, and recursive feasibility you'll need to solve those problems separately anyway. Also, the FaSTrack safety guarantee will depend on how you model other objects, especially moving objects like other cars and people, and whether or not that model is stochastic. For a good example of this, check out another

issue_title: Negative angle of attack even in climb
issue_contents: I launched the default ROSplane simulation (take off at center, orbit center at 100 meters at 30 meters/sec) but the angle of attack/alpha measurement in /fixedwing/truth is always negative. Based on Small Unmanned Aircraft: Theory and Practice, pointing the nose up should result in a positive alpha but alpha tends to stay at around -0.045 to -0.05, even when climbing altitude.

Thanks for your interest in rosplane!  I think what your seeing is due to C_L_0 being positive (see figure 4.7 in the book).  This means that at zero (or slightly negative) angle of attack (aoa) the plane should still have positive lift.  Since you need about the same amount of lift throughout the flight then you will have about the same aoa the whole time.  Further, if the aircraft is flying around like a rocket (30 m/s is about 70 mph) then it wont need very much aoa to get lots of lift (equation 4.6). We should probably slow that plane down to 20 m/s or less. What really should change as you fly up and down is the pitch angle (theta). You can try plotting theta and alpha together to understand what I'm talking about a little better.

We of course have another problem with the plugins in that they do not currently incorporate wind models into the wind triangle (refer to figure 2.12). The problem is that the body frame wind model doesn't work very well for multiple UAVs flight in the same wind.  We have given that some thought but don't have solutions until someone tackles that problem.
Feel free to ask other questions and hopefully we'll get this rosplane working buttery smooth!
I agree with what

said.  The fixedwing.launch file has been updated to command an airspeed of 15 m/s (which is much closer to what it should be for this aircraft). I ran the simulation and now alpha is still negative, but much less so at -0.015 radians (-0.86 degrees).

We could make it a submodule here, make them both a submodule to another repo, or something else.  Any other ideas?

I think a "minimalist workspace" for getting the ground station running with rosplane, having rosplane, rosflight, and the groundstation as submodules, would be useful for people wanting to get a quick start.
I think I agree with

.  I think what we should do is provide a link in the ROSplane readme to the groundstation, and then in the groundstation readme, include instructions that tell people that they need to build the groundstation package inside a workspace that contains both the rosflight and rosplane packages.  I think this makes sense because this way, people will find out about the groundstation through the rosplane readme, and then if they've been using it and running the sim and stuff, then they just need to add the groundstation to their workspace and catkin_make
I'm going to call the byu-uav-class/rosplane_ws a good solution to this for now.

yes that's one of the issues, in the previous version this FindNAOqi.cmake file was duplicated in every package using NAOqi C++ APIs.

We decided not to duplicate this file in every package using naoqi functions (to look for NAOqi SDK only once during precompilation process, and not every time a package needs it) . But this assumes that people always compile all the naoqi packages at the same time and don't try to compile only naoqi_sensors for example.
So this will work for every catkin_make call but not for a catkin_make --pkg naoqi_sensors.
If this is really an issue we can still get back to the previous architecture, which is not optimised but works even if you build only one package using NAOqi C++ API.

It looks that the camera_info is not being published (at least on my V3.2 NAO with Naoqi 1.14) by default (when launching the node, nothing gets published there). Looking at the code I've seen two potential causes:

The first one is that the launch file sets two calibration file paths, the calibration_file_top and the calibration_file_bottom, and it loads both parameters in the init_config method but in the reconfigure it uses a 'camera_info_url' parameter which is not set by the launch. I guess there should be an assigment of the camera_info_url to one of the other paths depending on the camera source used. I suppose this may be due to the change of the structure of the parameters.

The other one is that when the camera_info_url param is set it is not published by default, but it the information is published when the calibration file url is changed via the dynamic reconfigure. Looking at the code there's an if in the reconfigure which sets the cameraInfoManager if self.config['camera_info_url'] != new_config['camera_info_url'], and I suppose that at the time of running the node this has not happened. I have not touched this as I don't know much about dynamic reconfigure nor why is that if there.

issue_title: irb120: meshes can probably be decimated
issue_contents: Not really high-priority, but some of the visual meshes can probably be decimated a bit. That shouldn't have an effect on visual quality.

Some of the joints in the IRB 120 (T) urdfs have transforms where a translation is defined over more than 1 axis, and for which these translations are sometimes very small (< 1mm fi). While this is perfectly legal, most industrial robots have relatively simple kinematic chains, where axes are only offset in one dimension.
The
transform is probably ok, but transforming points into any of the intermediate frames could give incorrect results (when compared to the industrial controller).
This may be a consequence of using the SolidWorks to URDF converter, as it has a tendency to place joints at strange locations.

and see what the rationale is.

This is also an issue in the abb repository, but the rgba="0 1 1 1" is cyan so the name does not accurately describe the color. I don't have a preference on the color so either the name should be changed to cyan or the rgba should be updated. It is less work to update the rgba in the abb repository so this may be the best solution.
If we are going to fix this, perhaps we should create a shared xacro that just defines all ABB colours. This can then be included in all ABB urdfs, making sure colours are consistent.
On the "shared xacro", make sure you namespace everything in such a way that it doesn't have naming collisions.  In the past I've found that multiple xacro definitions of something like
have caused issues.  Unfortunately, I can't remember the "right" way.  I know....I'm no help :)

I think,
: You are correct, it does correct the rgb for the colour yellow. I believe the only open question is, if yellow is the appropriate colour for the collision geometry.

I guess that is up to us. MoveIt will colour meshes reddish when they are in collision, iirc, so it would only be a visual aid for when inspecting the model or visualising state I guess. For (my) other pkgs, I've always just left collision and visual geometry material colour the same, but I can see the value of having separate colours.

for the colours of the meshes (as far as they don't use Collada meshes).

Current suggestion:
Variant names for ABB manipulators may include a
(indicating support for a particular feature, or a physical characteristic of the variant), a
(one or more digits, indicating maximum supported payload in kg) and finally a specification of the
of the arm (in meters). Examples:
and
All ABB support packages shall be named using the following template:
Note that this template omits the modifier, payload and reach components included in the actual product name.
All artefacts within ABB support, MoveIt configuration and plugin packages shall be named using the following template:
Where MODEL is a numeric string, MODIFIER is a string, PAYLOAD is a numeric string (max payload in kg) and REACH is a numeric string (reach converted to centimeters, avoiding fractional numbers).
If a particular model does not have variants based on reach, the REACH component should be omitted from the ROS-Industrial name as well.
Examples:
and

Can you describe how you setup your workspace and how you build it? Cloning just this repository is not enough, and is typically the reason for these kind of problems.
I cloned this package to my workspace/src path and used catkin_make to compile and there is something warning. So I rebuild it use wstool and cmake tool.
In short, after I failed to compile using catkin_make command in workspace, I run the below command in workspace/src path:
wstool init .
wstool merge abb_experimental/abb_experimental.rosinstall
wstool update
mkdir build && cd build && cmake ../ && make && sudo make install
There is a divergence between the
and the instructions
. Try the instructions on the wiki, those should work.
The missing step is using
to make sure you have all dependencies installed. It would seem like you don't have them, which is why compilation and later running failed.
wrote:
mkdir build && cd build && cmake ../ && make && sudo make install
Note: only in very rare circumstances would a
be used with ROS packages. For almost all typical usage, please follow regular a Catkin workflow as is documented on the wiki.
. thanks a lot. I will try it tomorrow，and give feedback to you.

After I used 'hardware_interface/PositionJointInterface' to replace 'PositionJointInterface' in irb120_3_58_macro.xacro file, the warnings missed.
That warning is somewhat expected, as the
pkgs have been created for Gazebo 2, while you are using a newer version.
Related:
Could I please ask you to close this issue if you feel it has been resolved?
Of course. Thank you again.

The *_support packages in this repository have run_depend/exec_depend dependencies on rviz:

issue_title: Does this repo further fragment abb support?
issue_contents: Wouldn't this code be better kept in the main

repo as the latest branch, and keep older branches for backwards compatibility? Otherwise you really confuse developers which to use / contribute to / focus on. This is messy. When does "experimental" no longer become experimental?
Please refer to
(perhaps specifically
). There is a specific reason for why we have
repositories in ROS-Industrial.
This repository is not something where old branches / pkgs are stored or bw compatibility is maintained. Experimental pkgs are experimental, that's why they are hosted here.
As this is not an actual bug or issue with the pkgs in this repository, I'll close it, but feel free to keep commenting.
Looks like the 120 has inertial values defined in the URDF here:
Does anyone know how those values were determined?
and I are trying to determine those values for the IRB1200 5_90 and 7_70 models. We've contacted ABB and they aren't willing to share those values - did someone measure them?
/cc
I don't know where they came from, but sometimes people use the CAD model to estimate them.  As you have found, the robot vendors do not provide this information.  I would use at your own risk.
These were made up / guessed / approximated using SolidWorks (from

The masses and inertial values for each link were calculated in solidworks. Adding the mass of each link gives a total of 18kg, which is lower than the robots actual value of 25kg. I contacted ABB about this, but the factory doesn't provide more accurate values for each link. They did say that solidworks values are accurate, but that they don't include the robot cable harness as the mass distribution is difficult to calculate. I updated the inertia tensors and cog origins to account for the new joint translations, but it might be worth double checking these values. The inertia tensor for link 6 seemed was causing problems in Gazebo (values were too small) so I ended up using a simplified matrix for this link.
See also
I'm going to close this as it's not really an issue with the packages.
Feel free to keep commenting though.
Thanks for the info! We'll estimate the intertias as well as we can and submit a PR. They'll be useful for doing more realistic gazebo simulation of the robot.
issue_quotes: The masses and inertial values for each link were calculated in solidworks. Adding the mass of each link gives a total of 18kg, which is lower than the robots actual value of 25kg. I contacted ABB about this, but the factory doesn't provide more accurate values for each link. They did say that solidworks values are accurate, but that they don't include the robot cable harness as the mass distribution is difficult to calculate. I updated the inertia tensors and cog origins to account for the new joint translations, but it might be worth double checking these values. The inertia tensor for link 6 seemed was causing problems in Gazebo (values were too small) so I ended up using a simplified matrix for this link.

issue_title: how to run the server and client correctly
issue_contents: hi,I am a newer of opcua,and i download ur code,  compile correctly.but i don't know how to use it,i just roslaunch the server and client .can u help me how to run it correctly? thank u very much!
Hi
what do you want to do? what is your goal? This is just a mapper from OPC UA to ROS and opposite.

I want to use ur mapper to convert my ros message to OPC UA(for Server) in PC-A,and there is another PC-B (OS is windows) to be a OPC UA client. The goal is to realize the communication between PC-A and PC-B.I have no idea,Can you give some advice? Thanks again!
you should start

After a few seconds (20-30, depending on number of topics) you will get OPC UA Server started. Than you can explore it using UaExpert. For windows client please see example applications in python_opcua repositry.
Hello :)
since I couldn't find anything about it in this repository, I want to ask if there is some kind of documentation or tutorial on how to use your package.
For example: How do I send packages to a certain IP? How do I listen to a certain IP? When should I run rosopcua.launch and when should I run client.launch?
Thank you
Hi @ToRaVe ,
thank you for your interest in this package. Sorry not to answer earlier, but I was not available last week. I added in PR
getting started steps in each README.md file.

Have a nice day! :)

if str(self.name)== "/slam/pos" :
rospy.loginfo(str(self.name))
self._recursive_create_items(self.parent, idx, topic_name, topic_type, self.message_instance, True)
self._subscriber = rospy.Subscriber(self.name, self.message_class, self.message_callback)
self._publisher = rospy.Publisher(self.name, self.message_class, queue_size=1)
rospy.loginfo("Created ROS Topic with name: " + str(self.name))
now create only the specific topic that i need and exclude camera topic that create problem.

parameter.
