issue_title: EKF problem with Az bias estimate
issue_contents: If Az is left unfixed, then it climbs until it gets to about 10 m/s^2.  Or, just enough to cancel out gravity.  Not really sure why.  I fixed it, and I get good enough performance for now.  I'm moving on to velocity control.
I would suspect that
may have fixed this in his solution to
,  can you confirm that this issue is solved?
ekf remove, now using mekf
We need to be able to account for the transform in the camera (6DOF)
Thanks Jerel!!  That is awesome.  We put the offset in the measurement model in the EKF
As it stands currently, we often replenish points on top of current points.  We need a good way to make sure that new points are unique.
We set it to replenish points if less than 75% of the original points were found.  Not perhaps the most elegant, but it seems to work
We need to implement a velocity controller and an altitude controller in order to test our mono vo in hardware.  Started on the "velocity_control" branch
I finished this.
Not sure why this is, but our velocities estimates are about half that of truth when in the simulator.  We should dive into this when we have time
Per my email discussion with
, the EKF is really strugging on simulated data.
Even after using a perfect IMU and perfect GPS, we get really bad performance.
So I just played around with it for a while, and I'm still getting the poor performance.

Do you think you could take a minute and go through my jacobians?  I have found the latex source code, and I added it to the repo.  I did actually find an error when I went through them just now, I but I would appreciate another set of eyes.

I have turned of the velocity and angle portion of the GPS update.  I also turned off all noise on the IMU and the GPS in the ros_copter_ekf_testing branch of byu-magicc/fcu_sim.  Go ahead and try it with the ekf_development branch.

I haven't looked at the jacobian yet because I wanted to see how it was behaving first and I'm having trouble with the ros_copter_ekf_testing branch of byu-magicc/fcu_sim.  It is only publishing imu messages of (0,0,-9.8).  It seems that in gazebo_imu_plugin.cpp vdot is always zero.
Since the imu z is always -9.8 it never triggers the flying_ bool to start running gps and imu updates and the ekf always just publishes an estimate of zero.
That's weird...  Okay.  So there was a comment in the original source code that says that sometimes, GetRelativeLinearAccel returns zero.  Which would be why you're getting vdot to always be zero.
We could do it the way that ETHZ did it, but lets add in the coriolis terms. - The following psuedocode should work
What do you think?
I implemented vdot that way and it seems to be working pretty well.
I looked through the jacobian on the second page of that pdf.  I think I found a few errors.  Could you double check these?
I implemented these changes but it still doesn't work very well.  I'll keep looking into it but I was hoping you could check these 3 changes to make sure I'm not thinking about this wrong.
You're right.  Thanks for going through those.  I know that's a huge pain.

I think I may have figured out (at least partially) what is going on.  It has to do with the IMU plugin. Somehow, gravity is being applied backwards (I tested this by making the quad go up and down over and over again, and watching the simulated IMU data.).
It should be
Notice, the final line.  Instead of the previous version, where we were doing
we are flipping gravity
I am in the middle of some work on
right now, so it'll be a huge pain to merge that change myself.  I was wondering if you could try putting that in, and see what happens.

My next test, to make sure that IMU is working properly would be to send the quad back and forth in the x-direction such that it reaches steady-state velocity, observe IMU to make sure it responds as expected, and again in the y-direction.  Do you think you could do that, and make sure that works?  You could also see it if in the EKF if the roll and pitch estimates are terrible.
I'm sorry this is such a huge pain. It's supposed to be easy.  I guarantee though, that this will be helpful to everyone else in the lab.
By the way, I am working on an altitude estimator right now, and these changes fixed the problem on my side.  I am only doing altitude right now, so I am not going to be able to see angle changes.

Switching the gravity didn't fix it.  I think the problem may come from the angle estimates so I've been looking at the components of the orientation quaternion.  I'm seeing something kind of weird that I don't understand.  With the gravity switched to being subtracted, I get:
It goes the opposite direction from truth.
When I switch back to adding gravity, the bumps happen the same but it slowly diverges:
Do you know what might cause this?

On equation 8 of the EKF Jacobian paper, I believe that the x acceleration should be **-**g*st.  This effects equation 9 and the imu updated step.  Changing this in the code make the x position estimate stop going the opposite direction.
Here is a recent graph of the estimate I get with the GPS helping keep it on track:
The IMU part of the estimate still tends to overshoot the actual values.  Is this normal?  I expected it to be more accurate when we are using perfect IMU messages.
Also, would you like me to make the changes I've pointed out to the PDF and push that?
Actually, the y estimate was also going the wrong way until I switched the sign of the y acceleration in equation 8 (now it is **+**g
sp).
Haha!!  Nice.  That is awesome.  Fantastic work.  Kalman Filter can be so frustrating, way to stick with it.

The reason that the IMU doesn't work perfectly is because there is simulated drag.  The drag introduces acceleration in the x and y dimensions which is not taken into account in our dynamic model (we could take it into account, you can talk to David about this if you're interested, the drag dynamics are actually observable given position data).  This additional acceleration makes our attitude estimate wrong.  The transient response is very well estimated by the gyros, but the prolonged attitude estimation tends towards level.  That is, unless we start estimating drag.

Okay, so - here's what you should do.  Take the branch with the updated jacobians, and create a pull request, then assign me to it. That's the official way that we will merge all your changes into master.  You have the ability to merge it straight in yourself, but it's sort of poor form.  Do the same thing with the simulator.   The pull request lets us talk about the changes, and I can make suggestions, and eventually we'll merge it in and it will be the official master.

and

issue_title: EKF node - Parameter about frame of Mocap
issue_contents: Depending on the truth source, the frame changes.  The motion capture room published in NWU, while the gazebo simulator publishes in NED.

We can either switch mocap, so that everything we do is in NWU, (I think that is actually a good idea, so we can compare apples to apples when we plot them side-by-side).  Or, we can add a parameter to the ekf node to determine which frame the truth data is coming in on, so we filter accordingly.
ekf removed, now using mekf
We need to support the magnetometer before we can get good position and velocity estimates.
and

, what would be left to do before we could use the magnetometer to resolve our heading? I can make sure that the latest ROSflight supports mag early this week.  I have delayed getting the mag going because I wanted to merge it in at the same time I merged in the asynchronous stuff.  However,  I have been running into some weird issues getting multiple sensors reading asynchronously on ROSflight which has caused some delays.  What if we just do asynchronous IMU, while blocking other sensors for now, until I can resolve those issues?
I remember that
was working on getting mag calibrated and streaming from byu-magicc/fcu_io before I left, but I don't know what the state of that is currently.

, do you think that you could get it into the ekf?  Unfortunately, I'm a little hazy on the measurement model.  I'm pretty sure that it is in the UAV book, and if it's not, it is definitely somewhere online.  We might need to do a little reading before we fully understand the measurement models, but once we have them, it should be easy to simulate and add to the EKF.  What do you think?
I think this is the final step for the LANL project, I guess this and
There is a model for magnetometers in the UAV book.  I understand most of it so I can get started putting it into the EKF.

I do have one question: The model applies bias error and sensor noise.  I assume these are related to the alpha and beta terms in the state, but I don't really understand how they relate.  How should the bias error and sensor noise be represented in the ekf?
Also, what kind of message will the magnetometer make?
Great!  Thanks

.  The alpha and beta terms in the EKF are biases on the accelerometer and gyro measurements, respectively.  We would need an additional 3 states as biases for the magnetometer, if we decided to estimate them.  For now, let's not estimate magnetometer bias.

However, you're right, we do get some information, especially about the gyros biases in the magnetometer update.  Do a similar thing as we did for the GPS.  First, write the vector of measurements as a function of the states and inputs.  The magnetometer measurement will include the inputs, which are
, and
.  Then, take each of these input terms, and substitute the measurement, plus the bias, because
The
term shows up whenever you include
, and the beta terms show up when you use
, and
.  I don't think that the GPS was a function of the inputs, so this will be a little more complicated, but not terrible.  You'll end up with a few 1's in the Jacobian, on the bias terms.

Right this minute, I can't remember if we are assuming that the bias is positive, or negative.  I might have derived it backwards, but I can't remember.  You've gone through my accelerometer model, it should be a very similar model for the magnetometer.  If you want, you can write it up first in the latex document, and I'll go through it.
The magnetometer will be a

I don't understand what are az, p, q, and r?  And where do these come into the magnetometer measurements?  As far as I can tell, the magnetometer measurements are only related to phi, theta, ans psi.  In the IMU part of the pdf, it just drops all the terms with p, q, and r because the coriolis terms are small.
Oh, yeah. You're right.  I think it will be independent of the bias terms then.
I wrote everything up for the magnetometer on the latex document.  Could you take a look at it?
I went through the latex doc.  I don't have the UAV book, so I didn't check eq. 17.  Assuming that 17 is right, then all the terms in 19 are right.  Nice work!
I do have one recommendation. Before merging, let's change the known magnetic field vector to something other than
.  It took me a second to figure out what you were talking about because I am used to
being used for acceleration vectors.  Let's use something else, what about

The UAV book didn't seem to have exactly what I needed to make an EKF.  It calculated the heading based on the measured magnetic field but there wasn't an easy way to isolate the components of the magnetic field in order to take partial derivatives.  But based on how it described the magnetometer working, I figured that the measured magnetic field is simply the global magnetic field transformed into the robot frame.  Does that sound right?  That is where eq 17 comes from.  I added to the latex document to make it clear how I calculated eq 17.
In order to make sense of the measured magnetic field, it has to know what the magnetic field is at it's current location.  I was thinking of using the code from
to do this.  Is there a better way?
Awesome!  I think that is exactly the right approach.

Yeah, it'd be sweet to use that data.  Is the code overly complicated?  Mag is returned 160 times per second, so it may make sense to run it only on initialization, and assume that it is constant throughout the flight.

I'll go through the derivation of eq. 17 later this evening, but It looks right.  I spend some time thinking about the angles, and it made sense. What's the approach now?  Do we need to set up a simulation?

As for my tasks, I just made a pull request for the async branch yesterday, which has magnetometer (and a super-snazzy circular buffer for asynchronously reading i2c).   I'm sure you're more aware of the state of mag calibration than I am.

The code from WMM seems easy enough to use.  I'm just having trouble accessing it's functions from within ekf.cpp.  I've got the header from WMM included and it recognizes all of the structs declared there but not the functions.
The next step is probably setting up a simulator so we can test it.  Do you want to do that our should I try?
I'll go ahead and set up the simulator.  You get the ekf going, and I think you can work with
on getting the calibration going.

I can't get the WMM code to work.  It calls some memory allocation functions that use malloc that throw errors.  The only way I've been able to convince ros to find the file is to change it from .c to .cpp.  But a physics professor I was talking to told me that malloc is incompatible with c++.  Any thoughts on how to fix this?  Or ideas on other ways to determine what the magnetic field should be in a given location?

Meanwhile, I've been testing things with the same magnetic field the simulation uses.  I turned off the IMU and GPS so only the magnetometer is updating.  When I do that, phi, theta, and psi all are nearly 0 and don't really change.  I figure that maybe it isn't trusting my magnetometer measurements at all, but I thought changing the R matrix would fix this but it doesn't seem to make a difference.  What else could make it do this?
I'm having a problem with fcu_sim.  About 3/4 of the time when I run it, it crashes and prints this:
Any ideas?
I was able to tune everything to get the magnetometer working pretty well.  This is what it looks like with an IMU and Magnetometer:
With magnetometer noise on, I get this:
Is this accurate enough?  Is there anything I can do to improve it?
strikes again!

This is awesome, and those are fantastic results.  You can only track so well with noise, and we don't want to spend too much time tuning it in simulation, since we'll likely have to do it again in hardware.
Put up a merge request!

issue_title: Takes off like stupid sometimes in waypoints
issue_contents: Sometimes, the position controller sends the drone upwards at full throttle.
Reported by
in NNOA project.
Investigating this issue, We just need to saturate the desired acceleration in z to minus gravity.
Otherwise, large negative desired accelerations will contribute to the total desired thrust, and cause an inverted feedback loop.
Will that just make us go upwards at -gravity instead of full throttle?
Robert
On Wed, Nov 16, 2016 at 7:29 PM, James Jackson
wrote:
Investigating this issue, We just need to saturate the desired
acceleration in z to minus gravity. Line 243
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
or mute the thread

No.  Because I add gravity back in, if we saturate to gravity, then the commanded thrust will be zero.  We only need to saturate on downward accelerations, because we often have a thrust to weight ratio greater than 2 with multi rotors.
gotcha!

Hi guys, first of all thanks for the hard work on this project. Sorry for the long post, but I don't want to miss anything:

I want to simulate the environment Naze32 10 DOF (running ROSflight) + Sonar in Gazebo. For that aim I am using the ROSflight branch "RC1.0". Right now I am ok simulating with the already existing xacro quadcopter. Steps I'm following to get everything running are:
Run "multirotor.launch" contained in rosflight_sim.
Run a "rosflight_io" node in order to start the SIL controller, with the udp parameter to true (set the  MIXER parameter to 1, which is aimed for X quadrotors).
Run a "rc_joy" node. (I have a FlySky transmitter attached to the computer)

Up to here the system works nicely. I can control the quadrotor via the transmitter. However it shows me an error in the ROS console saying "Unhealthy parameter estimator", every time I flight (active sensors on the board are: baro, magnetometer and sonar), event hough I'm controlling the quadrotor pretty well I keep reading the error, and immediately after the recover error message.

At this point I wanted to autonomously hover the quad in the air (just to check how to interact with topics). I thought I could use the "mekf" node in "ROScopter" package, adding to what i ran before the following steps:
Load common multirotor parameters from /roscopter_sim/params/multirotor.yaml (previously to that I loaded the /rosflight_sim/params/multirotor.yaml).
Run roscopter node "mekf", remapping "baro/data" to "baro", "sonar/data" to /sonar" and "mag/data" to "magnetometer".
As I also needed a controller I also ran the node "controller".
In order to hover at 2 meter height, I published a message in the /high_level_command with the following values (x=0,y=0,z=0,F=-2,mode=4).

I thought with these steps it would work but it doesn't, it flies away. I don't know what I am missing. I just want to set this environment up in order to be able to write my own navigation node (eventually I want to add also a camera to perform optical flow).
I am attaching the rosbag file of the simulation and the .launch, in case it helps.
Tank you very much!
Hey Pep!
Again, thanks for reporting this error!

Just real quick, let me explain the "UNHEALTHY ESTIMATOR" error.  The estimator makes an "unaccelerated flight assumption"  That is, it expects the norm of the acceleration vector to be approximately 9.8 m/s^2.  In implementation, if acceleration is measured to be more than 15% away from that nominal value, it skips the accelerometer update step of the estimation and just integrates gyros.  (This is the desired behavior, since that main assumption is being invalidated and doing the update would screw up the estimate.)   However, if you undergo an accelerated motion for more than 0.5 seconds, it throws that error and immediately clears it when it runs an accelerometer update.  It is nothing to be worried about, and clearly it's being thrown too often.  Perhaps we should up the time to something like 3-5 seconds, because that actually would be a problem.
One of us will dig into the setup you have going and see if we can't figure out what's going on with the fly-away error.
Okay, I think the first thing is that you're not loading the roscopter parameters. (try the
I just pushed)
The second thing is that the estimator defaults are tuned for a previous simulation which had far less noise on accelerometers.  We need to tune this.

The third thing is that the controller has an issue if you get too far above your set point.  The model inversion step ends up commanding a large acceleration because there's a big error, which maps into a big thrust.  This turns into positive feedback if you get too high above your setpoint.
For now,
flies on truth.  As soon as the estimator is tuned for the SIL sensors, we will switch it over to estimates.
You might also want to pull down the latest for
before you try again.
Hi guys,
thank you so much! James, I've done what you told me and it worked.

So, here what I understand is that we use the real position and not the estimated (remapped topics in the launch file). As soon as you do this tunning needed for flying with the estimate, please let me know.
I'll be aware on the changes in the repository.
Thanks for your help!

issue_title: How to add additional sensors to the mekf?
issue_contents: Hey, so our project is trying to build an autonomous quadcopter that navigates indoors without the aid of GPS, and because of size and weight limitations, we can't really use a LiDAR and perform SLAM with that. That leaves just a few possibilities. Now I've set up the roscopter package and I notice that for the mekf node, it uses IMU, GPS, magnetometer, barometer, and sonar data from what is published by rosflight_io to estimate the current state. Without the GPS input however, as far as I understand, just using the IMU data will not be enough because eventually the error builds even if the initial error is very small. No one in my project is really familiar with how EKFs work, and aside from reading and researching on our own, I wanted to ask you guys how you would go about adding sensors to the mekf.

So for instance, one of the sensors that could help us is an optical flow sensor, and specifically, we have the PX4flow board and have it setup to work with the px4flow_node package, and that would give us x, y, x-velocity, and y-velocity values.
Hey
, cool project!  The main motivation for our stuff is actually GPS-denied, however we haven't posted a lot of our GPS-denied code.
So, in general, to add sensors to an EKF you have to derive a "measurement model" and the associated jacobian.
For example, if you can write the estimated measurement from the PX4Flow in terms of the state where
is the state and
is the measurement.
Then the Jacobian you need to implement is
(and should be a short and fat matrix).
the
and
all create an
vector (the measurement) and an
matrix, (the jacobian).  Once you have those matrices, you can plug them into the Kalman Filter update step, which is also in each of these callback functions.
Honestly, Kalman filtering can be pretty complicated. I would recommend at the very least reading Dr. Beard's notes on the subject (
) (chapter 6)
I haven't looked at the filter in this package in a long while... it's kinda old, and we are in the middle of adapting our
package that
and I have been working on to be a bit more generic.  That filter will ultimately replace the
in roscopter. Adding measurement models is a little easier in that package, and it's being actively maintained.
Also, now that I am thinking about it, if you can carry a camera and have the computing power onboard, I would reommend
.   It's a really superb visual-inertial estimation package that works with almost anything.

Ok, so I'll need some more help on this. After going through the code a bit more, as well as the paper (which I honestly was not really able to understand past the first chapter), here is what I'm getting. VI-EKF and VINS aside, say we want to add the optical flow data to the MEKF, this is what I have understood that I need to do (verify and correct me please):

I need to add to the multirotor.yaml file variables related to the PX4Flow sensor. Now the sensors outputs flow_x, flow_y, and altitude, which are (delta)(pixels) in x, (delta)(pixels) in y, height in meters respectively. You can see this from this video

. Following from the GPS stuff in this file as it is the most similar to the optical flow data, I will need need to add a Rpx4flow variable for the covariance, put some flow_x stddev, flow_y stddev, alt stddev, k_flow_x, k_flow_y, k_alt, initial_flow_x, initial_flow_y, initial_alt, optflow_bias. Now, how on Earth do I get any of these values (aside from the initial stuff).
Once I have those parameters, set, do I need to change P0, Qx, Qu, etc. or any of the functions in mekf.cpp that involve updating the covariance and so on?
Once those parameters are set, I see that the callback function might look something like this?

issue_contents: Hi,

I would like to know if ROS_motionServer file on yumi_hw is available or is going to be available. Now  I am usig yumi_support/rapid/ROS_motionServer file, but it Works with joint_traj_msg, different as msg_joint_data.
If not, I will modify the actual ROS_motionServer file in yumi_support directory.
Thanks for all,
Júlia
Hi Julia,

when using yumi with a ros_control interface we had to do things a little bit differently from the legacy MoveIt interface. The legacy interface requires one state server and one motion server for each arm. The ros control interface only uses one state server for both arms. This is done in a tight loop with the corresponding hardware interface driver: we send the current joint states from RAPID to the interface node and then block and wait for the interface node to send us back the next joint commands. Unlike the legacy interface, we don't support trajectory download. The robot is at all times controlled by the ros_control node and requires constant commands.
To make this work, also note that you need to download our fork of industrial_core, as there is a small but very necessary change in the number of joints we are communicating between the nodes.
Hope that helps.
Todor

issue_title: what is the relationship between yumi_support/rapid and yumi_hw/rapid/ROS_control ? can I only use the former one instead of the latter one?
issue_contents: what is the relationship between    yumi_support/rapid    and     yumi_hw/rapid/ROS_control ?
Because I can understand the yumi_support/rapid files: each arm have a motion server and state server unlike the files in yumi_hw/rapid/ROS_control which didn't contain a motion_server.
So can I only use the former one: yumi_support/rapid?
yumi_support/rapid contains modules for running trajectory downloading to the robot. This is the preferred way to interface if you are using move_it and trajectory action interfaces.

The yumi_hw/rapid folder is used if you are setting up a ros_control hardware interface. In that case you are directly giving control setpoints, instead of downloading a trajectory. Commands are executed immediately, and feedback sent on the same connection object back to the ROS side. This is the preferd mode for running ros_control controllers. At the moment, this interface runs at about 10Hz.
That said, the moveit interface has not been extensively tested, so there might still be bugs in there. I also need to check if I have uploaded the latest versions from our robot to the repository.

issue_title: Split ros_control hardware interface arguments for arms and gripper
issue_contents: yumi_description/urdf/yumi.urdf.xacro should take two arguments such that the hardware interfaces for arms and grippers can be set independently.
Hello Robert,
I added this to our KTH fork yesterday. The corresponding commit is:
The files modified are:
yumi_description/urdf/yumi.urdf.xacro
yumi_description/urdf/yumi_nogrippers.urdf.xacro
yumi_launch/launch/yumi_gazebo_pos.launch
yumi_launch/launch/yumi_gazebo_vel.launch
yumi_launch/launch/yumi_pos_control.launch
yumi_launch/launch/yumi_vel_control.launch
Hi there,
I just wanted to know if there is an available (plug-and-play) torque interface for Yumi robot.
I would like to send joint torque commands, and also be able to read external force/torques applied to the robot.
Thanks for your help and sorry if this is irrelevant to your repository.
Mahdi
Hi Mahdi,

unfortunately that's not a feature we can do anything about at the moment. The interfaces to the robot from the manufacturer's side don't at the moment allow controlling or reading the joint torques. If this changes at some point, we would of course be very eager to add this support :)
T.
Thanks for your quick response.
Hi
I have tried to build this following the instructions provided but it fails with the following error

Could not find a package configuration file provided by "abb_egm_interface"
with any of the following names:
I have not been able to find anything related to these in the repository.
Cheers
Hi,

sorry about that. We are working on some new features which got pushed prematurely into master. I have reverted the merge and you should be able to build now. Can you please check if you are able to build now?
Hi
Many thanks. I am now able to do a build so will close this issue.
Hi

We are having the following issue with both the simulated robot in robot studio and the actual yumi robot. When launching the "yumi_moveit_config/launch/demo_online.launch" the following error occurs.
The "right_arm/joint_trajectory_action" and "left_arm/joint_trajectory_action" clients fail to connect as shown in the image below.
Not quite sure what is wrong here as we have followed the instructions from the wiki and issues list.
We are using the RAPID files from the "src/yumi/yumi_support/rapid" folder as we are trying to control the yumi robot using the moveit rviz gui interface.
Hi,

I am afraid we might not be able to help you out much. The moveit support is a direct port from the abb_driver in ros-industrial, with very minor modifications. I did that as a first step to developing the ros_control drivers and did not debug it thoroughly. In fact, I am pretty sure the RAPID drivers that you are using would not move all joints of the robot correctly, so be very careful when testing...

I don't think any of the other maintainers are using moveit to control the robot either, so I think you might need to do some digging and debugging. I remember it sometimes took a very long time to bring up the planning scene, which would mess with the robot controllers. Check if the config uses the full robot meshes or if you are using the coarse meshes. And please post what you find here and I will try to help as I can.
T.
Hi
We have managed to get this working now using the two steps below.
We were initially missing step 1 below which is what starts the industrial_robot_client which contains the joint_trajectory_action messaging that was previously missing.
From the terminal launch "robot_interface.launch" file as shown below. Ensure the correct robot ip   address is set in this file first.
"~/catkin_ws/src/yumi/yumi_support/launch$ roslaunch robot_interface.launch"
Now in a separate terminal launch the online moveit demo as shown below.
"~/catkin_ws$ roslaunch yumi_moveit_config demo_online"
We are now able to play around with the moveit.rviz GUI robot and see the actions translated onto the actual yumi robot  and the simulated yumi robot on robot studio.
Cheers

issue_contents: Hi Everybody,

I'm sitting in front of a YuMi for some time now and wondering what driver would be best for us and where to take it from. We intend to use it for bin-picking and execute pre calculated trajectories (ie. no live feedback/realtime required). It has to be fast!

I read somewhere that the ABB_driver based joint_trajectory downloader approach is supposed to have a long (several seconds) delay before starting trajectory execution. Is that true? Is it faster for short/sparse trajectories (number of points, not distance)?
I started using the drivers from

master branch and it is moving using MoveIt!. However there is a very notable delay before it does (ca 1s) and sometimes it moves joint6 (the wrist) to 0 instead of the intended position. I'm not sure if this is a ros_control issue (I doubt it) or related to yumi_hw.  Also sometimes it hangs at startup and the joint_state_controller does not come up.

I feel safer about using the trajectory downloader approach actually because we use that for other brands already but of course I worry about the long delays. What do you think? Can you point me to whatever branch and version you recommend?
Does egm also work for position control or just velocity control?
Thanks a lot
Simon

Small update, I haven't seen any real erroneous movements any more using the position controlled driver from yumi_hw master. I also have the gripper running using the code from feature_egm branch (using fewer locks/mutexes seems to be the main difference).

Delay before execution is somewhat acceptable now at 100% controller velocity override and aiming for slower speed in the trajectory parametrization (25%). However while some movements are nice and smooth, others are quite jerky, showing lots of stop and go motion. I have two days remaining next week to get a nice presentation for our potential customer, what do you think would be the best approach? For other robots we usually send trajectories with only two points (if collision free) but I read that for this driver I need more dense ones. I currently just interpolate 100 steps, no matter what distance. What step size do you recommend? How does it depend on velocity? Doesn't ros_control interpolate itself?
Should I try one of the egm branches or is that to complicated to setup?
sorry for spaming, but any opinion? Please :)
Hi Simon,

terribly sorry for the long wait, but we are overloaded at the moment. I am afraid that you are already using the best currently available solution to your issue... There are indeed several options for the yumi drivers, which are:
sorry couldn't help more.
T.
Hi tstoyanov,

when I wrote this I was using option 2 (direct joint control over ros_control and a native RAPID interface). This was indeed starting movements without major delays but movement often got jerky and generally looked imprecise. I think issues were mostly related to a mismatch between trajectory point spacing and execution rate of these. (And then there were also the mutex and other issues)

I then switched to using classical option 1, ie trajectory download based on abb_driver and this results in smooth and relatively speedy execution. However I still have (unpredictable) delays before execution of the trajectory starts. I assume this is due to internal collision checking in the yumi controller. Also trajectories are still slower than the designated max speed.
Do you know how to disable collision checking? Other settings that limit the velocity?
Hi Simon,
and sorry for the long delay. You probably have this figured out by now, but in case you did not, you can check issue
and the suggestions there. Regarding the collision checking, I think you can look at the MotionSup (motion supervision) level. If you set that to 0, you should be able to smash into things freely :)
contents_details_more: trajectory download and then execution in RAPID. This we have tested (briefly) with MoveIt, and seems to work ok. There might be an issue with joint 7 (elbow joint), which I would have to double-check, and this might explain the strange motions you see. This is in the main branch.

direct joint control over ros_control and a native RAPID interface. This should work without any delay, but in order to use it with moveit you would need a tracking controller. This should be possible to do, but I have not tried it and I am not sure how well the tracking controller will work. There are also a lot of issues with re-starting the robot and mutex initialization in this option.

the last option is ros_control over EGM, which should work best. You would again need a tracking controller, but at least this option should give you better tracking. You would however need an EGM license from ABB in order to use this on the robot.

issue_title: Yumi robot setup with 1 PC only
issue_contents: Dear all,
Sorry to ask this question here which seems not directly related to the repository.
But this repo seems to be the only one for Yumi if I want to program yumi in Linux.
I realised there are several ways to control Yumi, but all of the options seems require Robotstudio on a Window PC and ROS on a Linux PC.
Is there a way to use a Linux PC ONLY to control the Yumi robot?
Thank you very much.
Regards,
Lin
For the future novice who just got your robot:
The ROS interface (this repo) is installed on a Linux PC which is connected to the robot service port (XP23) via Ethernet port.

The RobotStudio, which is installed on a Windows PC, will only be used when you upload the RAPID program to the robot. You will use the same service port, so you need to disconnect the robot from the Linux machine. When the program is uploaded, the RobotStudio is not needed during control.
If you don't want to switch back and forth, you can use a network switch to connect all three devices (robot, Windows PC and Linux PC) together.

That particular phrasing is currently under review as well, and I will probably add a diagram to clarify it.
For a robot where the last link already follows
(so zero-pose has robot wrist aligned with
, typically the case for industrial robots),
is expected to be coincident with
(ie: identity transform). For a robot that in its zero-position is straight-up (ie: points to the sky, such as a KUKA IIWA or a Fanuc M-430iA), and all
s only have z-axis translations between them,
should be -90 degrees rotated over y, so the
axis now points straight-up as well. See
for an example.
As ROS (or: TF) attaches child links to the
axis by default (
again), this should make attaching child links (and sub-assemblies) more straightforward, as they would now be correctly mounted against the robot flange.
If we were to use
as an EEF attachment point, which has
typically pointing 'down' (due to the
rotation over y), we'd have to undo that rotation or the EEF subassembly will be sticking out 'to the side' of the robot.
The idea is that when switching robot variants (in a top-level / composite xacro fi) attachment of the EEF subassembly will always be the same: along the
axis (with no additional rotations required).

issue_title: When will staubli_experimental be migrated to the staubli repository?
issue_contents: When will
be migrated to the
repository? What kind of testing has to be done in order to to that?

The package itself will not be migrated, as that doesn't make much sense, but individual packages in the repository may be migrated after they've seen 'enough use'. That is a somewhat qualitative (and admittedly vague) criterium, but unfortunately there's not a very concrete way to define when these packages are 'good enough'.
Validation and verification wrt real robots can be done, but takes time, and even then doesn't guarantee that the pkg is completely fault free and/or 'done'.
As to the pkgs that have been in this repository for the past year (TX90 pkgs mostly): those can be migrated at our earliest convenience (but probably after we address the points you raised in
See also
(but that will be withdrawn).
As this is not really an issue with the pkgs in this repository, I'll close this issue.
You're more than welcome to keep commenting on it though.

issue_title: MoveIt packages for the tx60 and tx90 series
issue_contents: Are there any guidelines besides
one about how the MoveIt packages for robots in ROS-I should look like?
In
there are already MoveIt packages for the tx160 series available. Should they also be created for the tx90 and tx60 series?
wrote:
Are there any guidelines besides
one about how the MoveIt packages for robots in ROS-I should look like?
No, that is (unfortunately) the only document giving some hints at the moment.
I would recommend to mimic the configuration of the RX160 closely.
In
there are already MoveIt packages for the tx160 series available. Should they also be created for the tx90 and tx60 series?

We could definitely add some for those series as well. The reason we've been hesitant in the past with this is that we don't expect a lot of people to actually reuse MoveIt packages: you would have to either create a new one if you're setting things up for
robot in
robot cell, or start editing the one that is provided by a repository.

If users are creating a new one anyway, it doesn't make much sense for us to create and maintain one here in the repository. Editing could be an option, but if we ever release the MoveIt configurations, they would be located in non-world-writable locations, which makes editing impossible.
issue_quotes: one about how the MoveIt packages for robots in ROS-I should look like?
there are already MoveIt packages for the tx160 series available. Should they also be created for the tx90 and tx60 series?

issue_title: val_3 driver: rough and jerky trajectories
issue_contents: After working a while with
and the
in the
package, I figured that the executed trajectories of the real robot are not running very smoothly. Especially in the end of an executed path the movement is quite chopped.
Did also experience the same thing? Could there be a problem with the driver? Or is there a problem with the
library?
The driver could always play a role (it hasn't been tested
extensively, partly why it is in an experimental repository), but if you're using Kinetic and MoveIt, you may be running into
or related issues.
See
for a possibly related issue, and some links to relevant other issues.
I'm not saying this is the cause of what you're seeing, but it would be good to check this.
One way to see whether Kinetic OMPL is doing strange things is to generate a trajectory in some other way, time-parameterise it yourself and then send it to the driver directly.
Especially in the end of an executed path the movement is quite clipped.
I'm not sure I completely understand what you're describing here. What do you mean with 'clipped'?
I'm not sure I completely understand what you're describing here. What do you mean with 'clipped'?
By clipped I meant very jerky.
Yes
seems to describe exactly  the behaviour of my trajectories. I would guess that the content of the second comment in
could be a reason for the jerky trajectory execution.
Thing is, the time parameterisation code hadn't changed much (at all actually) between Indigo and Kinetic, until
got merged. That seemed to point to
that was interfering here. As you can read further down in
, it would seem that changes to OMPL itself have introduced this. This was reported in

The comment you link to (it's not an answer) suggests that it's mostly the time parameterisation. As I hope is now clear, that could be related, but is most likely not the cause. A strong hint for that is that the reporter of
mentions in the second comment on his own issue that:
I tested the following diff and the jerky trajectories are gone now.
Where "the following diff" undoes some changes to the trajectory generation parts of OMPL itself.

I believe it would make sense to see whether generating a path through some other means and then time parameterising it would immediately make clear whether or not OMPL is affecting this. Alternatively, have an Indigo version of MoveIt generate a trajectory and execute that. If that doesn't exhibit this behaviour, I believe it would point to OMPL again.
It would also be good to check whether configuring MoveIt to use TOTG improves things (
But that is all mentioned in
already.
According to the latest comments on
, the issue with OMPL is now fixed and is going to be backported to Kinetic.
Thank you very much! I will close this Issue now.
When will I be able to update the fix for this Problem? Will it be updatable in the apt-tree or would I have to apply the changes myself with some kind of patch which will be published?
What are the next steps?
The fix first needs to be verified. Then it needs to be backported to Kinetic. MoveIt/OMPL will need a new release, and that will need to be synced to the public repositories.
It could take some time. Building OMPL from source on Kinetic -- and thus MoveIt as well -- will make it available earlier to you.
Note also btw that it's not certain that this is the cause of what you describe. It's a good candidate, but there are no guarantees.
I recommend you keep a close eye on
Have you seen any improvement
with the release of the new MoveIt+OMPL?
To be honest, I have not worked with the robots for about a month. Do I have to compile MoveIt from source or is it already available via apt-get?
I will test it on monday and then present the results.
MoveIt & OMPL on Kinetic should have all the updates. No need for a source build.
Ok. I will test if there is any improvement and then post the results.
One thing to check btw is that the
and
setting for each trajectory point in the driver is set to really low values, so the controller cannot do much blending.
That could also be the cause of some jittering.
See
for another user that experimented a bit with that.
Ideally blending should not be used, but if all else fails, it might be something to look into.
: has this improved at all for you?
I just tested it. And yes it works perfectly fine. Thanks!
I will close the Issue now.

(for which several ROS packages exist).

issue_contents: Hi,
I'd like to create the model for the tx250 (as in

However I am having considerable trouble with the generation of an IKFast solution (which I do need very much). Openrave generates a file for me but I does not appear to yield correct results, basically there are no allowed positions for my robot.
My URDF works well in moveit so I can only assume it is correct.
I have tried compiling openrave from source as well as using the version built in ros kinetic.
One strange thing is that the file generated by ik fast is very long (~20K lines).
Would anybody happen to know what might be going wrong?

Would anybody care to run openrave as it should be quick enough if it's already installed. I am linking a script to run it with my parameters, only the paths inside should be adjusted (github does not like .sh extension).
Best,
I haven't tested anything, but I have the impression that you created the URDF using the SW2URDF plugin for SolidWorks.
That is possible, but you'll have to take extra care when defining the
s for the joints, or the plugin will do a number on the orientations of the axes which leads to very complex math for IKFast (and its generator) to solve.
An example of this can be seen in the xacro snippets for
this has both translations in two dimensions as well as a rotation.
I would suggest to simplify this by fixing the origins of your
s (and updating your meshes) and then trying again.
As this is not an issue with the packages in this repository I'll go ahead and close this.
Feel free to keep commenting on it though.
Thanks for the help.
Your impression is correct. I didn't really think through the fact that those awkward origins would mess things up. I would still expect the correct answer from ikfast though just not as fast.
Anyway I'll give it a shot, thanks.

The math (in the generator) is non-trivial -- take a look at Rosen's PhD thesis. Straightening out the transforms between joints helps in avoiding rounding errors and other causes of numerical instability.

So I straightened up some of the joints in my URDF. This time I got a clean no go from IK fast. Some things are very strange. One of them is that my first version gave 3 triplets of "unaligned joints" whereas the new one appears to have 4.

About the joint referred to earlier, I made some changes but didn't go 'all the way'. Actually there is a pair of 45° joints (4 and 5) making up the wrist of this arm. So there is bound to be more involved joint transforms since they are not colinear.

I'll see if further transformation of the joints can help but I don't expect it will since it will somehow mess up the rotation axes of the joints. I'll also look for an equivalence transform between this configuration and a more standard rx160 like colinear wrist.
Then I'll ask Rosen Diankov if I may bother him.
The TX 250 has a "complex wrist". In my experience IKFast sometimes has difficulties generating solutions for non-spherical wrist setups.
I can only suggest to follow
instead of the one explained in the various MoveIt tutorials. It's worked for me in the past where others failed.
Ignore the "4 dof" aspect of the Q&A and if you already have OpenRAVE installed you obviously don't need to use the Docker image.

issue_title: Driver skips points in between trajectory
issue_contents: The motion control task of the driver
when they match the current configuration.
Isn't there a missing check to ensure this only happens for the first point of a trajectory?
At least, that seems to be the
(which is conceptually the same but also checks

The main reason why this is incorrect imo is that motion point queueing is not the same as motion execution; the driver queues up the move commands onto the robot's internal motion buffer and then continues execution. But if the motion is stalled,

will always return the configuration at the time the point is queued, not at execution. The simplest case that leads to incorrect execution is starting with the robot on the zero-config, with the robot on but the motion button not active (paused motion). Then send a trajectory with 3 points:

. Upon receiving the points, the robot will skip the second point because it matches the configuration and the move that was supposed to involve 3 total moves, will actually do just one move and stop there.
That looks like an incorrect implementation indeed: there's no way to guarantee that
will be called at the right time -- most likely it will be called at the wrong time, as you note.
Could this problem cause the jerky trajectories that were mentioned in

It does cause trajectories to execute weirdly (depending on several factors, of course). We tested generating trajectories in MoveIt and then creating val3 code out of them and that works perfectly, so I would rule out MoveIt/OMPL as the source of jerkiness.
: did you already check whether removing that line improves things?
Should be relatively easy to check, just comment the line.
yes, I confirm. Removing the line indeed fixes the issue.

I can send a PR for it as is (just removing the line), although, I wanted to check first whether it was still meaningful to do this check but move it to the execution loop, so that it actually does what it was intended to do. But I can also send the removal-line PR for now and then send the other if I see it makes sense... What would be preferable from your perspective?

issue_title: Migration of staubli_val3_driver to its own repository
issue_contents: As a consequence of the consensus reached in
, I've extracted
out of this repository and have created a new repository that hosts just the driver. You may find it at
I've tried to retain as much of the commit history as possible (and where it made sense), and have transferred open issues as well.
As this package is largely ROS-agnostic (it essentially hosts a VAL3 application and some launch files), I've only created a
branch.
Commits and file provenance have been retained, and references to issues and PRs have been updated wherever possible.
What remains is to remove
from this repository here.
I don't want to do that unannounced, so this is the announcement -- at least here on the tracker.
Rationale for doing this now (and with this package):
is working on some improvements and will be contributing PRs to fix some of the outstanding issues. As his work is mostly focused on the driver, and the history of
was mostly linear, I decided to extract it
's changes would have to be integrated.
If any of the current users feel it's not a good idea to separate the driver from this repository, you have till 2020-01-23 to comment here and provide some rationale.
On 2020-01-24 I will
from this repository.
Nothing else will change, so previous commits and history of
will be retained here. If you currently have a fork of
with changes to
you will still be able to relate those to the state in this repository (even after the removal of the package).
: I realise this will complicate your work somewhat, as you should fork the new repository and migrate your commits.
Let me know if you'd like me to assist you with this.

Should be no problem. I like the idea of having a separate repo. I won't be able to add any more to my fork until next month (busy time of the year for us), but I can go ahead and migrate my commits and submit a PR.
Submitting a PR would be good, as it would allow us to discuss the approach(es) you've taken.
I would encourage you to do that.
Edit: and just to be extra clear: a PR against the new repository :)
But don't throw away your old fork yet. It may be that there is some community member which has a very strong argument for
migrating the driver to its own repository.
Would it be okay to have all the changes in a single commit, or is it preferred to have each individual change in its own commit?
I would actually prefer to have logical, coherent sets of changes in separate commits. So not necessarily individual changes, but also not everything in one large one.
That would facilitate both review as well as management of changes.

A good heuristic I sometimes use is to keep a working system in mind and think about how a set of changes would affect it: one way to then structure commits would be to keep the system in a working state at all times (fi: introduce a new feature/function in one commit and then start using it in a follow-up one).  This is of course not always possible and neither does it always make sense, but it does work quite well for certain kinds of changes.
Another guideline would be to never move
edit files (ie: their content) in the same commit. It becomes impossible to revert the move and/or the content changes separately.
There are more, but it's rather off-topic for this issue.
Edit: appreciate you asking btw.
Awesome, I will submit the PR tomorrow once I have everything migrated.

Sometimes, the target angles will drift outside of the acceptable range. This causes erratic behavior in the mapper.
NOTE: Azi-Drive
command the boat with these angles, as it realizes in the control loop that these are out of bounds.
Lines that should be stopping this:
Is this fixed?
Azi drive is auto-clipping incoming wrench commands to avoid impossible commands.
When the vehicle is commanded with too large a wrench, azi-drive does not converge, and the existing azi-drive codebase does not handle this well.
This is half-solved, in the sense that the clipping will prevent a convergence problem in 99% of cases (Exceptions in the angle-ranging problem).
Lines causing this:
I won't have time to fix this until June.
Possible fixes:
Is this fixed? Would it be better to scale all values equally to maintain the direction of the force vector? Clipping would change the direction of the force vector which is bad for the controller.

issue_title: Make sure thrust is always zeroed in all circumstances
issue_contents: I believe if the thruster_config.py node is shut down it does not zero the motors
One idea is to use services for setting thrust instead of a message stream. Services calls are still guaranteed to complete during a node's shutdown,
. Same is true in ROScpp afaik.
Azi Drive does this using a
node which provides a shutdown service. When you kill AD, it
and kills thrust using that service.
My thinking is to handle this natively inside of the thruster driver; because if the AD control manager crashes along with AD, then we are SOL.

So the control manager has to be killed after azi drive so they can't be in the same launch file? Otherwise the control manager could be killed before AD which would cause it not to stop the thrusters. Maybe you should make the control manager call stop_boat_service on shutdown... Except that uses msgs which are not guaranteed to be sent... hmm.

Well, we can work from lowest level up. Making sure that if anything in the chain breaks anything below it should be zeroed. But that would require a service at each level to make it safe, which is doable but seems like there is a better way. I guess I'll go through and convert all msg in the actuator chain into srvs instead.
P.S. ROScpp is the same but there is no shutdown hook you have to do it manually (not to bad though).
Yes, they control_manager and the rest of azi-drive cannot be in the same
launch file. However, services are guaranteed to be sent, so if mission
critical actions (thrust, servo angles) are set by service, then we can
change them in shutdown hooks. We just can't rely on messages.
Maybe adding timeouts to the motor controller is a good idea - "If I don't
receive a thrusterNewton command at least every 5 seconds, I will shut down
the motors"
On Thu, May 14, 2015 at 3:07 PM, fnivek
wrote:
So the control manager has to be killed after azi drive so they can't be
in the same launch file? Otherwise the control manager could be killed
before AD which would cause it not to stop the thrusters. Maybe you should
make the control manager call stop_boat_service on shutdown... Except that
uses msgs which are not guaranteed to be sent... hmm.
Well, we can work from lowest level up. Making sure that if anything in
the chain breaks anything below it should be zeroed. But that would require
a service at each level to make it safe, which is doable but seems like
there is a better way. I guess I'll go through and convert all msg in the
actuator chain into srvs instead.
P.S. ROScpp is the same but there is no shutdown hook you have to do it
manually (not to bad though).
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
Jacob Panikulam | (630) - 877 - 7665
Machine Intelligence Lab
Github
| About Me
I have an idea. The lowest level actuator control nodes should stop there actuators on shutdown and when a kill is issued from the global
. Each node that updates actuators (including the lowest level nodes) (i.e.
or
)must send a kill to the kill service on shutdown.

This method stops the actuators anytime the low level controllers are shutdown. Any time any node sends a Kill the actuators will stop. There is still an issue when the kill node gets stopped before any node that uses the global kill is shutdown. This could be solved a few different ways;
Using services in the lowest level control nodes that the kill node would tell to stop when it is shutdown,
by ensuring the kill node is always the first node to start and the last node to be shutdown,
or use the kill node as a heart beat, the low level nodes would have to receive not killed msgs from the kill node otherwise after some timeout they should stop there actuators.
I'm going to investigate the final solution of the above three first.
About done with the upgrade! I'm updating the kill_handling to have the heartbeat built in. I'll have a readme of how to use it shortly.
That was a lot of work but its done! See the
for the proper procedure to use actuators.

contents_details_more: If it's drifting to the left when the visualizer thinks it is going straight, I
that is because the left and right thrusters are generating different thrust for the same value.

If it is spinning when it supposed to be strafing, it is likely because the center of mass is offset from the geometric center of the boat, and Azi should (but doesn't) account for that. The simulator uses the geometric center, not the real COM.

issue_title: Path planning breaks when the boat is directly downwind from the waypoint
issue_contents: The navigator tries to go for the longest first tack, which puts it downwind from the waypoint at one point on its path. Whenever the boat is directly downwind, the longest tack rapidly alternates between the two laylines, and the boat oscilates
Further analysis confirms that this is due to the apparent wind heading changing as the boat's speed changes

issue_title: Simulator dies after hours of use
issue_contents: During the demo the simulator froze up after a couple of hours and all the data overflowed and displayed very high numbers.  Likely some kind of overflow.
Resolved by adding distance limits and limiting sim speed for now.
Main issue lies with the dt getting too high, and then that brings acc and drag to really high numbers making speed super high.  Only happens at really fast sim speeds because
So new slider is limited to 1000%.

Make sure we don't tack back to back.  Either base this off of distance or time.  Note that basing it off of time will mean the simulator will only show accurate tacking if the speed is at 100% not 1000%.

If a tack fails/ or is preempted because it takes too long, the boat should bare off from the wind to get it speed back up before trying to tack again.  Currently it will just run that exact same loop again, but trying to tack with no momentum will always fail.

issue_title: unpausing in the simulator resets time scale to 1000% regardless of what it was before.
Boat only tacks when the current boat vmg goes negative
issue_contents: Especially noticeable when sailing a beam reach to beam reach course, the boat will gybe instead of tack.  This is now noticeable because the when the direct heading no longer lies in our current tack, then the

is set to the point in our tack closest to the next tack.  Previously this updated immediately after to the other side of the boat (which causes a tack without actually calling the tacking action).  This was fixed in commit

by making sure to navigate to a set heading before setting the next heading so we don't skip a gybe and tack without calling the tacking action.  It is now noticeable that the boat gybes instead of tacking because the line
is never true (because
is > 80) until
is negative which will never happen on a beam reach course (only happens on extremes of an upwind course).  This should be corrected so that
is never 80 but is a reasonable number determined properly based on course width. The boat shouldn't be restricted to tacking only when the speed on the other tack is 80 or so times greater.
has been changed to rely on beating parameter and start distance to target.  The beating parameter

is read from the parameter server and doesn't define a hard maximum for the width of the upwind course.  The boat will usually not go beyond the width specified, but if the course length is significantly longer than the beating parameter (>5 times) then the boat may travel slightly past the beating parameter's width.  In all cases the boat may travel less than the beating parameter if deemed optimal.

issue_title: Resizing windows vertically breaks buoy placement

issue_title: Does wpi_jaco support the mico arm?
issue_contents: The wpi_jaco package in ROS indigo servers as an alternative to jaco-ros. I want to know if this package supports the mico arm? Thank you!

The package isn't written directly to support the mico arm, but the APIs for the jaco and mico are very similar, so much of the package should work with the mico.  There would need to be a few small changes, such as using a urdf of the mico instead of the jaco in jaco_description, and units would need to be changed in a few places throughout the package since the mico api takes positions in mm instead of m.
Is there a moveit config available for this package?
I have created one by myself but I would be very interested in a proper joint_limits.yaml.

We don't have any sort of official moveit config for this package.  I'd recommend sticking with your own, as the config I've been using is somewhat experimental.  You can also check with the kinovarobotics jaco repository, but I don't believe they're working with moveit.

issue_contents: Form time to time I get the following error message when I execute a trajectory generated by moveit:

That can happen if the trajecoty points form too sharp of a corner for the trajectory generator to fit a smooth curve to.  This can be prevented by adjusting a max_curvature parameter.  I just updated the code to expose this parameter in the launch file, so that it can be set when launching the node.  It's tuned experimentally; I increased it a bit and it's working consistently on our arm, but if you still get this exception, try increasing the max_curvature parameter.

issue_contents: I tried using your package with the 4.3.0001, 5.0.3 and 5.0.5 firmware installed on our arm.
Can you confirm that you are using the JACO_5.0.5.33.hex on you arm?

My problem is that after I moved the arm via the velocity controller. I can't close the gripper via a angual_cmd. I did some debugging and found out that the controller works as expected and sends the trajectory to the API but the arm doesn't react.

Yeah, we're using version 5.0.5.0033.  I've actually seen this problem with the gripper happen before.  I assumed it had to do with switching control modes.  When you switch between angular control and Cartesian control, the arm won't move if you're near a singularity, and this includes the gripper.  There may be another cause, since the velocity controller uses only angular control as well, so there shouldn't be a mode switch.  I've seen the same thing as you, though, where the command goes through but the arm doesn't respond.
Does this happen often with your gripper?  It happened rarely on our arm, and it hasn't done it in a while.
I switched to velocity control of the gripper (via angual_cmd) this works so far.
I have fixed the gripper problem by using velocity control to move the
gripper instead of position control.
But the latest API seems to have some problems related to control mode
changes. (And also API control mode, but this is another problem) I use
your teleop node with a 3d mouse and it works quite well but just until I
execute a path via moveit using the velocity control method. Then teleop
completely stops working. I tried restarting all nodes and change to
cartesian mode, but teleop only works again after switching the arm off and
on again.
Yeah, we're using version 5.0.5.0033. I've actually seen this problem with
the gripper happen before. I assumed it had to do with switching control
modes. When you switch between angular control and Cartesian control, the
arm won't move if you're near a singularity, and this includes the gripper.
There may be another cause, though, since the velocity controller uses only
angular control as well, so there shouldn't be a mode switch. Does this
happen often with your gripper? It happened rarely on our arm, and it
hasn't done it in a while.
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub

I've talked to Kinova about this, and that's the intended functionality with the current api.  This happens because the arm has moved into a singularity protection zone using angular control (i.e. what the velocity controller is using), and so a switch to Cartesian control (what the teleop is using) will not work.  This preserves the arm's singularity avoidance behavior.  The singularity protection zones are near the joint limits of the non-continuous joints, near the arm's full extension, a cylinder around the base that the end-effector and wrist joint can't move into, and a few other constraints between the middle joints that I'd need to look up.

The problem is that this covers a significant amount of the arm's workspace, and using angular control can easily move it into one of these zones.  Cartesian control will work if you move the arm outside of these protection zones with the velocity controller, but it's difficult to determine if it will work or not without trying it.  You can still use angular control, and you can also get Cartesian control back by running the arm's home command.

This has been a big problem for us as well, and so I'd like to write my own cartesian controller using the API's angular control to get around this problem.  I have some other things to work on first, though, but it is on my todo list!

issue_title: Control only fingers with angular/cartesian command
issue_contents: The angular/cartesian command does not work for only the fingers:
I have used the topic jaco_arm/angular_cmd (or jaco_arm/cartesian_cmd,
they have the same issue) to send a angular command to just the fingers
to move the gripper. As an example, I had sent the following command via
the terminal:
The fingers did not move at all for any value I had put in. When I
switched armCommand to true (the joint values are the current joint
values of the arm), the fingers did open.

It looks like the API only allows finger position commands to be sent if an arm position command is sent with it.  Previously if you were sending only a finger command the callback would automatically fill in a 0 joint velocity command, but the API will only accept a position finger command if a position arm command is set.  For now I changed it so that if you don't specify an arm joint command and you're trying to send a finger position command, it will automatically fill in the current arm positions to send in the API command.

There's some error in the joint position accuracy (at least in our arm), so the arm jerks a bit when you send only a finger position command.  The velocity command works fine, however, as sending a 0 velocity with finger velocities gives the desired behavior.  I think a better solution would be to write a PID controller that will use finger velocity commands to reach a desired finger position, so that the arm can be held in place with a 0 velocity command instead of the current position command.  I'll look into that in the near future!
I implemented the PID controller instead, now it works pretty nicely!
Also my tests show nice results!

issue_title: Gripper action returns result instantly (and incorrect)
issue_contents: I have used the actionlib jaco_arm/fingers_controller/gripper to send a goal to the gripper. What I saw was that I received a result instantly when sending the goal.
The result also contains the current width of the gripper and not the end width of the gripper (I think because the result is returned immediately).
Next to that, I also received (reach_goal = true) when sending the gripper to an unreachable goal (say value 200).
The gripper should send the result only when the gripper has reached (or cannot reach) its goal.

.  You can try these as well, but if I remember correctly they were breaking something with our driver... I can't confirm this at the moment though, and I'm wary of making changes to the repository here because I currently don't have access to a JACO for testing.

issue_contents: Hi,
I've made a moveit config for our Kinova Mico, based on wpi_jaco. It works far better than other repositories btw.
Now I've come across this problem:

When I use /mico_arm/fingers_controller/gripper as GripperCommand, it won't execute grasp movements corrently. I think this is based on the fact that the action-goal accept values from 0.0 to ~7000.0 for open and closed finger position, while joint_states are published in radians from ~0.0 to ~1.0.
So when moveit tries to close both fingers, Mico goes to fully open position, since for /mico_arm/fingers_controller/gripper/goal the value 1.0 means open, in whatever unit that is.

I haven't used MoveIt! to control the gripper, but what you're saying makes sense if MoveIt! controls the gripper based on the joint_state position.  If that's the case I can make a moveit-friendly gripper controller that converts a joint state position goal into the units that the Kinova API uses.
Do you have the exact value that moveit's sending for a close command?  It's hard for me to test because I only have a Jaco, but aside from the scale the principle should be the same.
Alright! That would be amazing.
I manually sent positions to the GripperCommand using axclient.py. Then I read the /joint_states topic and made a small table:
| Request   | Measured Joint State  | Ratio
It's hard to tell the exact mutliplicator, but I'd say the GripperCommand's position must be about 6900 times bigger than the joint_state's radian.

Alright, update to the latest code in the develop branch and give it a try.  Just have your MoveIt! config use /mico_arm/fingers_controller_radian/gripper as the gripper action server instead.  It might not be tuned exactly right, but it works for my gripper open/close values on the Jaco.  Let me know how it works for you!
Great job! It works fine.
Thanks for the support
Hi,
when launching arm.launch, the jaco_arm_trajectory_node is started and it calls the home-service.
This might not be a common problem, but when Mico is build on top of our robot, homing can cause dangerous collisions.
Is it possible to initialize without homing? Or can I make homing somehow optional, without modifying too much of your code?

Unfortunately, homing is part of kinova's startup procedure for the arm (calibration probably).  You could check with Kinova about alternatives, or if you can set a different home position, but in my experience it has a required, preset home position.
Hi,

I would like to comment on this issue. I have had extended conversations with the ROS support of Kinova and I have been told that homing is not required anymore with the latest firmware. Hence, you can disable it in the software if needed.

I have also had some problems with the switching between angular and cartesian control. It seems that the Kinova API sometimes deadlocks - or stays in the angular control - even when trying to switch it back to cartesian control. For us, this could only be solved by homing, but this is another issue which should be fixed sometime in the future.
For this latest issue, someone should contact ROS support of Kinova. This can be done via
Oh, that's good to hear!  I'll add a flag to the launch file to make homing optional.  We've had safety issues with the home as well, so I'd like to bypass it.
Parameter's added, the arm will still home on initialization by default, but if you don't want it to then launch the arm with:
roslaunch wpi_jaco_wrapper arm.launch home_arm_on_init:=false

Maybe this is a pure MoveIt related problem, but we noticed that when using a node that uses moveit::planning_interface::MoveGroup, the jaco_arm/cartesian_cmd  won't work anymore, while jaco_arm/angular_cmd works fine.
Most solutions we found suggested using asyncspinners, but that didn't solve it.
Sorry if this is only MoveIt related, but we are trying to eliminate all sources of error, while having much time pressure.
In that case, just  close or remove this topic.
today we suffered the same problem, after using jaco_arm/angular_cmd for a couple of times, while no MoveIt was running.
We noticed that we can restart jaco_arm_trajectory_node to reanable cartesian control, eventhough MoveIt runs in parallel.
Sadly this strategy doesn't work, when homing is disabled.
Hi,
same problem here...

We are using a Mico arm + MoveIt! (mico_arm/angular_cmd) and a joypad control mode (mico_arm/cartesian_cmd). After a movement via MoveIt! (over mico_arm/angular_cmd) the cartesian topic is sometimes blocked/ignored and sometimes not. As far as I know, this depends on the current pose/joint configuration of the robot. The topic is always blocked in some poses and in other its always working ... maybe because the arm is moved into a configuration, which can't be reached via cartesian movement and further cartesian movement is therefore blocked (out of bounds?!)
Furthermore this seems not to be a problem of the wpi_jaco package, because the original
declares the following limitation:
After using angular control, the arm may not respond to Cartesian commands (e.g., arm_pose or figer_position) until the arm has been homed.
So it seems to be a Kinova Software Bug/Limitation and can't be fixed unfortunately...

Yeah, as far as I've been able to figure out, this is a problem with Kinova's API.  Both this package and the kinova-ros packages use the same API to communicate with the arm at a low level.  The arm has defined zones to avoid due to singularities while it's operating in Cartesian control mode.  They are reachable with angular control, however, and the arm won't respond if you move into one of these spaces and switch to Cartesian control.  Homing the arm will fix this, as it moves the arm back into a valid pose.

It's also possible to use angular control to move to another non-singularity pose and resume Cartesian control.  I'm not sure how to detect what poses are safe for Cartesian control.  We try to do as much with angular control as possible to avoid this problem (you can also use MoveIt! to plan cartesian trajectories, and execute them as angular trajectories on the arm).  Unfortunately I'm not sure if there's a solution.  I see it as a limitation, as you suggest.
issue_quotes: After using angular control, the arm may not respond to Cartesian commands (e.g., arm_pose or figer_position) until the arm has been homed.

Hello Kural,

The wpi_jaco_wrapper package has a trajectory follower set up as a ROS actionlib server.  You're attempting to call an actionlib callback method directly in your C++ code, which will not work.  You instead need to create an actionlib client that connects to the trajectory actionlib server that you want to use.  For detailed instructions on how to do this, check out the actionlib page of the ROS wiki, which also has a complete set of tutorials:
#include
#include<stdlib.h>
#include
#include<string.h>
#include
#include<time.h>
#include
#include<ros/ros.h>
#include "control_msgs/FollowJointTrajectoryGoal.h"
#include "/opt/ros/hydro/include/trajectory_msgs/JointTrajectoryPoint.h"
#include "/opt/ros/hydro/include/trajectory_msgs/JointTrajectory.h"
#include </home/administrator/catkin_ws/src/wpi_jaco/wpi_jaco_wrapper/include/wpi_jaco_wrapper/jaco_arm_trajectory_node.h>
#include <actionlib/client/simple_action_client.h>
using namespace std;
typedef actionlib::SimpleActionClientJacoArmTrajectoryController::execute_smooth_trajectory TrajClient;
void letswait(int);
int main(int argc, char **argv)
void letswait(int secs){
clock_t end;
end=clock()+secs*CLOCKS_PER_SEC;
while(clock()<end);
I have tried to call the function through the actionlib client. I have initialized the client and connected to the server but I am not able to call the function. Please help.
Thanking You
KURAL
You need to send the goal through the connected action client, rather than calling the function.  I recommend going through and running at least the beginner tutorials here
before you try to use actionlib.

For the sound quality, the issue could come from the conversions from the buffer to numpy or from the type of data we use in all the conversions.
Is the full code slow or just when handling utterances?
A few things to check:
– The line
forces a conversion of the numpy array with int type to float and then back to int. It could lead to the quality issue by scaling the sound too much (you could print the value of

to check if it's not too large) or to the speed issue because of the conversion (in which case we could cast the multiplier into an integer). However, quality-wise, this should not be different from the previous behavior that was using integers to represent the data.
– Maybe the
function could be replaced by
– Double check that the right sample rate is used on read and write.
– Can you upload a file with quality issues?

What does "TWE" means in the end of the name "ATIForceTorqueSensorTWE"?
What does "TWE" means in the end of the name "ATIForceTorqueSensorTWE"?
TWE is a shortened word of Transducer Without Electronics and the name of a version of ATI FT sensors.
This means that the sensor was provided without any electronic devices such as DAQ.

issue_title: [Feature Request] Manually upload parameter object content to parameter server
issue_contents: This is kind of a follow-up idea to the already implemented "Set default values on parameter server if no value is set" request,
I would like to manually upload the current parameters of the parameter object to the server at any time.

This is meant to enable me to save multiple "sessions" of my project in multiple parameter instances at a time. (like having a list of parameter objects and "re-loading" one of them as the one being currently worked on)
Thanks in advance! :)
Hi, thanks for the idea.
Would a simple params.setOnServer() be enough for your use case?
Yes it would! Thanks for dealing with my issue!
