issue_contents: Since
, there are many updates.
Thanks!
Hi, thanks for the interest.
First of all please notice that the project just got a new maintainer (myself) as
is now quite busy.
There have been many updates and yet more to come (e.g.
). I would like to get those two PR through before releasing a new version (maybe 1.0.0).
Hi,
unlike what I've said in my previous message, I'm now planning on releasing the current state of the
branch (at
It is preferable to do a release considering all changes that were made since 0.1.1 (Unit testing, Python support etc...), and the further refactoring brought by
The release of version 0.1.2 is thus pending on
Release 0.1.2 is pending due to a
issue ...
See this post
The release process went through yesterday ! In a few days the package should be in the main repo.
Follow its status
With the release of version 0.1.2. this week, I get errors for all parameters listed in a .params file when launching my stack.
Location:
Hi, please could you provide a little more information as what is your error ? Could it be a namespace issue ?
Error: "Parameter 'foo/bar' is not defined." Whereas "foo" is my node and "bar" is my parameter I define according to your specs within the .params file.
I don't think this is a namespace issue. I didn't change anything despite switching to the shortly released new rosparam_handler version.

utilities.hpp is currently installed to /include/rosparam_handler/rosparam_handler/utilities.hpp -- note the double occurence of "rosparam_handler" in the path. This leads to failures when including it in generated parameter configuration files.

This problem does not occur when you do not have an "install" directory in your workspace, which may explain why it is commonly missed. However, it is unfortunately also present in the currently distributed version of the rosparam_handler package!

I surmise the cause of the problem is that because dynamic_reconfigure already creates the target directory, and thus the subsequence copy-step accidentally copies the whole directory instead of its contents.
A quick fix is to replace the "DIRECTORY" form of the install directive with the "FILES" form.  See the following patch. Since you only have one header, it should be fine.
Hi, thanks for reporting the issue. It is already fixed in PR
that is about to be merged
FYI,
has been merged, I'm waiting for
to be merged as well before releasing 0.1.3 which will fix this issue.
Release 0.1.3 containing the installation fix
is under release process. In a week roughly it should be available from the ros repo.
issue_code:
diff --git a/CMakeLists.txt b/CMakeLists.txt
index a0d0437..d10ecfb 100644
--- a/CMakeLists.txt
+++ b/CMakeLists.txt
@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@ install(
 )
 
 install(
-        DIRECTORY include/rosparam_handler/
+        FILES include/rosparam_handler/utilities.hpp
         DESTINATION ${CATKIN_PACKAGE_INCLUDE_DESTINATION}
 )

issue_title: Planning does not end forever on solving complex problems
issue_contents: Although the process to send a query to a solver is implemented as an action, most clients wait for results from a server.
Especially, the
planner displays intermediate logs at a very high rate, which hangs terminal app and decrease storage access performance.

issue_title: ReflexUSBHand consturctor breaks global/relative namespace scoping
issue_contents: in
sets the namespace to hand type as opposed to
in the  older 'reflex_sf_hand.py' where it would set the anem to given launch arg.

This version predefines the namespace as the type and still uses it for functionality defined by type, thus limiting the configuration options. Also, the preceding slash forces looking into root instead of a given namespace. Most critically, the node looks at  /<< handtype >> for params instead of the user-given name of the hand.
Addressed here:
issue_code:
'class ReflexUSBHand(ReflexHand):
    def __init__(self):
        self.usb_hand_type = rospy.get_param('usb_hand_type')  
        self.init_namespace = '/' + self.usb_hand_type

If you want to use the ROS driver I linked above, we need a UART-USB converter. They are cheap, and there's one in my room that we can use, but we should tell Electrical if we are changing their layout.

issue_title: gui: unresponsive for multiple subscriber and publisher
issue_contents: running
roslaunch arni_core test_1_3x3_steady.launch
(will start 3 subscriber and 3 publisher to /forest (with ~300Hz combined))
rqt
and then starting arni-details.
trying to klick anything in arni-details is quite slow.
Grommetox and PRGfx experience no unresponsivenes, so it seems to be a local problem. No idea what it causes though.

The massive use of timers for the updating of the gui together with a lot of logic to keep the model running even on systems with a large number of nodes/lots of data can lead to performance problems on weaker plattforms (depends on the strength of a single core). Currently not resolvable.

issue_title: Build failing when following the instructions in readme
issue_contents: I tried to build the repo using the instructions in the readme file, but the build is failing with the following error:
I think the bug is reproducible in which case we should fix it so that the newcomers don't get stuck.
Fixed that. Try now.
The previous error is fixed with
, but there is a new error:
can you look into this??
might have fixed it. Check now.
The previous one's fixed, there's a new one:
How come you guys are able to work on this when there's so many bugs in the code?

Actually these errors occur only during a fresh build. These are headers which are generated when building the code. So, it depends upon the system whether the headers will be generated before the node or after. In your case it is the later one. Since there are a very few people working with the present code so we know work around these problems.

Try to mitigate all these bugs so that 1. Newcomers don't get stuck or overwhelmed by all the errors and 2. If you are not present, people who don't know the workarounds end up wasting a lot of time figuring those out.
It is working perfectly now, I'll see if I can fix the Travis issue

issue_contents: This (extremely rare and seemingly random) error occurs during normal running:

My current hypothesis is that one of the dimensions of ss_img is going to zero length, but based on the way things were when this happened, I'm not sure why that'd be the case. I am going to surround that block with a try-except so we can get a look at ss_img (and every argument of that floodFill) if this ever happens again.
There I was minding my own business driving around and all of a sudden this happened to me!
<< Could this be an issue?
I set the waypoint towards the bottom left corner of this grid. It had started rotating then after a second or two it gave the error and terminated the move.
Also, in
I'm encountering the same issue (with it's floodFill)
Yes, as suspected the problem is that somehow ss_img is getting one dimension of length zero. Based on the 0's in push's y-components, I think I know exactly why this is happening. Will fix soon.

The current fix just picks some basic sample space (unadvised by the ogrid geometry, like the old days) when we get into the special (and rare) degenerate case. I haven't been able to recreate the degenerate case since implementing this fix, so it may not work as intended, and thus this issue will not close yet. Please report here if the print statement tells you to.

It seems that there are multiple causes of the degenerate case. One we know for sure is being too close to the edge of the ogrid. Regardless, the resulting failure is the same in every case, so we have protected against it by catching the degenerate ss_img and reverting to the old style ogrid analysis as needed.

issue_contents: Hi if i want to fly multiple drone through this set up what and where should I start ? Can you guide me ?
Hi there, flying multiple drones is much more complex (fleet management) than one.
I would propose you FKIE_multimaster to run multiple interconnected ROS masters across the network and using the task system to actually control them.
Never forget that you have a 6D flying object; Never put "blocking tasks" or else it will crash. You always need to send setpoints.
Any update?
yeh it's possible two way either using through reverse vpn client on drone which connect drone to cloud or server. other one is blockchain but 2 one is complicated now stage
Easiest is VPN (zerotier/OpenVPN) + fkie_multimaster/rocon.

issue_title: Should allocator keep publishing if the messages doesn't change?
issue_contents: If the allocator receives multiple identical
messages in a row, it currently only publishes
only for the first of the identical messages.
See

Line 81
      in
I don't think this is the desired behaviour. It was probably done at some point for performance reasons, but I suggest removing this feature so that one message in always causes one message out.

Actually I think the reason was that out manipulator code was very CPU heavy, and we usually used the manipulators only when not using the thrusters, so this feature would avoid taking resources away from the manipulators.
This makes sense for safety reasons as well, currently if the stop message is dropped then the thrusters will keep running.
Exactly.

issue_title: Setpoint issue / ROV "loose" depthhold in multiple axis controls
issue_contents: The controller node should not call
in headingHold and depthHold when they are not active.
This is a problem when the different controllers is combined; like in depth and heading hold control mode.
The controllers should only be able to change the setpoint of the state they are regulating. Eg. depthHold should only be able to change the heave setpoint.
Fixing this fixes the ROV "floating" away from its depth hold setpoint when we are changing the yaw state with control command from joystick.

I wanted to edit some poses because I was too close to the target.

Ah now I understand you.
I think this is unfortunately something that isn't really 'fixable': the Fanuc TP will show you the angle J3 is making
. ROS however will always want the angle J3 is making wrt J2. This cannot include the J2/J3 interaction, as then it's essentially the angle J3 makes wrt the
frame, not wrt J2. So the driver removes the contribution due to the interaction when broadcasting joint states, and adds it when sending
s to the controller.
As you found out, converting joint angles you get from the TP into radians then doesn't work, or at least not without taking the J2/J3 interaction into account.
I just made the small calculation (addition) to the joint values and everything works well now
I may have misunderstood your comment earlier: I thought you compensated for J2-J3 in
. I now believe you did the math and then adjusted the values in the
array in the yaml. Is that correct? If so, then that is acceptable / the correct approach.

yaml array by doing the math.

page about this.

issue_title: Can't move robot using IKFast for fanuc_lrmate200id
issue_contents: I'm opening moveit setup with
roslaunch moveit_setup_assistant setup_assistant.launch

and clicking edit existing package. I load fanuc_lrmate200id_moveit_config. Then I click Planning Groups, then manipulator, then edit selected, and choose fanuc_lrmate200id_manipulator_kinematics/IKFastKinematicsPlugin for the Kinematic Solver. I then press Save, go to Configuration Files, and hit Generate Package. I run catkin_make, and open RViz with
roslaunch fanuc_lrmate200id_moveit_config demo.launch

which results in the robot being loaded on my screen normally, but I can't move it by clicking it or by running code to move it. Using KDLKinematicsPlugin works fine for me, but I would like to use IKFast
Can you tell me why you edit the MoveIt configuration? The IKFast plugin is generated code, and cannot be used with anything but the original chain that it was generated for.
Please see
for a (probably) related ROS Answers Q&A.

I edited the configuration to add a tool to the end of the robot. I made a link_7 and a joint_7. Joint_7 is connected via link_6 and link_7. Then I connected link_7 to tool0. To keep the baselink->tool0 rule, should I instead connect tool0-link7 for joint_7? Thanks for the help
No, I'm afraid you can't change the
chain, or the IKFast plugin won't work any more.
I would also not recommend to introduce a
or a
, as it seems like something that can become confusing (seeing as all the links and joints in the robot model are named in that fashion).
If you need a toolframe, I recommend making it a child of the
frame that was recently added to all models (
). Don't change

, as it's not meant to be changed. To plan for your new toolframe, you could either see whether you could configure it as a new end effector in the MoveIt configuration, or you could just transform any pose target you want to plan for back to
first - if you want to stick with the IKFast plugin.
Using any other plugin for the new chain that you would define would probably be easier.
Edit: the various tutorials and wiki pages do tell you to make new tool frames children of
, but we're moving away from that, and the introduction of the
frames is the first step. See also
Also: if you haven't already: I would recommend to create a new xacro macro to add the tool frame joint and link, instead of editing

and add it there directly. That would cleanly compose things and keep the separation of concerns, while also making it easier for you to keep track of updates/changes upstream (ie: in this repository).

I cloned the latest version of fanuc_experimental to get the flange updates. So, just to be clear, I should make a new link for my tool, then make a new joint with the parent link as flange and the child link as my tool? If so, thanks for the help!
wrote:
I should make a new link for my tool, then make a new joint with the parent link as flange and the child link as my tool?
yes, you could do that yes.
But make sure to give your tool frame the correct orientation:
follows ROS conventions, so x+ is forward. Tools on Fanucs have z+ forward, which requires the
rotations that the
joint has.
And note that you still cannot use the IKFast plugin with your new tool, unless you setup MoveIt properly
manually transform poses for your new tool back to
(which is possible, as there is a
transform via
available).

issue_contents: I'm having connection issues while connecting my laptop running ROS/MoveIt to the physical robot to run movement commands. I'm not sure whether I've configured something wrong or there is a network issue. Attempts to connect to the physical robot only go through about 1/3 of the time, and there's a small chance I'll get disconnected while running my movement commands. Sometimes the robot seems to connect, and RViz will update to match the physical robot's position, but move commands don't reach the robot. Other times, the connection isn't made at all.
Here's the output from the teach pendant, I'm not sure how useful this is:
I also occasionally get this error in my console
This definitely looks like a network issue.
Are you using a wireless connection by any chance? If so, try with a wired one.
PS: could I ask you to open issues about
pkgs over at
's issue tracker btw? I try to keep things centralised, and this repo is just for storage of packages.
We can keep this one open for now, but please keep it in mind next time.
Thanks.
I tried switching to a wired connection, it results in the same issues. Might it better to talk to my network managers about this? Sorry, I didn't realize that belonged in the fanuc issues

Assuming that the software has not changed, it would seem likely that this is a network issue. If possible, try different network cables (both between you and the network, and between the controller and the network), or even a direct connection (also with different cables).
From the errors on the TP, it looks like connections are dropping (
and
are
and
and
respectively). The error on your terminal also suggests this.
I typically see these when cables have gone bad or there is intermittent network connectivity because of some other reason.
Check that the ROS nodes involved aren't repeatedly shutting down and coming back up.
If that is not the case, I'd look at the hardware side of things (ie: your network).
I'll try a direct connection between by laptop and the robot, my cable is definitely good. If that works, I'll assume its a network issue and talk to the network managers. Thanks!

issue_title: Collision meshes of LR 200id too restrictive.
issue_contents: The current collision meshes of the LR mate 200id are too restrictive.
In particular, I'm talking about the mesh for link2.
Link 2 is supposed to have a bigger opening such that link 4 is partly inside of the current link 2 collision mesh (example of such a joint configuration in radians: [0, 0.3, -1, 0, 1.3, 0]).
Take a look at
, which is basically the same problem, but for KUKA Agilus KR6 and KR10.
See
for a PR that addressed that issue.
You could probably improve the collision mesh for
using the
tool mentioned in the PR.

: did your collision meshes work better?

Yes it did, but I am hesitant to make a PR because it might be too lax (or the robot I am working with isn't mastered very accurate). The only replacement I needed in collision mesh was as you suggested link_2.

Are you using any particular setup? Just the plain
robot in empty space? Something else?

Some observations I’ve made:
When I use RViz to motion plan and I select random valid, it gives me invalid poses all the time and it gives me the same warning and errors, just not quite as many.

I removed the table and now the random valid seems to work. How can I add the table without affecting the collision awareness of the robot?
Did you re-run the MoveIt Setup Assistant after adding the new geometry? If you didn't, the allowed collision matrix would not be updated.

I can see if I can reproduce your issue later today, but that may take while. In general I have the idea that something is out of sync or not updated properly and then leads to MoveIt/OMPL not being correctly setup, leading to your issues.
re: code vs rviz plugin difference: that is really hard to answer without seeing your code. There are so many things that influence MoveIt motion plan requests.
But in general my advice would still be to create a separate work cell xacro macro,
the robot macro file, instantiate it and add the table there. Consider the robot xacro as read-only.
You also cannot change the kinematic chain, or you'll run into things like
. That is a consequence of how IKFast plugins work.

Ok, good to hear that got cleared up.
I'm closing this for now, as I don't expect the fact that you're going to use a real robot is going to influence things very much.
If you encounter the same issue, please re-open.

Thanks for your help, I just tested it out on the actual robot and everything seems resolved. I do have one more question, I have turned the speed all the way up on the robot to 100% via the Karel variables. Is there something else I can do/check to increase the speed? Also does the kinematics solver or the planner increase the velocity of the planned path?
Is there something else I can do/check to increase the speed?

No, most likely not. Fanuc robots are extremely limited in the ways they can be controlled externally, and the driver uses one particular approach that does not result in very good motion performance. You could see whether
performs any better for you (if you're not already using it), but I don't expect it.
may be of interest, but is not a full ROS-I driver at the moment.
Also does the kinematics solver or the planner increase the velocity of the planned path?
I don't understand this.

Another thing to keep in mind is that industrial controllers don't do very well with dense trajectories. That is also true when executing motions using hard-coded, off-line generated programs (ie: TP programs for Fanuc).
Sparser trajectories generally work better and will result in faster motion.
Everything is working fine, thank you for your help!

issue_title: What is the precision for control of end effector ?
issue_contents: Hi,
This is more a question than an issue,
when I set a goal pose for end-effector, the robot  cannot be at the goal in precision manufacturer promises. For instance in below picture;
I set goal pose for end effector as ;
However the end effector ends up at ;
is this expected behavior? if not what could be possible reasons for this behavior ?
According to manufacturer's claim the precision is 3 decimals.
Sorry,  not really related to this repository, I tested robot with a simple TP program even in there robot seems to suffer to be precise on 3 decimals
According to manufacturer's claim the precision is 3 decimals.
There are many factors that affect the behaviour and performance of the robot here, two of which I would like to draw your attention to:
accuracy vs repeatability: Fanuc (and almost all other robot mfgs) spec
, not accuracy. You are asking the robot to move its TCP to a specific Cartesian pose, which is a task that requires accuracy. This can be done, but would require calibrating your robot.
Now if the robot would not end up at the same pose after you make it go somewhere else (so
), then repeatability specs would not be met and you'd have reason to 'complain'.
As far as I can tell -- from the limited information you provide -- it could well be that the robot is performing exactly as it should.
ROS' FK vs robot's FK: the urdf on the ROS side is used for visualisation tasks, but also for collision avoidance path planning in MoveIt
for performing FK based on joint angles published by the driver. The urdf you created modelled an
, based on data from the datasheets.

No robot is ever ideal, so there is a good chance that the results from FK on the ROS side show slight differences with those the robot's controller will report. This is not just due to calibration of link lengths and joint origins, but also (for larger robots and heavier payloads) due to link deflection compensation and other dynamic effects.
Similar to the previous point: it could well be that the robot is performing perfectly fine, but your expectations are not completely aligned with what a real robot would do here.
Your two points made me to have a better understanding of situation.

In my application the robot is not supposed to perform repetitive tasks but more like perception based tasks which could lead robot's TCP to different poses each time, therefore I was seeking for the accuracy that asked in the description of issue. However the calibration step seems what I am looking for in this case.
Thank you for the clarification

I want to run pr2_interactive_manipulation in a real robot, but it seems pretty broken.
see the output at
after I running:
roslaunch pr2_interactive_manipulation pr2_interactive_manipulation_robot.launch nav:=true
see the output at
after I running:
roslaunch pr2_interactive_manipulation_frontend pr2_interactive_manipulation_desktop.launch nav:=true
the rviz appears but I can not interact with the robot - no interactive markers appear anywhere.
And the fixed frame (/map) does not exist, and I manually change it to /base_link (I run the both launch file wit nav:=true).
Note that you can see the output of robot.launch, the output just cycles the following info over and over...
[ INFO] [1373485727.731924178, 29.689000000]: Waiting for service environment_server/get_robot_state
[ INFO] [1373485727.732991397, 29.689000000]: waitForService: Service [/environment_server/get_robot_state] has not been advertised, waiting...
Can you help me fix this to get interactive markers working?
Thank you very much.
Hi all,
I have successfully complied this stack on our PR2 (Ubuntu 12.04, ROS Groovy).  Note that I updated the ros groovy software on the PR2 yesterday with "sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get upgrade".
I cloned the pr2_object_manipulation stack on PR2 this morning, then used "rosdep check pr2_object_manipulation" to check the dependencies and there is no dependency error.
Then I rosmake it, and I get the [error: no matching function for call to ‘bodies::Body::containsPoint(const tf::Vector3&)’].
Then I run "sudo apt-get remove ros-groovy-geometric-shapes", it removes all moveit related packages.
After that, I re-rosmake the stack, and everything is OK.
The interactive markers are return.
Hope this experiment can help you.
Thanks.

issue_title: Action Never Finishes if Obstacle Appears On Vehicle
issue_contents: This can be fixed by ignoring junk ogrid information that the boat "has an obstacle on it" but should probably be fixed by figuring out what is actually breaking when that kind of junk is given.

If the obstacle gets erased, we just continue on with the move, which is good. However, if the obstacle never gets erased, the real problem is just that the move will never end / the action will never finish, thus bricking the robot. I'm thinking the best way to deal with this is to check if we "have collided" (an obstacle is literally ON the plan state, which should never happen) and handle that in a well defined way.
Fixed (presumably).

issue_contents: Just do it already.

Sometimes after traveling for a bit, things open up and re-planning right then would help a lot. How can we program in this intelligence? For example, escape behavior will switch to car behavior when a clear line of sight is found, but when would car decide it too should drop its last plan in favor of something else?
This is probably not necessary enough to warrant an issue. And more threading complexity may not be wise.
Hi Jason Nezvadovitz:
Thankyou for you project.
I want to know how to set in rviz so that  i can see the GUI like the picture you paste in "Readme"?
I copy the lqrrt.rviz into .rviz fold and there is a "global status:warn -- no tf data" at rviz panel

Hmm. So with lqrrt.rviz in your .rviz folder, you should be able to open rviz and then click File -> Open Config and then select lqrrt.rviz from the .rviz folder. This should create the default view for my ROS demo. Then after running catkin_make on the lqrrt_ros package, do

and 2 new windows should appear: a command GUI and a drawing pane for drawing obstacles. For the command GUI, set move_type to 'drive' and then send various goals (and for fun, increase the last option 'speed_factor' to something greater than 1). For the drawing pane, left-click to draw obstacles, right-click to erase, press q to clear all, and esc to exit. Here is a video so you can follow these steps:

You might notice that it says "behavior: car" and such. This is a simulation for a boat, actually. "car behavior" refers to the fact that I make it more likely for the boat to move tangent to its path like a car would, even though physically it can still turn in place.
Hello Jason Nezvadovitz:
You project is awesome, and can you tell me which papers or algorithm you used in this project?
LQR-RRTstar?
It has the functionality to work almost as what

describes, just without the "star" part (that is, without the "rewire" step). I used to have the rewire step too but it slowed down tree growth so much (Python isn't too fast...) that I decided to abandon that step for my real-time applications. You'll notice that one of the open Issues here is to re-implement "star" (rewiring) in an effective way. Unfortunately, I probably won't get around to that as I am caught up with other work. Thanks for checking this out though! You may also notice that many of my demos use a constant cost-to-go matrix for LQRSteer, which effectively reduces them to using the most basic form of kinodynamic RRT. Again, the reason for this was because solving a Riccati equation every iteration was too slow for my applications.
